title: For the Welfare of the People

segment_text: “Three people, mendicants, arise in the world for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of compassion for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.
title: For the Welfare of the People

segment_text: What three?
title: For the Welfare of the People

segment_text: It’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.
title: For the Welfare of the People

segment_text: He teaches Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
title: For the Welfare of the People

segment_text: This is the first person who arises in the world for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of compassion for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.
title: For the Welfare of the People

segment_text: Furthermore, it’s when a mendicant is a perfected one, with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own true goal, utterly ended the fetters of rebirth, and is rightly freed through enlightenment.
title: For the Welfare of the People

segment_text: They teach Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And they reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
title: For the Welfare of the People

segment_text: This is the second person who arises in the world for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of compassion for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.
title: For the Welfare of the People

segment_text: Furthermore, it’s when a disciple of that Teacher is a trainee, a learned practitioner with precepts and observances intact.
title: For the Welfare of the People

segment_text: They teach Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And they reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
title: For the Welfare of the People

segment_text: This is the third person who arises in the world for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of compassion for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.
title: For the Welfare of the People

segment_text: These are the three people who arise in the world for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of compassion for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.”
title: For the Welfare of the People

segment_text: The Buddha spoke this matter.
title: For the Welfare of the People

segment_text: On this it is said:
title: For the Welfare of the People

segment_text: “The Teacher is the first, the great seer,
title: For the Welfare of the People

segment_text: following whom is the evolved disciple,
title: For the Welfare of the People

segment_text: and then a trainee, a practitioner,
title: For the Welfare of the People

segment_text: learned, with precepts and observances intact.
title: For the Welfare of the People

segment_text: These three are first among gods and humans,
title: For the Welfare of the People

segment_text: beacons proclaiming the teaching!
title: For the Welfare of the People

segment_text: They fling open the door to the deathless,
title: For the Welfare of the People

segment_text: freeing many from yokes.
title: For the Welfare of the People

segment_text: Following the path so well taught
title: For the Welfare of the People

segment_text: by the unsurpassed caravan leader,
title: For the Welfare of the People

segment_text: those who are diligent in the Holy One’s teaching
title: For the Welfare of the People

title: Observing Ugliness

segment_text: “Mendicants, meditate observing the ugliness of the body.
title: Observing Ugliness

segment_text: Let mindfulness of breathing be well-established internally in front of you.
title: Observing Ugliness

segment_text: Meditate observing the impermanence of all conditions.
title: Observing Ugliness

segment_text: As you meditate observing the ugliness of the body, you will give up desire for the body.
title: Observing Ugliness

segment_text: When mindfulness of breathing is well-established internally in front of you, there will be no distressing external thoughts or wishes.
title: Observing Ugliness

segment_text: When you meditate observing the impermanence of all conditions, ignorance is given up and knowledge arises.”

title: Practicing In Line With the Teaching

segment_text: “Regarding a mendicant practicing in line with the teaching, it is in line with the teaching to declare that
title: Practicing In Line With the Teaching

segment_text: this is what it means to practice in line with the teaching. When speaking, they speak in line with the teaching, not against it. When thinking, they think in line with the teaching, not against it. And rejecting both, they meditate staying equanimous, mindful and aware.”

segment_text: The Buddha spoke this matter.
title: Practicing In Line With the Teaching

segment_text: On this it is said:
title: Practicing In Line With the Teaching

title: Practicing In Line With the Teaching

segment_text: contemplating the teaching,
title: Practicing In Line With the Teaching

title: Practicing In Line With the Teaching

segment_text: doesn’t decline in the true teaching.
title: Practicing In Line With the Teaching

title: Practicing In Line With the Teaching

segment_text: sitting or lying down,
title: Practicing In Line With the Teaching

title: Practicing In Line With the Teaching

title: Destroyers of Sight

segment_text: “Mendicants, these three unskillful thoughts are destroyers of sight, vision, and knowledge. They block wisdom, they’re on the side of anguish, and they don’t lead to extinguishment.

title: Destroyers of Sight

title: Destroyers of Sight

segment_text: malice,
title: Destroyers of Sight

title: Destroyers of Sight

title: Destroyers of Sight

segment_text: These three skillful thoughts are creators of sight, vision, and knowledge. They grow wisdom, they’re on the side of solace, and they lead to extinguishment.
title: Destroyers of Sight

title: Destroyers of Sight

title: Destroyers of Sight

title: Destroyers of Sight

title: Destroyers of Sight

title: Destroyers of Sight

title: Destroyers of Sight

title: Destroyers of Sight

title: Destroyers of Sight

segment_text: like rain on the dust,
title: Destroyers of Sight

segment_text: with a heart calmed of thought,
title: Destroyers of Sight

segment_text: you’ll touch the state of peace right here.”

title: The Best Kinds of Confidence

segment_text: “Mendicants, these three kinds of confidence are the best.
title: The Best Kinds of Confidence

segment_text: What three?
title: The Best Kinds of Confidence

segment_text: Mendicants, the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, is said to be the best of all sentient beings—be they footless, with two feet, four feet, or many feet; with form or formless; with perception or without perception or with neither perception nor non-perception.
title: The Best Kinds of Confidence

segment_text: Those who have confidence in the Buddha have confidence in the best.
title: The Best Kinds of Confidence

segment_text: Having confidence in the best, the result is the best.
title: The Best Kinds of Confidence

segment_text: Fading away is said to be the best of all things whether conditioned or unconditioned. That is, the quelling of vanity, the removing of thirst, the abolishing of clinging, the breaking of the round, the ending of craving, fading away, cessation, extinguishment.
title: The Best Kinds of Confidence

segment_text: Those who have confidence in the teaching of fading away have confidence in the best.
title: The Best Kinds of Confidence

segment_text: Having confidence in the best, the result is the best.
title: The Best Kinds of Confidence

segment_text: The Saṅgha of the Realized One’s disciples is said to be the best of all communities and groups. It consists of the four pairs, the eight individuals. This is the Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples that is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.
title: The Best Kinds of Confidence

segment_text: Those who have confidence in the Saṅgha have confidence in the best.
title: The Best Kinds of Confidence

segment_text: Having confidence in the best, the result is the best.
title: The Best Kinds of Confidence

segment_text: These are the three best kinds of confidence.”
title: The Best Kinds of Confidence

segment_text: The Buddha spoke this matter.
title: The Best Kinds of Confidence

segment_text: On this it is said:
title: The Best Kinds of Confidence

segment_text: “For those who, knowing the best teaching,
title: The Best Kinds of Confidence

title: The Best Kinds of Confidence

segment_text: confident in the best Awakened One,
title: The Best Kinds of Confidence

segment_text: supremely worthy of a religious donation;
title: The Best Kinds of Confidence

segment_text: confident in the best teaching,
title: The Best Kinds of Confidence

segment_text: the bliss of fading and stilling;
title: The Best Kinds of Confidence

segment_text: confident in the best Saṅgha,
title: The Best Kinds of Confidence

segment_text: the supreme field of merit—

title: The Best Kinds of Confidence

title: The Best Kinds of Confidence

title: The Three Knowledges

segment_text: “Mendicants, I describe a brahmin who is master of the three Vedic knowledges in terms of the teaching, not by mere oral recitation.
title: The Three Knowledges

segment_text: How so?
title: The Three Knowledges

segment_text: It’s when a mendicant recollects many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
title: The Three Knowledges

segment_text: This is the first knowledge they achieved. Ignorance was destroyed and knowledge arose; darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.
title: The Three Knowledges

segment_text: Furthermore, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, a mendicant sees sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They spoke ill of the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never spoke ill of the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
title: The Three Knowledges

segment_text: This is the second knowledge they achieved. Ignorance was destroyed and knowledge arose; darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.
title: The Three Knowledges

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
title: The Three Knowledges

segment_text: This is the third knowledge which they achieved. Ignorance was destroyed and knowledge arose; darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.
title: The Three Knowledges

segment_text: That’s how I describe a brahmin who is master of the three Vedic knowledges in terms of the teaching, not by mere oral recitation.”
title: The Three Knowledges

title: Accomplished in Ethics

segment_text: “Mendicants, take a mendicant who is accomplished in ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom. They advise and instruct. They educate, encourage, fire up, and inspire, and can rightly explain the true teaching. Even the sight of those mendicants is very helpful, I say.
title: Accomplished in Ethics

segment_text: Even to hear them,
title: Accomplished in Ethics

segment_text: approach them,
title: Accomplished in Ethics

segment_text: pay homage to them,
title: Accomplished in Ethics

segment_text: recollect them,
title: Accomplished in Ethics

segment_text: or go forth after them is very helpful, I say.
title: Accomplished in Ethics

segment_text: Why is that?
title: Accomplished in Ethics

segment_text: For one who frequents and associates with such mendicants, their incomplete spectrum of ethics is completed. Their incomplete spectrum of immersion … wisdom … freedom … knowledge and vision of freedom is completed.
title: Accomplished in Ethics

segment_text: Such mendicants are called ‘teachers’, ‘leaders of the caravan’, ‘vice-discarders’, ‘dispellers of darkness’, ‘bringers of light’, ‘luminaries’, ‘lamps’, ‘candlebearers’, ‘beacons’, ‘noble ones’, and ‘clear-eyed ones’.”

title: Very Helpful

segment_text: “Mendicants, brahmins and householders are very helpful to you, as they provide you with robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
title: Very Helpful

segment_text: And you are very helpful to brahmins and householders, as you teach them the Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And you reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
title: Very Helpful

segment_text: That is how this spiritual path is lived in mutual dependence in order to cross over the flood and make a complete end of suffering.”

title: Deceivers

segment_text: “Mendicants, those mendicants who are deceivers and flatterers, pompous and fake, insolent and scattered: those mendicants are no followers of mine.

segment_text: They’ve left this teaching and training, and they don’t achieve growth, improvement, or maturity in this teaching and training.
title: Deceivers

segment_text: But those mendicants who are genuine, not flatterers, wise, amenable, and serene: those mendicants are followers of mine.

title: A River

segment_text: “Suppose a person was being carried along by a river current that seemed nice and pleasant.
title: A River

segment_text: If a person with clear eyes saw them, they’d say:
title: A River

segment_text: ‘Mister, even though the river current carrying you along seems nice and pleasant, downstream there is a lake with waves and whirlpools, saltwater crocodiles and monsters. When you reach there it will result in death or deadly pain.’
title: A River

segment_text: Then, when they heard what was said, they’d paddle against the stream using their hands and feet.
title: A River

segment_text: I’ve made up this simile to make a point.
title: A River

segment_text: And this is the point.
title: A River

segment_text: ‘Stream’ is a term for craving.
title: A River

segment_text: ‘Seeming nice and pleasant’ is a term for the six interior sense fields.
title: A River

segment_text: ‘A downstream lake’ is a term for the five lower fetters.
title: A River

segment_text: ‘Danger of waves’ is a term for anger and distress.
title: A River

segment_text: ‘Whirlpool’ is a term for the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
title: A River

segment_text: ‘Saltwater crocodiles and monsters’ is a term for females.
title: A River

segment_text: ‘Against the stream’ is a term for renunciation.
title: A River

segment_text: ‘Paddling with hands and feet’ is a term for being energetic.
title: A River

segment_text: ‘A person with clear eyes’ is a term for the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.”
title: A River

segment_text: The Buddha spoke this matter.
title: A River

segment_text: On this it is said:
title: A River

segment_text: “In pain they’d give up sensual pleasures,
title: A River

segment_text: aspiring to the future sanctuary from the yoke.
title: A River

segment_text: With deep understanding and heart well-freed,
title: A River

segment_text: they’d experience universal liberation.
title: A River

segment_text: That knowledge master <j>who has completed the spiritual journey,
title: A River

segment_text: and gone to the end of the world, <j>is called ‘one who has gone beyond’.”
title: A River

title: Accomplishment in Ethics

segment_text: “Mendicants, live by the ethical precepts and the monastic code. Live restrained in the monastic code, conducting yourselves well and seeking alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, keep the rules you’ve undertaken.

segment_text: When you’ve done this, what more is there to do?
title: Accomplishment in Ethics

segment_text: Suppose a mendicant has got rid of desire and ill will while walking, and has given up dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, and doubt. Their energy is roused up and unflagging, their mindfulness is established and lucid, their body is tranquil and undisturbed, and their mind is immersed in samādhi.

title: The World

segment_text: In this world—with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—whatever is seen, heard, thought, known, attained, sought, and explored by the mind, all that has been understood by the Realized One.
title: The World

segment_text: That’s why he’s called the ‘Realized One’.
title: The World

segment_text: From the night when the Realized One understands the supreme perfect awakening until the night he becomes fully extinguished—in the element of extinguishment with nothing left over—everything he speaks, says, and expresses is real, not otherwise.
title: The World

segment_text: That’s why he’s called the ‘Realized One’.
title: The World

segment_text: The Realized One does as he says, and says as he does.
title: The World

title: The World

segment_text: That’s why he’s called the ‘Realized One’.”

title: With Dhaniya the Cowherd

segment_text: “It is no small gain for us

segment_text: that we have seen the Buddha.
title: With Dhaniya the Cowherd

segment_text: We come to you for refuge, Clear-eyed One.
title: With Dhaniya the Cowherd

title: With Dhaniya the Cowherd

segment_text: My wife and I, obedient,
title: With Dhaniya the Cowherd

title: With Dhaniya the Cowherd

title: With Dhaniya the Cowherd

segment_text: we shall make an end of suffering.”
title: With Dhaniya the Cowherd

segment_text: “Your children bring you delight!”
title: With Dhaniya the Cowherd

segment_text: said Māra the Wicked,
title: With Dhaniya the Cowherd

segment_text: “Your cattle also bring you delight!
title: With Dhaniya the Cowherd

title: With Dhaniya the Cowherd

segment_text: without attachments there’s no delight.”
title: With Dhaniya the Cowherd

title: With Dhaniya the Cowherd

segment_text: said the Buddha,
title: With Dhaniya the Cowherd

segment_text: “Your cattle also bring you sorrow.
title: With Dhaniya the Cowherd

title: With Dhaniya the Cowherd

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Magadhans in the Southern Hills near the brahmin village of Ekanāḷa.
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: Now at that time the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Farmer had harnessed around five hundred plows, it being the season for sowing.
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to where Bhāradvāja the Farmer was working.
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: Now at that time Bhāradvāja the Farmer was distributing food.
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: Then the Buddha went to where the distribution was taking place and stood to one side.
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: Bhāradvāja the Farmer saw him standing for alms
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: and said to him,
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: “I plough and sow, ascetic, and then I eat.
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: You too should plough and sow, then you may eat.”
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: “I too plough and sow, brahmin, and then I eat.”
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: “I don’t see Master Gotama with a yoke or plow or plowshare or goad or oxen, yet he says:
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: ‘I too plough and sow, brahmin, and then I eat.’”
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: Then Bhāradvāja the Farmer addressed the Buddha in verse:
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: “You claim to be a farmer,
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: but I don’t see you farming.
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: Tell me your farming when asked,
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: so I can recognize your farming.”
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: “Faith is my seed, fervor my rain,
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: and wisdom is my yoke and plough.
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: Conscience is my pole, mind my strap,
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: mindfulness my plowshare and goad.
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: Guarded in body and speech,
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: I restrict my intake of food.
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: I use truth as my scythe,
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: and gentleness is my release.
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: Energy is my beast of burden,
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: transporting me to sanctuary from the yoke.
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: It goes without turning back
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: where there is no sorrow.
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: That’s how to do the farming
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: that has the Deathless as its fruit.
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: When you finish this farming
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: you’re released from all suffering.”
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: Then Bhāradvāja the Farmer filled a large bronze dish with milk-rice and presented it to the Buddha:
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: “Eat the milk-rice, Master Gotama,
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: you are truly a farmer.
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: For Master Gotama does the farming that has the Deathless as its fruit.”
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: “Food enchanted by a spell isn’t fit for me to eat.
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: That’s not the principle of those who see, brahmin.
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: The Buddhas reject things enchanted with spells.
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: Since there is such a principle, brahmin, <j>that’s how they live.
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: Serve with other food and drink
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: the consummate one, the great seer,
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: with defilements ended and remorse stilled.
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: For he is the field for the seeker of merit.”
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: “Then, Master Gotama, to whom should I give the milk-rice?”
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: “Brahmin, I don’t see anyone in this world—with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—who can properly digest this milk-rice, except for the Realized One or one of his disciples.
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: Well then, brahmin, throw out the milk-rice where there is little that grows, or drop it into water that has no living creatures.”
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: So Bhāradvāja the Farmer dropped the milk-rice in water that had no living creatures.
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: And when the milk-rice was placed in the water, it sizzled and hissed, steaming and fuming.
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: Suppose there was an iron cauldron that had been heated all day. If you placed it in the water, it would sizzle and hiss, steaming and fuming.
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: In the same way, when the milk-rice was placed in the water, it sizzled and hissed, steaming and fuming.
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: Then Bhāradvāja the Farmer, shocked and awestruck,  went up to the Buddha, bowed down with his head at the Buddha’s feet, and said,
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: “Excellent, Master Gotama! Excellent!
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, Master Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways.
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: I go for refuge to Master Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: May I receive the going forth, the ordination in the ascetic Gotama’s presence?”
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: And Bhāradvāja the Farmer received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.
title: With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

segment_text: Not long after his ordination, Venerable Bhāradvāja, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

segment_text: So subtle and pleasant is the teaching
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: that is well proclaimed by you, Blessed One.
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: It’s all we long to hear. So when asked,
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: O Best of Buddhas, tell us!
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: All these mendicants have gathered,
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: and the layfolk too are here to listen.
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: Let them hear the teaching <j>the immaculate one discovered,
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: like gods listening to the fine words of Vāsava.”
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: “Listen to me, mendicants, I will educate you
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: in the cleansing teaching; all bear it in mind.
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: An intelligent person, seeing the meaning,
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: would adopt the deportment <j>proper to a renunciate.
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: No way would a mendicant go out at the wrong time;
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: at the right time, they’d walk the village for alms.
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: For chains bind one who wanders at the wrong time,
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: which is why the Buddhas avoid it.
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: Sights, sounds, tastes, smells, and touches,
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: which drive beings mad—
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: dispel desire for such things,
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: and enter for the morning meal at the right time.
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: After receiving alms for the day,
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: on returning a mendicant would sit in private alone.
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: Inwardly reflective, they’d curb their mind
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: from outside things, keeping themselves collected.
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: Should they converse with a disciple,
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: with anyone else, or with a mendicant,
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: they’d bring up only the sublime teaching,
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: not dividing or blaming.
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: For some contend in debate,
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: but we praise not those of little wisdom.
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: In place after place they are bound in chains,
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: for they send their mind over there far away.
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: Alms, a dwelling, a bed and seat,
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: and water for rinsing the dust from the cloak—
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: after hearing the teaching of the Holy One,
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: a disciple of splendid wisdom <j>would use these after appraisal.
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: That’s why, when it comes to alms and lodgings,
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: and water for rinsing the dust from the cloak,
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: a mendicant is unsullied in the midst of these things,
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: like a droplet on a lotus-leaf.
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: Now I shall tell you the householder’s duty,
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: doing which one becomes a good disciple.
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: For one burdened with possessions <j>does not get to realize
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: the whole of the mendicant’s practice.
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: They’d not kill any creature, nor have them killed,
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: nor grant permission for others to kill.
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: They’ve laid aside violence towards all creatures
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: frail or firm that there are in the world.
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: Next, a disciple would avoid knowingly
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: taking anything not given at all,
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: they’d not get others to do it, <j>nor grant them permission to steal;
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: they’d avoid all theft.
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: A sensible person would avoid the unchaste life,
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: like a burning pit of coals.
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: But if unable to remain chaste,
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: they’d not transgress with another’s partner.
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: In a council or assembly,
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: or one on one, they would not lie.
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: They’d not get others to lie, <j>nor grant them permission to lie;
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: they’d avoid all untruths.
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: A householder espousing this teaching
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: would not consume liquor or drink.
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: They’d not get others to drink, <j>nor grant them permission to drink;
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: knowing that ends in intoxication.
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: For drunken fools do bad things,
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: and encourage other heedless folk.
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: Reject this field of demerit,
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: the maddening, deluding frolic of fools.
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: You shouldn’t kill living creatures, or steal,
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: or lie, or drink alcohol.
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: Be celibate, refraining from sex,
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: and don’t eat at night, the wrong time.
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: Not wearing garlands or applying perfumes,
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: you should sleep on a low bed, <j>or a mat on the ground.
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: This is the eight-factored sabbath, they say,
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: explained by the Buddha, <j>who has gone to suffering’s end.
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: Then having rightly undertaken the sabbath
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: complete in all its eight factors
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: on the fourteenth, fifteenth, <j>and eighth of the fortnight,
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: as well as on the fortnightly special displays,
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: on the morning after the sabbath
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: a clever person, rejoicing with confident heart,
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: would distribute food and drink
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: to the mendicant Saṅgha as is fitting.
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: One should rightfully support one’s parents,
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: and undertake a legitimate business.
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: A diligent layperson observing these duties
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: ascends to the gods called Self-luminous.”
title: With Dhammika

segment_text: “I shall extol going forth
title: Going Forth

segment_text: with the example of the Clear-eyed One,
title: Going Forth

segment_text: the course of inquiry that led to
title: Going Forth

segment_text: his choice to go forth.
title: Going Forth

segment_text: ‘This life at home is cramped,
title: Going Forth

segment_text: a realm of dirt.’
title: Going Forth

segment_text: ‘The life of one gone forth is like an open space.’
title: Going Forth

segment_text: Seeing this, he went forth.
title: Going Forth

segment_text: Having gone forth, he shunned
title: Going Forth

segment_text: bad deeds of body.
title: Going Forth

segment_text: And leaving verbal misconduct behind,
title: Going Forth

segment_text: he purified his livelihood.
title: Going Forth

segment_text: The Buddha went to Rājagaha,
title: Going Forth

segment_text: the Mountainfold of the Magadhans.
title: Going Forth

segment_text: He betook himself for alms,
title: Going Forth

segment_text: replete with excellent marks.
title: Going Forth

segment_text: Bimbisāra saw him
title: Going Forth

segment_text: while standing atop his longhouse.
title: Going Forth

segment_text: Noticing that he was endowed with marks,
title: Going Forth

segment_text: he said the following:
title: Going Forth

segment_text: ‘Pay heed, sirs, to this one,
title: Going Forth

segment_text: handsome, majestic, radiant;
title: Going Forth

segment_text: accomplished in deportment,
title: Going Forth

segment_text: he looks just a plough’s length in front.
title: Going Forth

segment_text: Eyes downcast, mindful,
title: Going Forth

segment_text: unlike one from a low family.
title: Going Forth

segment_text: Let the king’s messengers run out,
title: Going Forth

segment_text: and find where the mendicant will go.’
title: Going Forth

segment_text: The messengers sent out
title: Going Forth

segment_text: followed right behind, thinking
title: Going Forth

segment_text: ‘Where will the mendicant go?
title: Going Forth

segment_text: Where shall he find a place to stay?’
title: Going Forth

segment_text: Wandering indiscriminately for alms,
title: Going Forth

segment_text: sense doors guarded and well restrained,
title: Going Forth

segment_text: his bowl was quickly filled,
title: Going Forth

segment_text: aware and mindful.
title: Going Forth

segment_text: Having wandered for alms,
title: Going Forth

segment_text: the sage left the city.
title: Going Forth

segment_text: He betook himself to Mount Paṇḍava,
title: Going Forth

segment_text: thinking, ‘Here is the place I shall stay.’
title: Going Forth

segment_text: Seeing that he had arrived at a place to stay,
title: Going Forth

segment_text: the messengers withdrew nearby,
title: Going Forth

segment_text: but one of them returned
title: Going Forth

segment_text: to inform the king.
title: Going Forth

segment_text: ‘Great king, the mendicant
title: Going Forth

segment_text: is on the east flank of Mount Paṇḍava.
title: Going Forth

segment_text: There he sits, like a tiger or a bull,
title: Going Forth

segment_text: like a lion in a mountain cave.’
title: Going Forth

segment_text: Hearing the messenger’s report,
title: Going Forth

segment_text: the aristocrat set out
title: Going Forth

segment_text: hurriedly in his fine chariot
title: Going Forth

segment_text: towards Mount Paṇḍava.
title: Going Forth

segment_text: He went as far as vehicles could go,
title: Going Forth

segment_text: then dismounted from his chariot,
title: Going Forth

segment_text: approached on foot,
title: Going Forth

segment_text: and reaching him, drew near.
title: Going Forth

segment_text: Seated, the king greeted him
title: Going Forth

segment_text: and made polite conversation.
title: Going Forth

segment_text: When the courtesies were over,
title: Going Forth

segment_text: he said the following:
title: Going Forth

segment_text: ‘You are young, just a youth,
title: Going Forth

segment_text: a lad in the prime of life.
title: Going Forth

segment_text: You are endowed with beauty and stature,
title: Going Forth

segment_text: like an aristocrat of good lineage
title: Going Forth

segment_text: in glory at the army’s head,
title: Going Forth

segment_text: surrounded by a troop of elephants.
title: Going Forth

segment_text: I offer you pleasures—enjoy them!
title: Going Forth

segment_text: But please tell me your lineage by birth.’
title: Going Forth

segment_text: ‘Up north, O King, on the slopes
title: Going Forth

segment_text: of the Himalayas, lies the land
title: Going Forth

segment_text: of a native among the Kosalans,
title: Going Forth

segment_text: full of wealth and strength.
title: Going Forth

segment_text: They are of the Solar clan,
title: Going Forth

segment_text: their lineage is the Sakyans.
title: Going Forth

segment_text: I have gone forth from that family—
title: Going Forth

segment_text: I do not yearn for sensual pleasure.
title: Going Forth

segment_text: Seeing the danger in sensual pleasures,
title: Going Forth

segment_text: seeing renunciation as sanctuary,
title: Going Forth

segment_text: I shall go on to strive;
title: Going Forth

segment_text: that is where my mind delights.’”
title: Going Forth

segment_text: “During my time of resolute striving
title: Striving

segment_text: on the bank of the Nerañjara River,
title: Striving

segment_text: I was meditating very hard
title: Striving

segment_text: for the sake of finding sanctuary from the yoke.
title: Striving

segment_text: Namucī approached,
title: Striving

segment_text: speaking words of kindness:
title: Striving

segment_text: ‘You’re thin, discolored,
title: Striving

segment_text: on the verge of death.
title: Striving

segment_text: Death has a thousand parts of you,
title: Striving

segment_text: one fraction is left to life.
title: Striving

segment_text: Live sir! Life is better!
title: Striving

segment_text: Living, you can make merits.
title: Striving

segment_text: While leading the spiritual life
title: Striving

segment_text: and serving the sacred flame,
title: Striving

segment_text: you can pile up abundant merit—
title: Striving

segment_text: so what will striving do for you?
title: Striving

segment_text: Hard to walk is the path of striving,
title: Striving

segment_text: hard to do, a hard challenge to win.’”
title: Striving

segment_text: These are the verses Māra spoke
title: Striving

segment_text: as he stood beside the Buddha.
title: Striving

segment_text: When Māra had spoken in this way,
title: Striving

segment_text: the Buddha said this:
title: Striving

segment_text: “O Wicked One, kinsman of the negligent,
title: Striving

segment_text: you’re here for your own purpose.
title: Striving

segment_text: I have no need for
title: Striving

segment_text: the slightest bit of merit.
title: Striving

segment_text: Those with need for merit
title: Striving

segment_text: are fit for Māra to address.
title: Striving

segment_text: I have faith and energy too,
title: Striving

segment_text: and wisdom is found in me.
title: Striving

segment_text: When I am so resolute,
title: Striving

segment_text: why do you beg me to live?
title: Striving

segment_text: The rivers and streams
title: Striving

segment_text: might be dried by the wind,
title: Striving

segment_text: so why, when I am resolute,
title: Striving

segment_text: should it not dry up my blood?
title: Striving

segment_text: And while the blood is drying up,
title: Striving

segment_text: the bile and phlegm dry too.
title: Striving

segment_text: And as my muscles waste away,
title: Striving

segment_text: my mind grows more serene.
title: Striving

segment_text: And all the stronger grow mindfulness
title: Striving

segment_text: and wisdom and immersion.
title: Striving

segment_text: As I meditate like this,
title: Striving

segment_text: having attained the supreme feeling,
title: Striving

segment_text: my mind has no interest in sensual pleasures:
title: Striving

segment_text: behold a being’s purity!
title: Striving

segment_text: Sensual pleasures are your first army,
title: Striving

segment_text: the second is called discontent,
title: Striving

segment_text: hunger and thirst are the third,
title: Striving

segment_text: and the fourth is said to be craving.
title: Striving

segment_text: Your fifth is dullness and drowsiness,
title: Striving

segment_text: the sixth is said to be cowardice,
title: Striving

segment_text: your seventh is doubt,
title: Striving

segment_text: contempt and obstinacy are your eighth.
title: Striving

segment_text: Profit, praise, and honor,
title: Striving

segment_text: and misbegotten fame;
title: Striving

segment_text: the extolling of oneself
title: Striving

segment_text: while scorning others.
title: Striving

segment_text: This is your army, Namucī,
title: Striving

segment_text: the strike force of the Dark One.
title: Striving

segment_text: Only a hero can defeat it,
title: Striving

segment_text: but in victory there lies bliss.
title: Striving

segment_text: Let me gird myself—
title: Striving

segment_text: so what if I die!
title: Striving

segment_text: I’d rather die in battle
title: Striving

segment_text: than live on in defeat.
title: Striving

segment_text: Here some ascetics and brahmins
title: Striving

segment_text: are swallowed up, not to be seen again.
title: Striving

segment_text: And they do not know the path
title: Striving

segment_text: traveled by those true to their vows.
title: Striving

segment_text: Seeing Māra ready on his mount,
title: Striving

segment_text: surrounded by his bannered forces,
title: Striving

segment_text: I shall meet them in battle—
title: Striving

segment_text: they’ll never make me retreat!
title: Striving

segment_text: That army of yours has never been beaten
title: Striving

segment_text: by the world with all its gods.
title: Striving

segment_text: Yet I shall smash it with wisdom,
title: Striving

segment_text: like an unfired pot with a stone.
title: Striving

segment_text: Having brought my thoughts under control,
title: Striving

segment_text: and established mindfulness well,
title: Striving

segment_text: I shall wander from country to country,
title: Striving

segment_text: guiding many disciples.
title: Striving

segment_text: Diligent and resolute,
title: Striving

segment_text: following my instructions,
title: Striving

segment_text: they will proceed despite your will,
title: Striving

segment_text: to where there is no sorrow.”
title: Striving

segment_text: “For seven years I followed
title: Striving

segment_text: step by step behind the Blessed One.
title: Striving

segment_text: I found no vulnerability
title: Striving

segment_text: in the mindful Awakened One.
title: Striving

segment_text: A crow once circled a stone
title: Striving

segment_text: that looked like a lump of fat.
title: Striving

segment_text: ‘Perhaps I’ll find something tender,’ it thought,
title: Striving

segment_text: ‘perhaps there’s something tasty.’
title: Striving

segment_text: But finding nothing tasty,
title: Striving

segment_text: the crow left that place.
title: Striving

segment_text: Like the crow that pecked the stone,
title: Striving

segment_text: I leave Gotama disappointed.”
title: Striving

segment_text: So stricken with sorrow
title: Striving

segment_text: that his harp dropped from his armpit,
title: Striving

segment_text: that spirit, downcast,
title: Striving

segment_text: vanished right there.
title: Striving

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: Well-Spoken Words

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: Well-Spoken Words

segment_text: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
title: Well-Spoken Words

segment_text: “Mendicants!”
title: Well-Spoken Words

segment_text: “Venerable sir,” they replied.
title: Well-Spoken Words

segment_text: The Buddha said this:
title: Well-Spoken Words

segment_text: “Mendicants, speech that has four factors is well spoken, not poorly spoken. It’s blameless and is not criticized by sensible people.
title: Well-Spoken Words

segment_text: What four?
title: Well-Spoken Words

segment_text: It’s when a mendicant speaks well, not poorly; they speak on the teaching, not against the teaching; they speak pleasantly, not unpleasantly; and they speak truthfully, not falsely.
title: Well-Spoken Words

segment_text: Speech with these four factors is well spoken, not poorly spoken. It’s blameless and is not criticized by sensible people.”
title: Well-Spoken Words

segment_text: That is what the Buddha said.
title: Well-Spoken Words

segment_text: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
title: Well-Spoken Words

segment_text: “Good people say well-spoken words are foremost;
title: Well-Spoken Words

segment_text: second, speak on the teaching, not against it;
title: Well-Spoken Words

segment_text: third, speak pleasantly, not unpleasantly;
title: Well-Spoken Words

segment_text: and fourth, speak truthfully, not falsely.”
title: Well-Spoken Words

segment_text: Then Venerable Vaṅgīsa got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said,
title: Well-Spoken Words

segment_text: “I feel inspired to speak, Blessed One! I feel inspired to speak, Holy One!”
title: Well-Spoken Words

segment_text: “Then speak as you feel inspired,” said the Buddha.
title: Well-Spoken Words

segment_text: Then Vaṅgīsa extolled the Buddha in his presence with fitting verses:
title: Well-Spoken Words

segment_text: “Speak only such words
title: Well-Spoken Words

segment_text: that do not hurt yourself
title: Well-Spoken Words

segment_text: nor harm others;
title: Well-Spoken Words

segment_text: such speech is truly well spoken.
title: Well-Spoken Words

segment_text: Speak only pleasing words,
title: Well-Spoken Words

segment_text: words gladly welcomed.
title: Well-Spoken Words

segment_text: Pleasing words are those
title: Well-Spoken Words

segment_text: that bring nothing bad to others.
title: Well-Spoken Words

segment_text: Truth itself is the undying word:
title: Well-Spoken Words

segment_text: this is an eternal truth.
title: Well-Spoken Words

segment_text: Good people say that the teaching and its meaning
title: Well-Spoken Words

segment_text: are grounded in the truth.
title: Well-Spoken Words

segment_text: The words spoken by the Buddha
title: Well-Spoken Words

segment_text: for finding the sanctuary, extinguishment,
title: Well-Spoken Words

segment_text: for the attainment of vision,
title: Well-Spoken Words

segment_text: this really is the best kind of speech.”
title: Well-Spoken Words

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā on the Sacrificial Cake

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying in the Kosalan lands on the bank of the Sundarikā river.
title: With Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā on the Sacrificial Cake

segment_text: Now at that time the brahmin Sundarikabhāradvāja was serving the sacred flame and performing the fire sacrifice on the bank of the Sundarikā.
title: With Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā on the Sacrificial Cake

segment_text: Then he looked all around the four quarters, wondering,
title: With Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā on the Sacrificial Cake

segment_text: “Now who might eat the leftovers of this offering?”
title: With Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā on the Sacrificial Cake

segment_text: He saw the Buddha meditating at the root of a certain tree with his robe pulled over his head.
title: With Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā on the Sacrificial Cake

segment_text: Taking the leftovers of the offering in his left hand and a pitcher in the right he approached the Buddha.
title: With Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā on the Sacrificial Cake

segment_text: When he heard Sundarikabhāradvāja’s footsteps the Buddha uncovered his head.
title: With Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā on the Sacrificial Cake

segment_text: Sundarikabhāradvāja thought, “This man is shaven, he is shaven!” And he wanted to turn back.
title: With Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā on the Sacrificial Cake

segment_text: But he thought,
title: With Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā on the Sacrificial Cake

segment_text: “Even some brahmins are shaven. Why don’t I go to him and ask about his birth?”
title: With Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā on the Sacrificial Cake

segment_text: Then the brahmin Sundarikabhāradvāja went up to the Buddha, and said to him,
title: With Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā on the Sacrificial Cake

segment_text: “Sir, in what caste were you born?”
title: With Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā on the Sacrificial Cake

segment_text: Then the Buddha addressed Sundarikabhāradvāja in verse:
title: With Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā on the Sacrificial Cake

segment_text: “I am no brahmin, nor am I a prince,
title: With Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā on the Sacrificial Cake

segment_text: nor peasant nor anything else.
title: With Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā on the Sacrificial Cake

segment_text: Fully understanding the clan of ordinary people,
title: With Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā on the Sacrificial Cake

segment_text: I wander in the world owning nothing, reflective.
title: With Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā on the Sacrificial Cake

segment_text: Clad in my cloak, I wander without home,
title: With Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā on the Sacrificial Cake

segment_text: my hair shorn, quenched.
title: With Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā on the Sacrificial Cake

segment_text: Since I’m unburdened by youngsters,
title: With Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā on the Sacrificial Cake

segment_text: it’s inappropriate to ask me about clan.”
title: With Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā on the Sacrificial Cake

segment_text: “Actually sir, when brahmins meet they politely
title: With Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā on the Sacrificial Cake

segment_text: ask each other whether they are brahmins.”
title: With Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā on the Sacrificial Cake

segment_text: “Well, if you say that you’re a brahmin,
title: With Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā on the Sacrificial Cake

segment_text: and that I am not,
title: With Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā on the Sacrificial Cake

segment_text: I shall question you on the Gāyatrī Mantra,
title: With Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā on the Sacrificial Cake

segment_text: with its three lines and twenty-four syllables.”
title: With Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā on the Sacrificial Cake

segment_text: “On what grounds have seers and men,
title: With Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā on the Sacrificial Cake

segment_text: aristocrats and brahmins here in the world
title: With Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā on the Sacrificial Cake

segment_text: performed so many different sacrifices to the gods?”
title: With Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā on the Sacrificial Cake

segment_text: “During a sacrifice, should a past-master, <j>a knowledge master,
title: With Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā on the Sacrificial Cake
