segment_text: Now at that time the wanderer Sabhiya had been presented with several questions by a deity who was a former blood relation, saying:
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: “Sabhiya, you should live the spiritual life with whatever ascetic or brahmin answers these questions.”
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Then Sabhiya, after learning those questions in the presence of that deity, approached those ascetics and brahmins who led an order and a community, and taught a community, who were well-known and famous religious founders, deemed holy by many people. That is,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Pūraṇa Kassapa, the bamboo-staffed ascetic Gosāla, Ajita of the hair blanket, Pakudha Kaccāyana, Sañjaya Belaṭṭhiputta, and the Jain ascetic of the Ñātika clan.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: And he asked them those questions,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: but they were stumped by them.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Displaying annoyance, hate, and bitterness,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: they questioned Sabiya in return.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Then Sabhiya thought,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: “Those famous ascetics and brahmins
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: were stumped by my questions.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Displaying annoyance, hate, and bitterness,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: they questioned me in return on that matter.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Why don’t I return to a lesser life so I can enjoy sensual pleasures?”
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Then Sabhiya thought,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: “This ascetic Gotama also leads an order and a community, and teaches a community. He’s a well-known and famous religious founder, deemed holy by many people.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Why don’t I ask him this question?”
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Then he thought,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: “Even those ascetics and brahmins who are elderly and senior, who are advanced in years and have reached the final stage of life; who are senior, long standing, long gone forth; who lead an order and a community, and teach a community; who are well-known and famous religious founders, deemed holy by many people—that is
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Pūraṇa Kassapa and the rest—
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: were stumped by my questions.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: They displayed annoyance, hate, and bitterness, and even questioned me in return.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: How can the ascetic Gotama possibly answer my questions,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: since he is so young in age and newly gone forth?”
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Then he thought,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: “An ascetic should not be looked down upon or disparaged because they are young.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Though young, the ascetic Gotama has great psychic power and might. Why don’t I ask him this question?”
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Then Sabhiya set out for Rājagaha.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Traveling stage by stage, he came to Rājagaha, the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground. He went up to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: and addressed the Buddha in verse:
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: “I’ve come full of  doubts and uncertainties,”
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: said Sabhiya,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: “wishing to ask some questions.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Please solve them for me.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Answer my questions in turn, <j>in accordance with the truth.”
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: “You have come from afar, Sabhiya,”
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: said the Buddha,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: “wishing to ask some questions.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: I shall solve them for you,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: answering your questions in turn, <j>in accordance with the truth.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Ask me your question, Sabhiya,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: whatever you want.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: I’ll solve each and every
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: question you have.”
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Then Sabhiya thought,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: “Oh, how incredible, how amazing!
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Where those other ascetics and brahmins didn’t even give me a chance, the Buddha has invited me.”
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Uplifted and elated, full of rapture and happiness, he asked this question.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: “What must one attain to be called a mendicant?”
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: said Sabhiya,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: “How is one ‘sweet’, how said to be ‘tamed’?
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: How is one declared to be ‘awakened’?
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: May the Buddha please answer my question.”
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: “When by the path they have walked themselves,”
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: said the Buddha to Sabhiya,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: “they reach quenching, with doubt overcome;
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: giving up desire to continue existence or to end it,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: their journey complete, their rebirths ended: <j>that is a mendicant.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Equanimous towards everything, mindful,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: they don’t harm anyone in the world.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: An ascetic who has crossed over, unclouded,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: not full of themselves, is sweet-natured.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Their faculties have been developed
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: inside and out in the whole world.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Having pierced through this world and the next,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: tamed, they bide their time.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: They have examined the eons in their entirety,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: and both sides of transmigration—<j>passing away and rebirth.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Rid of dust, unblemished, purified:
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: the one they call ‘awakened’ has attained <j>the end of rebirth.”
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: And then, having approved and agreed with what the Buddha said, uplifted and elated, full of rapture and happiness, Sabhiya asked another question:
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: “What must one attain to be called ‘brahmin’?”
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: said Sabhiya.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: “Why is one an ‘ascetic’, and how a ‘bathed initiate’?
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: How is one declared to be a ‘giant’?
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: May the Buddha please answer my question.”
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: “Having banished all bad things,”
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: said the Buddha to Sabhiya,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: “immaculate, well-composed, steadfast,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: consummate, they’ve left transmigration behind:
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: unattached, one such is called ‘brahmin’.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: A peaceful one who has given up good and evil,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: stainless, understanding this world and the next,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: gone beyond rebirth and death:
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: one such is rightly called ‘ascetic’.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Having washed off all bad things
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: inside and out in the whole world,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: among gods and humans bound to creations,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: the one they call ‘washed’ does not return to creation.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: They do nothing monstrous at all in the world,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: discarding all yokes and bonds,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: everywhere not stuck, freed:
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: one such is rightly called ‘giant’.”
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: And then Sabhiya asked another question:
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: “Who is a ‘field-victor’ according to the Buddhas?”
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: said Sabhiya,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: “Why is one ‘skillful’, and how ‘a wise scholar’?
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: How is one declared to be a ‘sage’?
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: May the Buddha please answer my question.”
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: “They are victors on the fields of deeds in their entirety,”
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: said the Buddha to Sabhiya,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: “the fields of gods, humans, and Brahmas;
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: released from the root bondage to all fields:
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: one such is rightly called ‘field-victor’.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: They have examined the coffers in their entirety,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: the coffers of gods, humans, and Brahmas;
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: released from the root bondage to all coffers:
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: one such is rightly called ‘skillful’.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: They have examined whiteness
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: both inside and out; understanding purity,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: they have left dark and bright behind:
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: one such is rightly called ‘a wise scholar’.”
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Understanding the nature of the bad and the good
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: inside and out in the whole world;
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: one worthy of honor by gods and humans,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: who has escaped from the net and the snare: <j>that is a sage.”
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: And then Sabhiya asked another question:
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: “What must one attain <j>to be called ‘knowledge master’?”
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: said Sabhiya,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: “Why is one ‘studied’, and how is one ‘heroic’?
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: How to gain the name ‘thoroughbred’?
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: May the Buddha please answer my question.”
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: “They have examined knowledges in their entirety,”
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: said the Buddha to Sabhiya,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: “those that are current among ascetics and brahmins;
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: rid of greed for all feelings,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: having left all knowledges behind: <j>that is a knowledge master.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Having studied proliferation and name & form
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: inside and out—the root of disease;
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: released from the root bondage to all disease:
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: one such is rightly called ‘studied’.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Refraining from all evil here,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: heroic, he escapes from the suffering of hell;
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: he is heroic and energetic:
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: one such is rightly called ‘hero’.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Whoever’s bonds are cut,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: the root of clinging inside and out;
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: released from the root bondage to all clinging:
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: one such is rightly called ‘thoroughbred’.”
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: And then Sabhiya asked another question:
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: “What must one attain to be called ‘scholar’?”
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: said Sabhiya,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: “Why is one ‘noble’, and how is one ‘well conducted’?
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: How to gain the name ‘wanderer’?
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: May the Buddha please answer my question.”
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: “One who has learned every teaching,”
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: said the Buddha to Sabhiya,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: “and has known for themselves what in the world <j>is blameworthy and blameless;
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: a champion, decided, liberated,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: untroubled everywhere: they call them ‘scholar’.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Having cut off defilements and clingings,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: being wise, they enter no womb.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: They’ve expelled the bog of the three perceptions,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: the one they call ‘noble’ does not return to creation.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: One here who is accomplished <j>and skillful in all forms of good conduct;
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: always understanding the teaching,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: everywhere not stuck, freed in mind,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: who has no repulsion: they are ‘well-conducted’.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: They wander full of wisdom,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: having banished any deed that results in suffering,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: deceit and conceit, as well as greed and anger,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: above, below, all round, between.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: They have made a limit on name & form;
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: the one they call a ‘wanderer’ <j>has reached their destination.”
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: And then, having approved and agreed with what the Buddha said, uplifted and elated, full of rapture and happiness, Sabhiya got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and extolled the Buddha in his presence with fitting verses:
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: “O one of vast wisdom, <j>there are three & sixty opinions
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: based on the doctrines of ascetics:
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: they are expressions of perception, <j>based on perception.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Having dispelled them all, <j>you passed over the dark flood.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: You have gone to the end, gone beyond suffering,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: you are perfected, a fully awakened Buddha; <j>I think you have ended defilements.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Splendid, intelligent, abounding in wisdom,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: ender of suffering—you brought me across!
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: When you understood my uncertainty,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: you brought me beyond doubt—homage to you!
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: A sage, accomplished in the ways of sagacity,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: you are gentle, not hardhearted, <j>O kinsman of the Sun.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Any doubts that I once had,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: you have answered for me, O Clear-eyed One.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Clearly you are a sage, an Awakened One,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: there are no hindrances in you.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: All your distress
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: is blown away and mown down.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Cooled, tamed, steadfast:
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: truth is your strength.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: O giant among giants, O great hero,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: when you are speaking
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: all the gods rejoice,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: including both Nārada and Pabbata.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Homage to you, O thoroughbred!
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Homage to you, supreme among men!
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: In the world with its gods,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: you have no rival.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: You are the Buddha, you are the Teacher,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: you are the sage who has overcome Māra;
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: you have cut off the underlying tendencies,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: you’ve crossed over, and you bring humanity across.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: You have transcended attachments,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: your defilements are shattered;
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: you are a lion, free of grasping,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: with fear and dread given up.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Like a graceful lotus
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: to which water does not stick,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: so both good and evil
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: do not stick to you.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Stretch out your feet, great hero:
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Sabhiya bows to the Teacher.”
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Then the wanderer Sabhiya bowed with his head at the Buddha’s feet and said,
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: “Excellent, sir! Excellent! …
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: Sir, may I receive the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence?”
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: “Sabhiya, if someone formerly ordained in another sect wishes to take the going forth, the ordination in this teaching and training, they must spend four months on probation. When four months have passed, if the mendicants are satisfied, they’ll give the going forth, the ordination into monkhood.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: However, I have recognized individual differences in this matter.”
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: “Sir, if four months probation are required in such a case, I’ll spend four years on probation. When four years have passed, if the mendicants are satisfied, let them give me the going forth, the ordination into monkhood.”
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: And the wanderer Sabhiya received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: And Venerable Sabhiya became one of the perfected.
title: With Sabhiya

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Sela

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Northern Āpaṇas together with a large Saṅgha of 1,250 mendicants when he arrived at a town of the Northern Āpaṇas named Āpaṇa.
title: With Sela

segment_text: The matted-hair ascetic Keṇiya heard:
title: With Sela

segment_text: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—has arrived at Āpaṇa, together with a large Saṅgha of 1,250 mendicants.
title: With Sela

segment_text: He has this good reputation:
title: With Sela

segment_text: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
title: With Sela

segment_text: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
title: With Sela

segment_text: He teaches Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
title: With Sela

segment_text: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”
title: With Sela

segment_text: So Keṇiya approached the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.
title: With Sela

segment_text: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.
title: With Sela

segment_text: The Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired him with a Dhamma talk.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Then he said to the Buddha,
title: With Sela

segment_text: “Would Master Gotama together with the mendicant Saṅgha please accept tomorrow’s meal from me?”
title: With Sela

segment_text: When he said this, the Buddha said to him,
title: With Sela

segment_text: “The Saṅgha is large, Keṇiya; there are 1,250 mendicants. And you are devoted to the brahmins.”
title: With Sela

segment_text: For a second time, Keṇiya asked the Buddha to accept a meal offering.
title: With Sela

segment_text: “Never mind that the Saṅgha is large, with 1,250 mendicants, and that I am devoted to the brahmins.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Would Master Gotama together with the mendicant Saṅgha please accept tomorrow’s meal from me?”
title: With Sela

segment_text: And for a second time, the Buddha gave the same reply.
title: With Sela

segment_text: For a third time, Keṇiya asked the Buddha to accept a meal offering.
title: With Sela

segment_text: “Never mind that the Saṅgha is large, with 1,250 mendicants, and that I am devoted to the brahmins.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Would Master Gotama together with the mendicant Saṅgha please accept tomorrow’s meal from me?”
title: With Sela

segment_text: The Buddha consented with silence.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, Keṇiya got up from his seat and went to his own hermitage. There he addressed his friends and colleagues, relatives and family members,
title: With Sela

segment_text: “My friends and colleagues, relatives and family members: please listen!
title: With Sela

segment_text: The ascetic Gotama together with the mendicant Saṅgha has been invited by me for tomorrow’s meal.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Please help me with the preparations.”
title: With Sela

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” they replied. Some dug ovens, some chopped wood, some washed dishes, some set out a water jar, and some spread out seats.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Meanwhile, Keṇiya set up the pavilion himself.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Now at that time the brahmin Sela was residing in Āpaṇa. He had mastered the three Vedas, together with their vocabularies, ritual, phonology and etymology, and the testament as fifth. He knew philology and grammar, and was well versed in cosmology and the marks of a great man. And he was teaching three hundred students to recite the hymns.
title: With Sela

segment_text: And at that time Keṇiya was devoted to Sela.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Then Sela, while going for a walk escorted by the three hundred students, approached Keṇiya’s hermitage.
title: With Sela

segment_text: He saw the preparations going on,
title: With Sela

segment_text: and said to Keṇiya,
title: With Sela

segment_text: “Keṇiya, is your son or daughter being married? Or are you setting up a big sacrifice? Or has King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha been invited for tomorrow’s meal?”
title: With Sela

segment_text: “There is no marriage, Sela, and the king is not coming.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Rather, I am setting up a big sacrifice.
title: With Sela

segment_text: The ascetic Gotama has arrived at Āpaṇa, together with a large Saṅgha of 1,250 mendicants.
title: With Sela

segment_text: He has this good reputation:
title: With Sela

segment_text: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
title: With Sela

segment_text: He has been invited by me for tomorrow’s meal together with the mendicant Saṅgha.”
title: With Sela

segment_text: “Mister Keṇiya, did you say ‘the awakened one’?”
title: With Sela

segment_text: “I said ‘the awakened one’.”
title: With Sela

segment_text: “Mister Keṇiya, did you say ‘the awakened one’?”
title: With Sela

segment_text: “I said ‘the awakened one’.”
title: With Sela

segment_text: Then Sela thought,
title: With Sela

segment_text: “It’s hard to even find the word ‘awakened one’ in the world.
title: With Sela

segment_text: The thirty-two marks of a great man have been handed down in our hymns. A great man who possesses these has only two possible destinies, no other.
title: With Sela

segment_text: If he stays at home he becomes a king, a wheel-turning monarch, a just and principled king. His dominion extends to all four sides, he achieves stability in the country, and he possesses the seven treasures.
title: With Sela

segment_text: He has the following seven treasures:
title: With Sela

segment_text: the wheel, the elephant, the horse, the jewel, the woman, the treasurer, and the counselor as the seventh treasure.
title: With Sela

segment_text: He has over a thousand sons who are valiant and heroic, crushing the armies of his enemies.
title: With Sela

segment_text: After conquering this land girt by sea, he reigns by principle, without rod or sword.
title: With Sela

segment_text: But if he goes forth from the lay life to homelessness, he becomes a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha, who draws back the veil from the world.
title: With Sela

segment_text: “But Keṇiya, where is the Blessed One at present, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?”
title: With Sela

segment_text: When he said this, Keṇiya pointed with his right arm and said,
title: With Sela

segment_text: “There, Mister Sela, at that line of blue forest.”
title: With Sela

segment_text: Then Sela, together with his students, approached the Buddha.
title: With Sela

segment_text: He said to his students,
title: With Sela

segment_text: “Come quietly, gentlemen, tread gently.
title: With Sela

segment_text: For the Buddhas are intimidating, like a lion living alone.
title: With Sela

segment_text: When I’m consulting with the ascetic Gotama, don’t interrupt.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Wait until I’ve finished speaking.”
title: With Sela

segment_text: Then Sela went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.
title: With Sela

segment_text: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.
title: With Sela

segment_text: and scrutinized the Buddha’s body for the thirty-two marks of a great man.
title: With Sela

segment_text: He saw all of them except for two,
title: With Sela

segment_text: which he had doubts about:
title: With Sela

segment_text: whether the private parts were covered in a foreskin, and the largeness of the tongue.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Then it occurred to the Buddha,
title: With Sela

segment_text: “Sela sees all the marks except for two,
title: With Sela

segment_text: which he has doubts about:
title: With Sela

segment_text: whether the private parts are covered in a foreskin, and the largeness of the tongue.”
title: With Sela

segment_text: The Buddha used his psychic power to will that Sela would see his private parts covered in a foreskin.
title: With Sela

segment_text: And he stuck out his tongue and stroked back and forth on his ear holes and nostrils, and covered his entire forehead with his tongue.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Then Sela thought,
title: With Sela

segment_text: “The ascetic Gotama possesses the thirty-two marks completely, lacking none.
title: With Sela

segment_text: But I don’t know whether or not he is an awakened one.
title: With Sela

segment_text: I have heard that brahmins of the past who were elderly and senior, the teachers of teachers, said,
title: With Sela

segment_text: ‘Those who are perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas reveal themselves when praised.’
title: With Sela

segment_text: Why don’t I extoll him in his presence with fitting verses?”
title: With Sela

segment_text: Then Sela extolled the Buddha in his presence with fitting verses:
title: With Sela

segment_text: “O Blessed One, your body’s perfect,
title: With Sela

segment_text: you’re radiant, handsome, lovely to behold;
title: With Sela

segment_text: golden colored,
title: With Sela

segment_text: with teeth so white; you’re strong.
title: With Sela

segment_text: The characteristics
title: With Sela

segment_text: of a handsome man,
title: With Sela

segment_text: the marks of a great man,
title: With Sela

segment_text: are all found on your body.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Your eyes are clear, your face is fair,
title: With Sela

segment_text: you’re formidable, upright, majestic.
title: With Sela

segment_text: In the midst of the Saṅgha of ascetics,
title: With Sela

segment_text: you shine like the sun.
title: With Sela

segment_text: You’re a mendicant fine to see,
title: With Sela

segment_text: with skin of golden sheen.
title: With Sela

segment_text: But with such excellent appearance,
title: With Sela

segment_text: what do you want with the ascetic life?
title: With Sela

segment_text: You’re fit to be a king,
title: With Sela

segment_text: a wheel-turning monarch, chief of charioteers,
title: With Sela

segment_text: victorious in the four quarters,
title: With Sela

segment_text: lord of all India.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Aristocrats, nobles, and kings
title: With Sela

segment_text: ought follow your rule.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Gotama, you should reign
title: With Sela

segment_text: as king of kings, lord of men!”
title: With Sela

segment_text: “I am a king, Sela”,
title: With Sela

segment_text: said the Buddha,
title: With Sela

segment_text: “the supreme king of the teaching.
title: With Sela

segment_text: By the teaching I roll forth the wheel
title: With Sela

segment_text: which cannot be rolled back.”
title: With Sela

segment_text: “You claim to be awakened,”
title: With Sela

segment_text: said Sela the brahmin,
title: With Sela

segment_text: “the supreme king of the teaching.
title: With Sela

segment_text: ‘I roll forth the teaching’:
title: With Sela

segment_text: so you say, Gotama.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Then who is your general,
title: With Sela

segment_text: the disciple who follows the Teacher’s way?
title: With Sela

segment_text: Who keeps rolling the wheel
title: With Sela

segment_text: of the teaching you rolled forth?”
title: With Sela

segment_text: “By me the wheel was rolled forth,”
title: With Sela

segment_text: said the Buddha,
title: With Sela

segment_text: “the supreme wheel of the teaching.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Sāriputta, taking after the Realized One,
title: With Sela

segment_text: keeps it rolling on.
title: With Sela

segment_text: I have known what should be known,
title: With Sela

segment_text: and developed what should be developed,
title: With Sela

segment_text: and given up what should be given up:
title: With Sela

segment_text: and so, brahmin, I am a Buddha.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Dispel your doubt in me—
title: With Sela

segment_text: make up your mind, brahmin!
title: With Sela

segment_text: The sight of a Buddha
title: With Sela

segment_text: is hard to find again.
title: With Sela

segment_text: I am a Buddha, brahmin,
title: With Sela

segment_text: the supreme surgeon,
title: With Sela

segment_text: one of those whose appearance in the world
title: With Sela

segment_text: is hard to find again.
title: With Sela

segment_text: A manifestation of divinity, unequaled,
title: With Sela

segment_text: crusher of Māra’s army;
title: With Sela

segment_text: having subdued all my opponents,
title: With Sela

segment_text: I rejoice, fearing nothing from any quarter.”
title: With Sela

segment_text: “Pay heed, sirs, to what
title: With Sela

segment_text: is spoken by the Clear-eyed One.
title: With Sela

segment_text: The surgeon, the great hero,
title: With Sela

segment_text: roars like a lion in the jungle.
title: With Sela

segment_text: A manifestation of divinity, unequaled,
title: With Sela

segment_text: crusher of Māra’s army;
title: With Sela

segment_text: who would not be inspired by him,
title: With Sela

segment_text: even one whose nature is dark?
title: With Sela

segment_text: Those who wish may follow me;
title: With Sela

segment_text: those who don’t may go.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Right here, I’ll go forth in his presence,
title: With Sela

segment_text: the one of such splendid wisdom.”
title: With Sela

segment_text: “Sir, if you like
title: With Sela

segment_text: in the teaching of the Buddha,
title: With Sela

segment_text: we’ll also go forth in his presence,
title: With Sela

segment_text: the one of such splendid wisdom.”
title: With Sela

segment_text: “These three hundred brahmins
title: With Sela

segment_text: with joined palms held up, ask:
title: With Sela

segment_text: ‘May we lead the spiritual life
title: With Sela

segment_text: in your presence, Blessed One?’”
title: With Sela

segment_text: “The spiritual life is well explained,”
title: With Sela

segment_text: said the Buddha,
title: With Sela

segment_text: “apparent in the present life, immediately effective.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Here the going forth isn’t in vain
title: With Sela

segment_text: for one who trains with diligence.”
title: With Sela

segment_text: And the brahmin Sela together with his assembly received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.
title: With Sela

segment_text: And when the night had passed Keṇiya had delicious fresh and cooked foods prepared in his own home. Then he had the Buddha informed of the time, saying,
title: With Sela

segment_text: “It’s time, Master Gotama, the meal is ready.”
title: With Sela

segment_text: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to Keṇiya’s hermitage, where he sat on the seat spread out, together with the Saṅgha of mendicants.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Then Keṇiya served and satisfied the mendicant Saṅgha headed by the Buddha with his own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.
title: With Sela

segment_text: When the Buddha had eaten and washed his hand and bowl, Keṇiya took a low seat and sat to one side.
title: With Sela

segment_text: The Buddha expressed his appreciation with these verses:
title: With Sela

segment_text: “The foremost of sacrifices <j>is the offering to the sacred flame;
title: With Sela

segment_text: the Gāyatrī Mantra is the foremost of poetic meters;
title: With Sela

segment_text: of humans, the king is the foremost;
title: With Sela

segment_text: the ocean’s the foremost of rivers;
title: With Sela

segment_text: the foremost of stars is the moon;
title: With Sela

segment_text: the sun is the foremost of lights;
title: With Sela

segment_text: for those who sacrifice seeking merit,
title: With Sela

segment_text: the Saṅgha is the foremost.”
title: With Sela

segment_text: When the Buddha had expressed his appreciation to Keṇiya the matted-hair ascetic with these verses, he got up from his seat and left.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Then Venerable Sela and his assembly, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. They lived having achieved with their own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
title: With Sela

segment_text: And Venerable Sela together with his assembly became perfected.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Then Sela with his assembly went to see the Buddha. He arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said:
title: With Sela

segment_text: “This is the eighth day since
title: With Sela

segment_text: we went for refuge, O Clear-eyed One.
title: With Sela

segment_text: In these seven days, Blessed One,
title: With Sela

segment_text: we’ve become tamed in your teaching.
title: With Sela

segment_text: You are the Buddha, you are the Teacher,
title: With Sela

segment_text: you are the sage who has overcome Māra;
title: With Sela

segment_text: you have cut off the underlying tendencies,
title: With Sela

segment_text: you’ve crossed over, and you bring humanity across.
title: With Sela

segment_text: You have transcended attachments,
title: With Sela

segment_text: your defilements are shattered;
title: With Sela

segment_text: you are a lion, free of grasping,
title: With Sela

segment_text: with fear and dread given up.
title: With Sela

segment_text: These three hundred mendicants
title: With Sela

segment_text: stand with joined palms raised.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Stretch out your feet, great hero:
title: With Sela

segment_text: let these giants bow to the Teacher.”
title: With Sela

segment_text: Unforeseen and unknown
title: The Dart

segment_text: is the extent of this mortal life—
title: The Dart

segment_text: hard and short
title: The Dart

segment_text: and bound to pain.
title: The Dart

segment_text: There is no way that
title: The Dart

segment_text: those born will not die.
title: The Dart

segment_text: On reaching old age death follows:
title: The Dart

segment_text: such is the nature of living creatures.
title: The Dart

segment_text: As ripe fruit
title: The Dart

segment_text: are always in danger of falling,
title: The Dart

segment_text: so mortals once born
title: The Dart

segment_text: are always in danger of death.
title: The Dart

segment_text: As clay pots
title: The Dart

segment_text: made by a potter
title: The Dart

segment_text: all end up being broken,
title: The Dart

segment_text: so is the life of mortals.
title: The Dart

segment_text: Young and old,
title: The Dart

segment_text: foolish and wise—
title: The Dart

segment_text: all go under the sway of death;
title: The Dart

segment_text: all are destined to die.
title: The Dart

segment_text: When those overcome by death
title: The Dart

segment_text: leave this world for the next,
title: The Dart

segment_text: a father cannot protect his son,
title: The Dart

segment_text: nor relatives their kin.
title: The Dart

segment_text: See how, while relatives look on,
title: The Dart

segment_text: wailing profusely,
title: The Dart

segment_text: mortals are led away one by one,
title: The Dart

segment_text: like a cow to the slaughter.
title: The Dart

segment_text: And so the world is stricken
title: The Dart

segment_text: by old age and by death.
title: The Dart

segment_text: That is why the wise do not grieve,
title: The Dart

segment_text: for they understand the way of the world.
title: The Dart

segment_text: For one whose path you do not know—
title: The Dart

segment_text: not whence they came nor where they went—
title: The Dart

segment_text: you lament in vain,
title: The Dart

segment_text: seeing neither end.
title: The Dart

segment_text: If a bewildered person,
title: The Dart

segment_text: lamenting and self-harming,
title: The Dart

segment_text: could extract any good from that,
title: The Dart

segment_text: then those who see clearly would do the same.
title: The Dart

segment_text: For not by weeping and wailing
title: The Dart

segment_text: will you find peace of heart.
title: The Dart

segment_text: It just gives rise to more suffering,
title: The Dart

segment_text: and distresses your body.
title: The Dart

segment_text: Growing thin and pale,
title: The Dart

segment_text: you hurt yourself.
title: The Dart

segment_text: It does nothing to help the dead:
title: The Dart

segment_text: your lamentation is in vain.
title: The Dart

segment_text: Unless a person gives up grief,
title: The Dart

segment_text: they fall into suffering all the more.
title: The Dart

segment_text: Bewailing those whose time has come,
title: The Dart

segment_text: you fall under the sway of grief.
title: The Dart

segment_text: See, too, other folk departing
title: The Dart

segment_text: to fare after their deeds;
title: The Dart

segment_text: fallen under the sway of death,
title: The Dart

segment_text: beings flounder while still here.
title: The Dart

segment_text: For whatever you imagine it is,
title: The Dart

segment_text: it turns out to be something else.
title: The Dart

segment_text: Such is separation:
title: The Dart

segment_text: see the way of the world!
title: The Dart

segment_text: Even if a human lives
title: The Dart

segment_text: a hundred years or more,
title: The Dart

segment_text: they are parted from their family circle,
title: The Dart

segment_text: they leave this life behind.
title: The Dart

segment_text: Therefore, having learned from the Perfected One,
title: The Dart

segment_text: dispel lamentation.
title: The Dart

segment_text: Seeing the dead and departed, think:
title: The Dart

segment_text: “I cannot escape this.”
title: The Dart

segment_text: As one would extinguish
title: The Dart

segment_text: a blazing refuge with water,
title: The Dart

segment_text: so too a sage—a wise,
title: The Dart

segment_text: astute, and skilled person—
title: The Dart

segment_text: would swiftly blow away grief that comes up,
title: The Dart

segment_text: like the wind a tuft of cotton.
title: The Dart

segment_text: One who seeks their own happiness
title: The Dart

segment_text: would pluck out the dart from themselves—
title: The Dart

segment_text: the wailing and moaning,
title: The Dart

segment_text: and sadness inside.
title: The Dart

segment_text: With dart plucked out, unattached,
title: The Dart

segment_text: having found peace of mind,
title: The Dart

segment_text: overcoming all sorrow,
title: The Dart

segment_text: one is sorrowless and extinguished.
title: The Dart

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying in a forest near Icchānaṅgala.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Now at that time several very well-known well-to-do brahmins were residing in Icchānaṅgala. They included
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: the brahmins Caṅkī, Tārukkha, Pokkharasādi, Jānussoṇi, Todeyya, and others.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Then as the brahmin students Vāseṭṭha and Bhāradvāja were going for a walk they began to discuss the question:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: “How do you become a brahmin?”
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Bhāradvāja said this:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: “When you’re well born on both your mother’s and father’s side, of pure descent, with irrefutable and impeccable genealogy back to the seventh paternal generation—
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: then you’re a brahmin.”
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Vāseṭṭha said this:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: “When you’re ethical and accomplished in doing your duties—
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: then you’re a brahmin.”
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: But neither was able to persuade the other.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: So Vāseṭṭha said to Bhāradvāja,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: “Master Bhāradvāja, the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—is staying in a forest near Icchānaṅgala.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: He has this good reputation:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Come, let’s go to see him and ask him about this matter.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: As he answers, so we’ll remember it.”
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” replied Bhāradvāja.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: So they went to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: and Vāseṭṭha addressed the Buddha in verse:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: “We’re both authorized masters
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: of the three Vedas.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: I’m a student of Pokkharasādi,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: and he of Tārukkha.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: We’re fully qualified
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: in all the Vedic experts teach.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: As philologists and grammarians,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: we match our teachers in recitation.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: We have a dispute
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: regarding genealogy.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: For Bhāradvāja says that
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: one is a brahmin due to birth,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: but I declare it’s because of one’s actions.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Oh Clear-eyed One, know this as our debate.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Since neither of us was able
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: to convince the other,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: we’ve come to ask you, sir,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: renowned as the awakened one.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: As people honor with joined palms
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: the moon on the cusp of waxing,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: bowing, they revere
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Gotama in the world.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: We ask this of Gotama,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: the Eye arisen in the world:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: is one a brahmin due to birth,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: or else because of actions?
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: We don’t know, please tell us,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: so we can recognize a brahmin.”
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: “I shall explain to you,”
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: said the Buddha,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: “accurately and in sequence,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: the taxonomy of living creatures,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: for species are indeed diverse.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Know the grass and trees,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: though they lack self-awareness.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: They’re defined by birth,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: for species are indeed diverse.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Next there are bugs and moths,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: and so on, to ants and termites.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: They’re defined by birth,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: for species are indeed diverse.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Know the quadrupeds, too,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: both small and large.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: They’re defined by birth,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: for species are indeed diverse.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Know, too, the long-backed snakes,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: crawling on their bellies.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: They’re defined by birth,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: for species are indeed diverse.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Next know the fish,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: whose habitat is the water.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: They’re defined by birth,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: for species are indeed diverse.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Next know the birds,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: flying with wings as chariots.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: They’re defined by birth,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: for species are indeed diverse.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: While the differences between these species
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: are defined by birth,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: the differences between humans
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: are not defined by birth.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Not by hair nor by head,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: not by ear nor by eye,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: not by mouth nor by nose,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: not by lips nor by eyebrow,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: not by shoulder nor by neck,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: not by belly nor by back,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: not by buttocks nor by breast,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: not by groin nor by genitals,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: not by hands nor by feet,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: not by fingers nor by nails,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: not by knees nor by thighs,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: not by color nor by voice:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: none of these are defined by birth
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: as it is for other species.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: In individual human bodies
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: you can’t find such distinctions.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: The distinctions among humans
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: are spoken of by convention.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Anyone among humans
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: who lives off keeping cattle:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: know them, Vāseṭṭha,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: as a farmer, not a brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Anyone among humans
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: who lives off various professions:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: know them, Vāseṭṭha,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: as a professional, not a brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Anyone among humans
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: who lives off trade:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: know them, Vāseṭṭha,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: as a trader, not a brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Anyone among humans
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: who lives off serving others:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: know them, Vāseṭṭha,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: as an employee, not a brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Anyone among humans
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: who lives off stealing:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: know them, Vāseṭṭha,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: as a bandit, not a brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Anyone among humans
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: who lives off archery:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: know them, Vāseṭṭha,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: as a soldier, not a brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Anyone among humans
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: who lives off priesthood:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: know them, Vāseṭṭha,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: as a sacrificer, not a brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Anyone among humans
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: who taxes village and nation,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: know them, Vāseṭṭha,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: as a ruler, not a brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: I don’t call someone a brahmin
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: after the mother or womb they came from.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: If they still have attachments,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: they’re just someone who says ‘sir’.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Having nothing, taking nothing:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: that’s who I call a brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Having cut off all fetters
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: they have no anxiety;
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: they’ve slipped their chains and are detached:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: that’s who I call a brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: They’ve cut the strap and harness,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: the reins and bridle too;
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: with cross-bar lifted, they’re awakened:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: that’s who I call a brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Abuse, killing, caging:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: they endure these without anger.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Patience is their powerful army:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: that’s who I call a brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Not irritable or stuck up,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: dutiful in precepts and observances,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: tamed, bearing their final body:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: that’s who I call a brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Like water from a lotus leaf,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: like a mustard seed off a pin-point,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: sensual pleasures slip off them:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: that’s who I call a brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: They understand for themselves
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: the end of suffering in this life;
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: with burden put down, detached:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: that’s who I call a brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Deep in wisdom, intelligent,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: expert in the variety of paths;
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: arrived at the highest goal:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: that’s who I call a brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Socializing with neither
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: householders nor the homeless;
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: a migrant with no shelter, few in wishes:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: that’s who I call a brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: They’ve laid aside violence
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: against creatures firm and frail;
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: not killing or making others kill:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: that’s who I call a brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Not fighting among those who fight,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: extinguished among those who are armed,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: not taking among those who take:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: that’s who I call a brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: They’ve discarded greed and hate,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: along with conceit and contempt,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: like a mustard seed off the point of a pin:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: that’s who I call a brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: The words they utter
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: are sweet, informative, and true,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: and don’t offend anyone:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: that’s who I call a brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: They don’t steal anything in the world,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: long or short,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: fine or coarse, beautiful or ugly:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: that’s who I call a brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: They have no hope
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: for this world or the next.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: with no need for hope, detached:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: that’s who I call a brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: They have no clinging,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: knowledge has freed them of indecision,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: they’ve plunged right into the deathless:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: that’s who I call a brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: They’ve escaped clinging
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: to both good and bad deeds;
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: sorrowless, stainless, pure:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: that’s who I call a brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Pure as the spotless moon,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: clear and undisturbed,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: they’ve ended delight and future lives:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: that’s who I call a brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: They’ve got past this grueling swamp
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: of delusion, transmigration.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Meditating in stillness, free of indecision,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: they have crossed over to the far shore.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: They’re extinguished by not grasping:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: that’s who I call a brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: They’ve given up sensual stimulations,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: and have gone forth from lay life;
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: they’ve ended rebirth in the sensual realm:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: that’s who I call a brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: They’ve given up craving,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: and have gone forth from lay life;
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: they’ve ended craving to be reborn:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: that’s who I call a brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: They’ve thrown off the human yoke,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: and slipped out of the heavenly yoke;
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: unyoked from all yokes:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: that’s who I call a brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Giving up discontent and desire,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: they’re cooled and free of attachments;
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: a hero, master of the whole world:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: that’s who I call a brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: They know the passing away
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: and rebirth of all beings;
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: unattached, holy, awakened:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: that’s who I call a brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Gods, centaurs, and humans
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: don’t know their destiny;
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: the perfected ones with defilements ended:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: that’s who I call a brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: They have nothing before or after,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: or even in between.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Having nothing, taking nothing:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: that’s who I call a brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Leader of the herd, excellent hero,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: great seer and victor;
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: unstirred, washed, awakened:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: that’s who I call a brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: They know their past lives,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: and sees heaven and places of loss,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: and has attained the ending of rebirth,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: that’s who I call a brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: For name and clan are formulated
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: as mere convention in the world.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Produced by mutual agreement,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: they’re formulated for each individual.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: For a long time this misconception
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: has prejudiced those who don’t understand.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Ignorant, they declare
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: that one is a brahmin by birth.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: You’re not a brahmin by birth,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: nor by birth a non-brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: You’re a brahmin by your deeds,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: and by deeds a non-brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: You’re a farmer by your deeds,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: by deeds you’re a professional;
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: you’re a trader by your deeds,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: by deeds are you an employee;
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: you’re a bandit by your deeds,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: by deeds you’re a soldier;
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: you’re a sacrificer by your deeds,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: by deeds you’re a ruler.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: In this way the astute regard deeds
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: in accord with truth.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Seeing dependent origination,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: they’re expert in deeds and their results.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Deeds make the world go on,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: deeds make people go on;
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: sentient beings are bound by deeds,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: like a moving chariot’s linchpin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: By fervor and spiritual practice,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: by restraint and by self-control:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: that’s how to become a brahmin,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: this is the supreme brahmin.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Accomplished in the three knowledges,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: peaceful, with rebirth ended,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: know them, Vāseṭṭha,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: as Brahmā and Sakka to the wise.”
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: When he had spoken, Vāseṭṭha and Bhāradvāja said to him,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: “Excellent, Master Gotama! Excellent! …
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember us as lay followers who have gone for refuge for life.”
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: Then the mendicant Kokālika went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: “Sir, Sāriputta and Moggallāna have corrupt wishes. They’ve fallen under the sway of corrupt wishes.”
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: When this was said, the Buddha said to Kokālika,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: “Don’t say that, Kokālika! Don’t say that, Kokālika!
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: Have confidence in Sāriputta and Moggallāna,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: they’re good monks.”
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: For a second time …
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: For a third time Kokālika said to the Buddha,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: “Despite my faith and trust in the Buddha, Sāriputta and Moggallāna have corrupt wishs. They’ve fallen under the sway of corrupt wishes.”
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: For a third time, the Buddha said to Kokālika,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: “Don’t say that, Kokālika! Don’t say that, Kokālika!
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: Have confidence in Sāriputta and Moggallāna,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: they’re good monks.”
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: Then Kokālika got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: Not long after he left his body erupted with boils the size of mustard seeds.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: The boils grew to the size of mung beans, then chickpeas, then jujube seeds, then jujubes, then myrobalans, then unripe wood apples, then ripe wood apples. Finally they burst open, and pus and blood oozed out.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: Then the mendicant Kokālika died of that illness.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: He was reborn in the Pink Lotus hell because of his resentment for Sāriputta and Moggallāna.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: Then, late at night, the beautiful Brahmā Sahampati, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: “Sir, the mendicant Kokālika has passed away.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: He was reborn in the Pink Lotus hell because of his resentment for Sāriputta and Moggallāna.”
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: That’s what Brahmā Sahampati said.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: Then he bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right side, before vanishing right there.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: Then, when the night had passed, the Buddha told the mendicants all that had happened.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: When he said this, one of the mendicants said to the Buddha,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: “Sir, how long is the life span in the Pink Lotus hell?”
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: “It’s long, mendicant.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: It’s not easy to calculate how many years, how many hundreds or thousands or hundreds of thousands of years it lasts.”
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: “But sir, is it possible to give a simile?”
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: “It’s possible,” said the Buddha.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: “Suppose there was a Kosalan cartload of twenty bushels of sesame seed. And at the end of every hundred years someone would remove a single seed from it.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: By this means the Kosalan cartload of twenty bushels of sesame seed would run out faster than a single lifetime in the Abbuda hell.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: Now, twenty lifetimes in the Abbuda hell equal one lifetime in the Nirabbuda hell.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: Twenty lifetimes in the Nirabbuda hell equal one lifetime in the Ababa hell.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: Twenty lifetimes in the Ababa hell equal one lifetime in the Aṭaṭa hell.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: Twenty lifetimes in the Aṭaṭa hell equal one lifetime in the Ahaha hell.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: Twenty lifetimes in the Ahaha hell equal one lifetime in the Yellow Lotus hell.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: Twenty lifetimes in the Yellow Lotus hell equal one lifetime in the Sweet-Smelling hell.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: Twenty lifetimes in the Sweet-Smelling hell equal one lifetime in the Blue Water Lily hell.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: Twenty lifetimes in the Blue Water Lily hell equal one lifetime in the White Lotus hell.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: Twenty lifetimes in the White Lotus hell equal one lifetime in the Pink Lotus hell.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: The mendicant Kokālika has been reborn in the Pink Lotus hell because of his resentment for Sāriputta and Moggallāna.”
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: That is what the Buddha said.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: “A person is born
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: with an axe in their mouth.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: A fool cuts themselves with it
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: when they say bad words.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: When you praise someone worthy of criticism,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: or criticize someone worthy of praise,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: you choose bad luck with your own mouth:
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: you’ll never find happiness that way.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: Bad luck at dice is a trivial thing,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: if all you lose is your money
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: and all you own, even yourself.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: What’s really terrible luck
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: is to hate the holy ones.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: For more than two quinquadecillion years,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: and another five quattuordecillion years,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: a slanderer of noble ones goes to hell,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: having aimed bad words and thoughts at them.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: A liar goes to hell,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: as does one who denies what they did.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: Both are equal in the hereafter,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: those men of base deeds.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: Whoever wrongs a man who has done no wrong,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: a pure man who has not a blemish,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: the evil backfires on the fool,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: like fine dust thrown upwind.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: One addicted to the way of greed,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: abuses others with their speech,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: faithless, miserly, uncharitable,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: stingy, addicted to backbiting.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: Foul-mouthed, divisive, ignoble,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: a life-destroyer, wicked, wrongdoer,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: worst of men, cursed, base-born—
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: quiet now, for you are bound for hell.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: You stir up dust, causing harm,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: when you, evildoer, malign the good.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: Having done many bad deeds,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: you’ll go to the pit for a long time.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: For no-one’s deeds are ever lost,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: they return to their owner.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: In the next life that stupid evildoer
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: sees suffering in themselves.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: They approach the place of impalement,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: with its iron spikes, sharp blades, and iron stakes.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: Then there is the food, which appropriately,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: is like a red-hot iron ball.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: For the speakers speak not sweetly,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: they don’t hurry there, or find shelter.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: They lie upon a spread of coals,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: they enter a blazing mass of fire.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: Wrapping them in a net,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: they strike them there with iron hammers.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: They come to blinding darkness,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: which spreads about them like a fog.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: Next they enter a copper pot,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: a blazing mass of fire.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: There they roast for a long time,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: writhing in the masses of fire.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: Then the evildoer roasts there
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: in a mixture of pus and blood.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: No matter where they settle,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: everything they touch there hurts them.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: The evildoer roasts in
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: worm-infested water.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: There’s not even a shore to go to,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: for all around are the same kind of pots.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: They enter the Wood of Sword-Leaves,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: so sharp they cut their body to pieces.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: Having grabbed the tongue with a hook,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: they stab it, slashing back and forth.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: Then they approach the impassable  Vetaraṇi River,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: with its sharp blades, its razor blades.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: Idiots fall into it,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: the wicked who have done wicked deeds.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: There dogs all brown and spotted,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: and raven flocks, and greedy jackals
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: devour them as they wail,
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: while hawks and crows attack them.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: Hard, alas, is the life here
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: that evildoers endure.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: That’s why for the rest of this life
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: a person ought do their duty without fail.
title: With Kokālika

segment_text: Experts have counted the loads of sesame
title: With Kokālika

title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the Eastern Monastery, the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother.
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: Now, at that time it was the sabbath—the full moon on the fifteenth day—and the Buddha was sitting in the open surrounded by the Saṅgha of monks.
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: Then the Buddha looked around the Saṅgha of mendicants, who were so very silent. He addressed them:
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: “Suppose, mendicants, they questioned you thus: ‘There are skillful teachings that are noble, emancipating, and lead to awakening. What is the real reason for listening to such teachings?’ You should answer:
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: ‘Only so as to truly know the pairs of teachings.’
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: And what pairs do they speak of?
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: ‘This is suffering; this is the origin of suffering’: this is the first contemplation.
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: ‘This is the cessation of suffering; this is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’: this is the second contemplation.
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: When a mendicant meditates rightly contemplating a pair of teachings in this way—diligent, keen, and resolute—they can expect one of two results:
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: enlightenment in the present life, or if there’s something left over, non-return.”
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: That is what the Buddha said.
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: “There are those who don’t understand suffering
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: and suffering’s cause,
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: and where all suffering
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: ceases with nothing left over.
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: And they do not know the path
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: that leads to the stilling of suffering.
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: They lack the heart’s release,
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: as well as the release by wisdom.
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: Unable to make an end,
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: they continue to be reborn and grow old.
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: But there are those who understand suffering
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: and suffering’s cause,
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: and where all suffering
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: ceases with nothing left over.
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: And they understand the path
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: that leads to the stilling of suffering.
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: They’re endowed with the heart’s release,
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: as well as the release by wisdom.
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: Able to make an end,
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: they don’t continue to be reborn and grow old.”
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: “Suppose, mendicants, they questioned you thus: ‘Could there be another way to contemplate the pairs?’
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: You should say, ‘There could.’
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: And how could there be?
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: ‘All the suffering that originates is caused by attachment’: this is one contemplation.
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: ‘With the utter cessation of attachment there is no origination of suffering’: this is the second contemplation.
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: When a mendicant meditates in this way they can expect enlightenment or non-return.”
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: Then the Teacher went on to say:
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: “Attachment is the source of suffering
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: in all its countless forms in the world.
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: When an ignorant person builds up attachments,
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: that idiot returns to suffering again and again.
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: So let one who understands <j>not build up attachments,
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: contemplating the origin of suffering and rebirth.”
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: Then the Teacher went on to say:
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs

segment_text: “For the independent there’s no agitation.
title: 3.12 Contemplating Pairs
