segment_text: I know the passing away and rebirth of beings,
title: Anuruddha

segment_text: their coming and going,
title: Anuruddha

segment_text: their lives in this state and that.
title: Anuruddha

segment_text: I’ve served the teacher
title: Anuruddha

segment_text: and fulfilled the Buddha’s instructions.
title: Anuruddha

segment_text: The heavy burden is laid down,
title: Anuruddha

segment_text: the conduit to rebirth is eradicated.
title: Anuruddha

segment_text: In the Vajjian village of Veḷuva,
title: Anuruddha

segment_text: my life will come to an end.
title: Anuruddha

segment_text: Beneath a thicket of bamboos,
title: Anuruddha

segment_text: being undefiled, I will be fully extinguished.”
title: Anuruddha

segment_text: This thought came to the ascetic
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: in the forest full of flowers,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: as he was seated alone
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: meditating in seclusion:
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: “The behavior of the mendicants
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: these days seems different
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: from when the protector of the world,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: the best of men, was still here.
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: Their robes were only for covering the private parts,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: and protection from the cold and wind.
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: They ate in moderation,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: content with whatever they were offered.
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: Whether food was refined or rough,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: a little or a lot,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: they ate only for sustenance,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: without greed or gluttony.
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: They weren’t so very eager
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: for the requisites of life,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: such as tonics and other necessities,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: as they were for the ending of defilements.
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: In the wilderness, at a tree’s root,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: in caves and caverns,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: fostering seclusion,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: they lived with that as their final goal.
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: They were used to simple things, unburdensome,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: gentle, not pompous at heart,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: unsullied, not scurrilous,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: their thoughts were intent on the goal.
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: That’s why they inspired confidence,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: in their movements, eating, and practice;
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: their deportment was as smooth
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: as a stream of oil.
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: With the utter ending of all defilements,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: those senior monks have now been quenched.
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: They were great meditators and great benefactors—
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: there are few like them today.
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: With the ending
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: of good principles and understanding,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: the victor’s teaching,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: full of all excellent qualities, has fallen apart.
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: This is the season
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: for bad principles and defilements.
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: Those who are ready for seclusion
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: are all that’s left of the true Dhamma.
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: As they grow, the defilements
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: possess most people;
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: they play with fools, it seems to me,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: like monsters with the mad.
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: Overcome by defilements,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: they run here and there
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: among the bases for defilement,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: as if they had declared war on themselves.
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: Having abandoned the true teaching,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: they argue with each other.
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: Following wrong views
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: they think, ‘This is better.’
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: They cut off their wealth,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: children, and wife to go forth.
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: But then they do what they shouldn’t,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: for the sake of a measly spoon of almsfood.
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: They eat until their bellies are full,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: and then they lie to sleep on their backs.
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: When they wake up, they keep on chatting,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: the kind of talk that the teacher criticized.
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: Valuing all the arts and crafts,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: they train themselves in them.
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: Not being settled inside, they think,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: ‘This is the goal of the ascetic life.’
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: They provide clay, oil, and talcum powder,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: water, lodgings, and food
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: for householders,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: expecting more in return.
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: And in addition, tooth-picks, portia flowers,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: flowers, food to eat,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: well-cooked almsfood,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: mangoes and myrobalans.
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: In medicine they are like doctors,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: in business like householders,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: in makeup like prostitutes,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: in sovereignty like lords.
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: Cheats, frauds,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: false witnesses, sly:
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: using multiple plans,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: they enjoy things of the flesh.
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: Pursuing shams, contrivances, and plans,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: by such means
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: they accumulate a lot of wealth
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: for the sake of their own livelihood.
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: They assemble the community
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: for business rather than Dhamma.
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: They teach the Dhamma to others
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: for gain, not for the goal.
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: Those outside the Saṅgha
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: quarrel over the Saṅgha’s property.
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: They’re shameless, and do not care
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: that they live on someone else’s property.
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: Some with shaven head and robe
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: are not devoted to practice,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: but wish only to be honored,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: besotted with property and reverence.
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: When things have come to this,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: it’s not easy these days
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: to realize what has not yet been realized,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: or to preserve what has been realized.
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: When shoeless on a thorny path,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: one would walk
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: very mindfully;
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: that’s how a sage should walk in the village.
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: Remembering the meditators of old,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: and recollecting their conduct,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: even in the latter days,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: it’s still possible to realize the deathless.”
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: That is what the ascetic, whose faculties
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: were fully developed, said in the sāl tree grove.
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: The brahmin, the seer, became quenched,
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: putting an end to all future lives.
title: Pārāpariya (3rd)

segment_text: Seeing many who inspire confidence,
title: Phussa

segment_text: evolved and well-restrained,
title: Phussa

segment_text: the seer of the Paṇḍara clan,
title: Phussa

segment_text: asked the one known as Phussa:
title: Phussa

segment_text: “In future times,
title: Phussa

segment_text: what desire and motivation
title: Phussa

segment_text: and behavior will people have?
title: Phussa

segment_text: Please answer my question.”
title: Phussa

segment_text: “Listen to my words,
title: Phussa

segment_text: Paṇḍarasa the seer,
title: Phussa

segment_text: and remember them carefully,
title: Phussa

segment_text: I will describe the future.
title: Phussa

segment_text: In the future many will be
title: Phussa

segment_text: angry and hostile,
title: Phussa

segment_text: offensive, stubborn, and devious,
title: Phussa

segment_text: jealous, holding divergent views.
title: Phussa

segment_text: Imagining they understand <j>the depths of the teaching,
title: Phussa

segment_text: they remain on the near shore.
title: Phussa

segment_text: Superficial and disrespectful towards the teaching,
title: Phussa

segment_text: they lack respect for one another.
title: Phussa

segment_text: In the future
title: Phussa

segment_text: many dangers will arise in the world.
title: Phussa

segment_text: Idiots will defile
title: Phussa

segment_text: the Dhamma that was taught so well.
title: Phussa

segment_text: Though bereft of good qualities,
title: Phussa

segment_text: unlearned prattlers, too sure of themselves,
title: Phussa

segment_text: will become powerful
title: Phussa

segment_text: in running Saṅgha proceedings.
title: Phussa

segment_text: Though possessing good qualities,
title: Phussa

segment_text: the conscientious and unbiased, <j>acting in the proper spirit,
title: Phussa

segment_text: will become weak
title: Phussa

segment_text: in running Saṅgha proceedings.
title: Phussa

segment_text: In the future, fools will accept
title: Phussa

segment_text: money, gold, and silver,
title: Phussa

segment_text: fields and land, goats and sheep,
title: Phussa

segment_text: and bonded servants, male and female.
title: Phussa

segment_text: Fools looking for fault in others,
title: Phussa

segment_text: but unsteady in their own ethics,
title: Phussa

segment_text: will wander about, insolent,
title: Phussa

segment_text: like cantankerous beasts.
title: Phussa

segment_text: They’ll be arrogant,
title: Phussa

segment_text: wrapped in robes of blue;
title: Phussa

segment_text: deceivers and flatterers, pompous and fake,
title: Phussa

segment_text: they’ll wander as if they were noble ones.
title: Phussa

segment_text: With hair sleeked back with oil,
title: Phussa

segment_text: fickle, their eyes painted with eye-liner,
title: Phussa

segment_text: they’ll travel on the high-road,
title: Phussa

segment_text: wrapped in robes of ivory color.
title: Phussa

segment_text: The deep-dyed ocher robe,
title: Phussa

segment_text: worn without disgust by the free,
title: Phussa

segment_text: they will come to loathe,
title: Phussa

segment_text: besotted by white clothes.
title: Phussa

segment_text: They’ll want lots of possessions,
title: Phussa

segment_text: and be lazy, lacking energy.
title: Phussa

segment_text: Weary of the forest,
title: Phussa

segment_text: they’ll stay within villages.
title: Phussa

segment_text: Being unrestrained, they’ll keep company with
title: Phussa

segment_text: those who get lots of stuff,
title: Phussa

segment_text: and who always enjoy wrong livelihood,
title: Phussa

segment_text: following their example.
title: Phussa

segment_text: They won’t respect those
title: Phussa

segment_text: who don’t get lots of stuff,
title: Phussa

segment_text: and they won’t associate with the wise,
title: Phussa

segment_text: even though they’re very amiable.
title: Phussa

segment_text: Disparaging their own banner,
title: Phussa

segment_text: which is dyed the color of copper,
title: Phussa

segment_text: some will wear the white banner
title: Phussa

segment_text: of those of other religions.
title: Phussa

segment_text: Then they’ll have no respect
title: Phussa

segment_text: for the ocher robe.
title: Phussa

segment_text: The mendicants will not reflect
title: Phussa

segment_text: on the nature of the ocher robe.
title: Phussa

segment_text: This awful lack of reflection
title: Phussa

segment_text: was unthinkable to the elephant,
title: Phussa

segment_text: who was overcome by suffering,
title: Phussa

segment_text: injured by an arrow strike.
title: Phussa

segment_text: Then the six-tusked elephant,
title: Phussa

segment_text: seeing the deep-dyed banner of the perfected ones,
title: Phussa

segment_text: straight away spoke these verses
title: Phussa

segment_text: connected with the goal.
title: Phussa

segment_text: One who, not free of stains themselves,
title: Phussa

segment_text: would wear the robe stained in ocher,
title: Phussa

segment_text: bereft of self-control and truth:
title: Phussa

segment_text: they are not worthy of the ocher robe.
title: Phussa

segment_text: One who’s purged all their stains,
title: Phussa

segment_text: steady in ethics,
title: Phussa

segment_text: possessing truth and self-control:
title: Phussa

segment_text: they are truly worthy of the ocher robe.
title: Phussa

segment_text: Devoid of virtue, unintelligent,
title: Phussa

segment_text: wild, doing what they like,
title: Phussa

segment_text: their minds astray, indolent:
title: Phussa

segment_text: they are not worthy of the ocher robe.
title: Phussa

segment_text: One accomplished in ethics,
title: Phussa

segment_text: free of greed, serene,
title: Phussa

segment_text: their heart’s intention pure:
title: Phussa

segment_text: they are truly worthy of the ocher robe.
title: Phussa

segment_text: The conceited, arrogant fool,
title: Phussa

segment_text: who has no ethics at all,
title: Phussa

segment_text: is worthy of a white robe—
title: Phussa

segment_text: what use is an ocher robe for them?
title: Phussa

segment_text: In the future, monks and nuns
title: Phussa

segment_text: with corrupt hearts, lacking regard for others,
title: Phussa

segment_text: will disparage those
title: Phussa

segment_text: with hearts of loving-kindness.
title: Phussa

segment_text: Though trained in wearing the robe
title: Phussa

segment_text: by senior monks,
title: Phussa

segment_text: the unintelligent will not listen,
title: Phussa

segment_text: wild, doing what they like.
title: Phussa

segment_text: With that kind of attitude to training,
title: Phussa

segment_text: those fools won’t respect each other,
title: Phussa

segment_text: or take any notice of their mentors,
title: Phussa

segment_text: like a wild colt with its charioteer.
title: Phussa

segment_text: Even so, in the future,
title: Phussa

segment_text: this will be the practice
title: Phussa

segment_text: of monks and nuns
title: Phussa

segment_text: when the latter days have come.
title: Phussa

segment_text: Before this frightening future arrives,
title: Phussa

segment_text: be easy to admonish,
title: Phussa

segment_text: courteous in speech,
title: Phussa

segment_text: and respect one another.
title: Phussa

segment_text: Have hearts of love and compassion,
title: Phussa

segment_text: and please do keep your precepts.
title: Phussa

segment_text: Be energetic, resolute,
title: Phussa

segment_text: and always staunchly vigorous.
title: Phussa

segment_text: Seeing negligence as fearful,
title: Phussa

segment_text: and diligence as a sanctuary,
title: Phussa

segment_text: develop the eightfold path,
title: Phussa

segment_text: realizing the deathless state.”
title: Phussa

segment_text: “One who’s mindful <j>as per their conduct and mindfulness,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: diligent <j>as per their intentions and meditation,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: happy inside, serene, solitary, contented:
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: that is what they call a mendicant.
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: When eating fresh or dried food,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: one shouldn’t be overly replete.
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: A mendicant should wander mindfully,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: with empty stomach, taking limited food.
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: Four or five mouthfuls before you’re full,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: drink some water;
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: this is enough for a resolute mendicant
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: to live in comfort.
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: If they cover themselves with a robe
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: that’s allowable and fit for purpose;
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: this is enough for a resolute mendicant
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: to live in comfort.
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: When sitting cross-legged,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: the rain doesn’t fall on the knees;
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: this is enough for a resolute mendicant
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: to live in comfort.”
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: “When you’ve seen happiness as suffering,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: and suffering as a dart,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: and that there’s nothing between the two—
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: what keeps you in the world? <j>What would you become?
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: Thinking, ‘May I have nothing to do <j>with those of bad wishes,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: lazy, lacking energy,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: unlearned, lacking regard for others’—
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: what keeps you in the world? <j>What would you become?”
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: “An intelligent, learned person,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: steady in ethics,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: devoted to serenity of heart—
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: let them stand at the head.”
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: “A beast who likes to proliferate,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: enjoying proliferation,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: fails to win extinguishment,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: But one who gives up proliferation,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: enjoying the state of non-proliferation,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: wins extinguishment,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.”
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: “Whether in the village or the wilderness,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: in a valley or the uplands,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: wherever the perfected ones live
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: is a delightful place.”
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: “The wilderness is so lovely!
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: Though most people don’t like it,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: those free of greed are happy there,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: as they don’t seek sensual pleasures.”
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: “Regard one who sees your faults
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: as a guide to a hidden treasure.
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: Stay close to one so wise and astute
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: who corrects you when you need it.
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: Sticking close to such an impartial person,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: things get better, not worse.”
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: “Advise and instruct;
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: curb wickedness:
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: for you shall be loved by the good,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: and disliked by the bad.”
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: “The Blessed One, the Buddha, the seer
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: was teaching Dhamma to another.
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: As he taught the Dhamma,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: I lent an ear to get the meaning.
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: My listening wasn’t wasted:
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: I’m freed, without defilements.”
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: “Not for knowledge of past lives,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: nor even for clairvoyance;
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: not for psychic powers, <j>or reading the minds of others,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: nor for knowing people’s <j>passing away and being reborn;
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: not for purifying the power of clairaudience,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: did I have any wish.”
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: “His only shelter is the foot of a tree;
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: shaven, wrapped in his outer robe,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: the senior monk foremost in wisdom,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: Upatissa himself practices absorption.
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: When in a meditation  free of placing the mind,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: a disciple of the Buddha
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: is at that moment blessed
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: with noble silence.
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: As a rocky mountain
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: is unwavering and well grounded,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: so when delusion ends,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: a monk, like a mountain, doesn’t tremble.
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: “To the man who has not a blemish,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: who is always seeking purity,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: even a hair-tip of evil
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: seems as big as a cloud.”
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: “I don’t long for death;
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: I don’t long for life;
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: I will lay down this body,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: aware and mindful.
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: I don’t long for death;
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: I don’t long for life;
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: I await my time,
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: like a worker waiting for their wages.”
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: “Both what came before and what follows after

title: Sāriputta

title: Sāriputta

segment_text: “Whether they’re honored

title: Sāriputta

segment_text: “The oceans and the earth,
title: Sāriputta

title: Sāriputta

segment_text: “The senior monk who keeps the wheel rolling,
title: Sāriputta

title: Sāriputta

title: Sāriputta

segment_text: he is neither attracted nor repelled.

title: Sāriputta

segment_text: so intelligent and thoughtful.
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: He is bright, but seems to be dull;
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: he always wanders, quenched.”
title: Sāriputta

segment_text: “I’ve served the teacher
title: Sāriputta

title: Sāriputta

title: Sāriputta

title: Mahākassapa

segment_text: He inclines to renunciation,
title: Mahākassapa

segment_text: and has escaped the three states of existence.
title: Mahākassapa

segment_text: The great sage’s neck is mindfulness meditation;
title: Mahākassapa

segment_text: faith is his hands, and wisdom his head.
title: Mahākassapa

segment_text: Having great knowledge,
title: Mahākassapa

segment_text: he always wanders, quenched.”
title: Mahākassapa

segment_text: The Book of the Forties is finished.
title: Mahākassapa

segment_text: Oh, when will I stay in a mountain cave,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: alone, with no companion,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: discerning all states of existence as impermanent?
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: This hope of mine, <j>when will it be?
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Oh, when will I stay happily in the forest,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: a sage wearing a torn robe, dressed in ocher,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: unselfish, with no need for hope,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: with greed, hate, and delusion destroyed?
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Oh, when will I stay alone in the wood,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: fearless, discerning this body as impermanent,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: a nest of death and disease,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: oppressed by death and old age; <j>when will it be?
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Oh, when will I live, <j>having grasped the sharp sword of wisdom
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: and cut the creeper of craving <j>that tangles around everything,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: the mother of fear, the bringer of suffering?
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: When will it be?
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Oh, when will I, seated on the lion’s throne,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: swiftly grasp the sword of the sages,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: forged by wisdom, of fiery might,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: and swiftly break Māra and his army? <j>When will it be?
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Oh, when will I be seen striving in the assemblies
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: with those who are virtuous, poised, <j>respecting the Dhamma,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: seeing things as they are, with faculties subdued?
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: When will it be?
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Oh, when will I focus on my own goal <j>at the Mountainfold,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: free of oppression by laziness, hunger, thirst,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: wind, heat, insects, and reptiles?
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: When will it be?
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Oh, when will I, serene and mindful,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: understand the four truths,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: that were realized by the great seer,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: and are so very hard to see? <j>When will it be?
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Oh, when will I, devoted to serenity,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: see with understanding the infinite sights,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and thoughts
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: as burning? <j>When will it be?
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Oh, when will I not be distraught
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: because of criticism,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: nor elated because of praise?
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: When will it be?
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Oh when will I discern the aggregates
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: and the infinite varieties of phenomena,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: both internal and external, as no more than
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: wood, grass, and creepers? <j>When will it be?
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Oh, when will the rain clouds in season
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: freshly wet me in my robe in the forest,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: walking the path trodden by the sages?
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: When will it be?
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Oh, when will I rise up, <j>intent on attaining the deathless,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: hearing, in the mountain cave,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: the cry of the crested peacock in the forest?
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: When will it be?
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Oh, when will I cross the Ganges, Yamunā,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: and Sarasvatī rivers, the Pātāla country,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: and the dangerous Baḷavāmukha sea,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: by psychic power unimpeded? <j>When will it be?
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Oh, when will I be devoted to absorption,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: rejecting entirely the signs of beauty,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: splitting apart desire for sensual stimulation,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: like an elephant that wanders free of ties? <j>When will it be?
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Oh, when will I realize the teaching of the great seer
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: and be content, like a poor person harassed in debt,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: harassed by creditors, who finds a hidden treasure?
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: When will it be?
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: For many years you begged me,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: “Enough of living in a house for you!”
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Why do you not urge me on, mind,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: now that I’ve gone forth as an ascetic?
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Didn’t you entice me, mind:
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: “On the Mountainfold, the birds with colorful wings,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: greeting the thunder, Mahinda’s voice,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: will delight you as you meditate in the forest?”
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: In my family circle, friends, loved ones, and relatives;
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: and in the world, sports and play, <j>and sensual pleasures;
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: all these I gave up when I entered this life:
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: and even then you’re not content with me, mind!
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: This is mine alone, it doesn’t belong to others;
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: when it is time to don your armor, why lament?
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Observing that all this is unstable,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: I went forth, seeking the deathless state.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: The methodical teacher, supreme among people,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: great physician, <j>guide for those who wish to train, said:
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: “The mind fidgets like a monkey,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: so it’s very hard to control if you are not free of lust.”
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Sensual pleasures are diverse, sweet, delightful;
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: an ignorant ordinary person is bound to them.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Seeking to be reborn again, they wish for suffering;
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: led on by their mind, they’re relegated to hell.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: “Staying in the grove resounding with cries
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: of peacocks and herons, <j>and adorned by leopards and tigers,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: abandon concern for the body, without fail!”
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: So you used to urge me, mind.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: “Develop the absorptions and spiritual faculties,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: the powers, awakening factors, and immersion;
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: realize the three knowledges <j>in the teaching of the Buddha!”
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: So you used to urge me, mind.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: “Develop the eightfold path to realize the deathless
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: emancipating, plunging into the end of all suffering,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: and cleansing all defilements!”
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: So you used to urge me, mind.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: “Reflect rationally on the aggregates as suffering,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: and abandon that from which suffering arises;
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: make an end of suffering in this very life!”
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: So you used to urge me, mind.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: “Rationally discern that impermanence is suffering,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: that emptiness is non-self, and that misery is death.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Uproot the wandering mind!”
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: So you used to urge me, mind.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: “Bald, unsightly, accursed,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: seek alms amongst families, bowl in hand.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Devote yourself to the word of the teacher, the great seer!”
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: So you used to urge me, mind.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: “Wander the streets well-restrained,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: unattached to families and sensual pleasures,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: like the full moon on a bright night!”
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: So you used to urge me, mind.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: “Be a wilderness-dweller and an alms-eater,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: one who lives in charnel grounds, a rag-robe wearer,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: one who never lies down, <j>always delighting in ascetic practices.”
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: So you used to urge me, mind.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Mind, when you urge me to the impermanent and unstable,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: you’re acting like someone who plants trees,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: then, when they’re about to fruit,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: wishes to cut down the very same trees.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Incorporeal mind, far-traveler, lone-wanderer:
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: I won’t do your bidding any more.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Sensual pleasures are suffering, painful, <j>and very dangerous;
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: I’ll wander with my mind focused only on quenching.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: I didn’t go forth due to bad luck or shamelessness,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: or due to a whim or banishment,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: nor for the sake of a livelihood;
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: it was because I agreed <j>to the promise you made, mind.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: “Having few wishes, abandoning disparagement,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: the stilling of suffering: <j>these are praised by good people.”
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: So you used to urge me, mind,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: but now you keep on with your old habits!
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Craving, ignorance, the loved and unloved,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: pretty sights, pleasant feelings,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: and the delightful kinds of sensual stimulation:
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: I’ve vomited them all, and I won’t swallow them back.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: I’ve done your bidding everywhere, mind!
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: For many births, I’ve done nothing to upset you.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Yet the creation in myself is because of your ingratitude—
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: for a long time I’ve transmigrated <j>in the suffering you’ve made.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Only you, mind, make a brahmin;
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: you make an aristocrat or a royal seer.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Sometimes we become peasants or menials;
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: and life as a god is also on account of you.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: You alone make us demons;
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: because of you we’re born in hell.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Then sometimes we become animals,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: and life as a ghost is also on account of you.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Come what may, you won’t betray me again,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: dazzling me with your ever-changing display!
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: You play with me like I’m mad—
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: but how have I ever failed you, mind?
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: In the past my mind wandered
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: how it wished, where it liked, as it pleased.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Now I’ll carefully guide it,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: as a trainer with a hook guides a rutting elephant.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: The teacher willed that this world appear to me
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: as impermanent, unstable, insubstantial.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Mind, let me leap into the victor’s teaching,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: carry me over the great flood, so hard to pass.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Things have changed, mind!
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Nothing could make me return to your control!
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: I’ve gone forth in the teaching of the great seer,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: those like me don’t come to ruin.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Mountains, oceans, rivers, the earth;
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: the four quarters, the intermediate directions, <j>below and in the sky;
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: the three realms of existence <j>are all impermanent and troubled—
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: where can you go to find happiness, mind?
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Mind, what will you do to someone <j>who has made the ultimate commitment?
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Nothing could make me a follower <j>under your control, mind;
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: there’s no way I’d touch a bellows <j>with a mouth open at each end;
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: curse this mortal frame flowing with nine streams!
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: You’ve ascended the mountain peak, <j>full of nature’s beauty,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: frequented by boars and antelopes,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: a grove sprinkled with fresh water in the rains;
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: and there you’ll be happy in your cave-home.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Peacocks with beautiful necks and crests,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: colorful tail-feathers and wings,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: crying out at the resounding thunder:
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: they’ll delight you as you meditate in the forest.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: When the sky has rained down, <j>and the grass is four inches high,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: and the grove is full of flowers like a cloud,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: in the mountain cleft, like the fork of a tree, I’ll lie;
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: it will be as soft as cotton-buds.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: I’ll act as a master does:
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: let whatever I get be enough for me.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: And that’s why I’ll make you as supple
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: as a tireless worker makes a cat-skin bag.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: I’ll act as a master does:
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: let whatever I get be enough for me.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: I’ll control you with my energy,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: as a skilled trainer controls an elephant with a hook.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Now that you’re well-tamed and reliable,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: I can use you, <j>like a trainer uses a straight-running horse,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: to practice the path so full of grace,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: cultivated by those who take care of their minds.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: I shall strongly fasten you to a meditation subject,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: as an elephant is tied to a post with firm rope.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: You’ll be well-guarded by me, <j>well-developed by mindfulness,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: and unattached to rebirth in all states of existence.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: You’ll use understanding <j>to cut the follower of the wrong path,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: curb them by practice, <j>and settle them on the right path.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: And when you have seen the cause of suffering <j>arise and pass away,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: you’ll be an heir to the greatest teacher.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Under the sway of the four distortions, mind,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: you dragged me around like a bull in a pit;
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: but now you won’t associate <j>with the great sage of compassion,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: the cutter of fetters and bonds?
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: Like a deer roaming free in the colorful forest,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: I’ll ascend the lovely mountain wreathed in cloud,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: and rejoice to be on that hill, free of folk—
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: there is no doubt you’ll perish, mind.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: The men and women who live <j>under your will and command,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: whatever pleasure they experience,
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: they are ignorant and fall under Māra’s control;
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: loving life, they’re your disciples, mind.
title: Tālapuṭa

segment_text: “Living in the wilderness, eating only almsfood,
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: happy with the scraps in our bowls,
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: let us tear apart the army of death,
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: while remaining serene within.
title: Mahāmoggallāna

title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: happy with the scraps in our bowls,
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: let us crush the army of death,
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: as an elephant a hut of reeds.
title: Mahāmoggallāna

title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: happy with the scraps in our bowls,
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: let us tear apart the army of death,
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: while remaining serene within.
title: Mahāmoggallāna

title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: happy with the scraps in our bowls,
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: let us crush the army of death,
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: as an elephant a hut of reeds.”
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: “You little hut, made of a chain of bones,
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: sewn together with flesh and sinew;
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: damn you mortal frame, you stink,
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: you cherish the parts of others!
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: You sack of dung encased in skin!
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: You demoness with horns on your chest!
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: O body, you have nine streams
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: that are flowing all the time.
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: With its nine streams,
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: your body stinks, full of dung.
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: A monk seeking purity
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: would avoid it like excrement.
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: If they knew you
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: like I do,
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: they’d keep far away,
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: like a cesspit in the rain.”
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: “So it is, great hero!
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: As you say, ascetic!
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: But some flounder here
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: like an old bull stuck in a bog.”
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: “Whoever might think
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: of making the sky yellow,
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: or some other color,
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: would only trouble themselves.
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: This mind is like the sky:
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: serene inside itself.
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: Evil-minded one, don’t attack me,
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: you’ll end up like a moth in a bonfire.”
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: “See this fancy puppet,
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: a body built of sores,
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: diseased, obsessed over,
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: in which nothing lasts at all.
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: See this fancy figure,
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: with its gems and earrings;
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: it is bones encased in skin,
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: made pretty by its clothes.
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: Rouged feet
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: and powdered face
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: may be enough to beguile a fool,
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: but not a seeker of the far shore.
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: Hair in eight braids
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: and eyeshadow
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: may be enough to beguile a fool,
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: but not a seeker of the far shore.
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: A rotting body all adorned
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: like a freshly painted makeup box
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: may be enough to beguile a fool,
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: but not a seeker of the far shore.
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: The hunter laid his snare,
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: but the deer didn’t spring the trap.
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: I’ve eaten the bait and now I go,
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: leaving the trapper to lament.
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: The hunter’s trap is broken,
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: but the deer didn’t spring the trap.
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: I’ve eaten the bait and now I go,
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: leaving the deer-hunter to grieve.”
title: Mahāmoggallāna

segment_text: “Then there was terror!
title: Mahāmoggallāna

title: Vaḍḍha’s Mother

segment_text: “Pointing out how the world works,
title: Kisāgotamī

segment_text: the sages have praised good friendship.
title: Kisāgotamī

title: Kisāgotamī

segment_text: even a fool becomes astute.
title: Kisāgotamī

segment_text: Associate with good people,
title: Kisāgotamī

segment_text: for that is how wisdom grows.
title: Kisāgotamī

segment_text: Should you associate with good people,
title: Kisāgotamī

segment_text: you would be freed from all suffering.
title: Kisāgotamī

segment_text: And you would understand suffering,
title: Kisāgotamī

segment_text: its origin and cessation,
title: Kisāgotamī

segment_text: the eightfold path,
title: Kisāgotamī

segment_text: and so the four noble truths.”
title: Kisāgotamī

segment_text: “‘A woman’s life is painful,’
title: Kisāgotamī

segment_text: explained the Buddha, <j>guide for those who wish to train,
title: Kisāgotamī

segment_text: ‘and for a co-wife it’s especially so.
title: Kisāgotamī

segment_text: After giving birth just once,
title: Kisāgotamī

segment_text: some women even cut their own throat,
title: Kisāgotamī

segment_text: while refined ladies take poison.
title: Kisāgotamī

segment_text: Being guilty of killing a person,
title: Kisāgotamī

segment_text: they both undergo ruin.’”
title: Kisāgotamī

segment_text: “I was on the road and about to give birth.,
title: Kisāgotamī

segment_text: when I saw my husband dead.
title: Kisāgotamī

segment_text: I gave birth there on the road
title: Kisāgotamī

segment_text: before I’d reached my own house.
title: Kisāgotamī

segment_text: My two children have died,
title: Kisāgotamī

segment_text: and on the road my husband lies dead—<j>oh woe is me!
title: Kisāgotamī

segment_text: Mother, father, and brother
title: Kisāgotamī

segment_text: all burning up on the same pyre.”
title: Kisāgotamī

segment_text: “Oh woe is you whose family is lost,
title: Kisāgotamī

segment_text: your suffering has no measure;
title: Kisāgotamī

segment_text: you have been shedding tears
title: Kisāgotamī

segment_text: for many thousands of lives.”

segment_text: “While staying in the charnel ground,
title: Kisāgotamī

segment_text: I saw my son’s flesh being eaten.

title: Kisāgotamī

segment_text: and my husband dead, I realized the deathless.
title: Kisāgotamī

title: Kisāgotamī

segment_text: leading to the deathless.

title: Kisāgotamī

segment_text: as seen in the mirror of the Dhamma.

title: Kisāgotamī

segment_text: “The two of us were co-wives,

segment_text: though we were mother and daughter.
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: I was struck with a sense of urgency,
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: so astonishing and hair-raising!
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: Curse those filthy sensual pleasures,
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: so nasty and thorny,
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: where we, both mother and daughter,
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: had to be co-wives together.
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: Seeing the danger in sensual pleasures,
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: seeing renunciation as sanctuary,
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: I went forth in Rājagaha
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: from the lay life to homelessness.
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: I know my past lives;
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: my clairvoyance is clarified;
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: I comprehend the minds of others;
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: my clairaudience is purified;
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: I've realized the psychic powers,
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: and attained the ending of defilements.
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: I’ve realized the six kinds of direct knowledge,
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: and fulfilled the Buddha’s instructions.
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: I created a four-horsed chariot
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: using my psychic powers.
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: Then I bowed at the feet of the Buddha,
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: the glorious protector of the world.”
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: “You’ve come to this sal tree all crowned with flowers,
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: and stand at its root all alone.
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: But you have no companion with you,
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: silly girl, aren’t you afraid of rascals?”
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: “Even if 100,000 rascals like this
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: were to gang up,
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: I’d stir not a hair nor tremble.
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: I’ll vanish,
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: or I’ll enter your belly;
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: and you still wouldn’t see me.
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: I’m the master of my own mind,
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: I’ve developed the bases of psychic power well.
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: I’ve realized the six kinds of direct knowledge,
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: and fulfilled the Buddha’s instructions.
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: Sensual pleasures are like swords and stakes;
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: What you call sensual delight
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: Relishing is destroyed in every respect,
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: and the mass of darkness is shattered.
title: Uppalavaṇṇā

segment_text: “I used to be a water-carrier. Even when it was cold,
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: I would always plunge into the water,
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: afraid of my mistresses’ beatings,
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: harassed by fear of abuse and anger.
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: Brahmin, what are you afraid of,
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: that you always plunge into the water,
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: your limbs trembling
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: in the freezing cold?”
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: “Oh, but you already know,
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: Madam Puṇṇikā, when you ask me:
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: I am doing good deeds,
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: to ward off the wickedness I have done.
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: Whosoever young or old
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: performs a wicked deed,
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: by ablution in water they are
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: released from their wicked deed.”
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: “Who on earth told you this,
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: one ignoramus to another:
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: ‘Actually, by ablution in water one is
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: released from a wicked deed.’
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: Would not they all go to heaven, then:
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: all the frogs and the turtles,
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: gharials, crocodiles,
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: and other water-dwellers too?
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: Butchers of sheep and pigs,
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: fishermen, animal trappers,
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: bandits, executioners,
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: and others of evil deeds:
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: by ablution in water they too would be
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: released from their wicked deeds.
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: If these rivers washed away
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: the bad deeds of the past,
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: then they’d also wash off goodness,
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: and thereby you would be excluded.
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: Brahmin, the thing that you are afraid of,
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: when you always plunge into the water,
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: do not do that very thing,
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: don’t let the cold harm your skin.”
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: “I have been on the wrong path,
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: and you’ve guided me to the noble path.
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: Madam, I give to you
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: this ablution cloth.”
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: “Keep the cloth for yourself,
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: I do not want it.
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: If you fear suffering,
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: if you don’t like suffering,
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: then don’t do bad deeds
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: either openly or in secret.
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: If you should do a bad deed,
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: or you’re doing one now,
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: you won’t be freed from suffering,
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: though you fly away and flee.
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: If you fear suffering,
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: if you don’t like suffering,
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: go for refuge to the Buddha, the poised,
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: to his teaching and to the Sangha.
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: Undertake the precepts,
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: that will be good for you.”
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: “I go for refuge to the Buddha, the poised,
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: to his teaching and to the Sangha.
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: I undertake the precepts,
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: that will be good for me.
title: Puṇṇikā

segment_text: of Jīvaka, the nun Subhā
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: was held up by a rascal.
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: Subhā said this to him:
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: “What harm have I done to you,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: that you stand in my way?
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: Sir, it’s not proper that a man
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: should touch a woman gone forth.
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: This training was taught by the Holy One,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: it is a serious matter in my teacher’s instructions.
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: I am pure and rid of blemishes,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: so why do you stand in my way?
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: One whose mind is sullied against one unsullied;
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: one who is lustful against one free of lust;
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: unblemished, my heart is freed in every respect,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: so why do you stand in my way?”
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: “You’re young and flawless—
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: what will going-forth do for you?
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: Throw away the ocher robe,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: come and play in the blossom grove.
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: Everywhere, the scent of pollen wafts sweet,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: born of the flowering woods.
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: The start of spring is a happy time—
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: come and play in the blossom grove.
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: And trees crested with flowers
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: cry out, as it were, in the breeze.
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: But what kind of fun will you have
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: if you plunge into the woods all alone?
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: Frequented by packs of predators,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: and she-elephants aroused by rutting bulls;
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: you wish to go without a friend
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: to the deserted, awe-inspiring forest.
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: Like a shining doll of gold,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: like a nymph wandering in a park of colorful vines,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: your matchless beauty will shine
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: in graceful clothes of exquisite muslin.
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: I’ll be under your sway,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: if we are to stay in the forest.
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: I love no creature more than you,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: O pixie with such bashful eyes.
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: Were you to take up my invitation—
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: ‘Come, be happy, and live in a house’—
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: you’ll stay in a longhouse sheltered from wind;
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: let the ladies look to your needs.
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: Dressed in exquisite muslin,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: put on your garlands and your cosmetics.
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: I’ll make all sorts of adornments for you,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: of gold and gems and pearls.
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: Climb onto a costly bed,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: its coverlet so clean and nice,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: with a new woolen mattress,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: so fragrant, sprinkled with sandalwood.
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: As a blue lily risen from the water
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: remains untouched by men,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: so too, O chaste and holy lady,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: your limbs grow old unshared.”
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: “This carcass is full of putrefaction, it swells
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: the charnel ground, for its nature is to fall apart.
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: What do you think is so essential in it
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: that you stare at me so crazily?”
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: “Your eyes are like those of a doe,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: or a pixie in the mountains;
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: seeing them,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: my sensual desire grows all the more.
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: Set in your flawless face of golden sheen,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: your eyes compare to a blue lily’s bud;
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: seeing them,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: my sensual excitement grows all the more.
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: Though you may wander far, I’ll still think of you,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: with your lashes so long, and your vision so clear.
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: I love no eyes more than yours,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: O pixie with such bashful eyes.”
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: “You’re setting out on the wrong road!
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: You’re looking to take the moon for your toy!
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: You’re trying to leap over Mount Meru!
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: You, who are hunting a child of the Buddha!
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: For in this world with all its gods,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: there will be no more lust anywhere in me.
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: I don’t even know what kind it could be,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: it’s been smashed root and all by the path.
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: Cast out like sparks from fiery coals,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: it’s worth no more than a bowl of poison.
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: I don’t even see what kind it could be,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: it’s been smashed root and all by the path.
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: Well may you try to seduce the type of lady
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: who has not reflected on these things,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: or who has never attended the Teacher:
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: but this is a lady who knows—now you’re in trouble!
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: No matter if I am reviled or praised,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: or feel pleasure or pain: I stay mindful.
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: Knowing that conditions are ugly,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: my mind clings to nothing.
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: I am a disciple of the Holy One,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: riding in the carriage of the eightfold path.
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: The dart pulled out, free of defilements,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: I’m happy to have reached an empty place.
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: I’ve seen brightly painted
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: dolls and wooden puppets,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: tied to sticks and strings,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: and made to dance in many ways.
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: But when the sticks and strings are taken off—
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: loosed, disassembled, dismantled,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: irrecoverable, stripped to parts—
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: on what could the mind be fixed?
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: That’s what my body is really like,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: without those things it can’t go on.
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: This being so,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: on what could the mind be fixed?
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: It’s like when you see a mural on a wall,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: painted with orpiment,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: and your vision gets confused,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: falsely perceiving that it is a person.
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: Though it’s as worthless as a magic trick,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: or a golden tree seen in a dream,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: you blindly chase what is hollow,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: like a puppet show among the people.
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: An eye is just a ball in a socket,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: with a pupil in the middle, and tears,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: and mucus comes from there as well,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: and so different eye-parts are lumped all together.”
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: The pretty lady ripped out her eye.
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: With no attachment in her mind at all, she said:
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: “Come now, take this eye,”
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: and asked for her forgiveness:
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: “May you be well, O chaste and holy lady;
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: such a thing will not happen again.
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: Attacking a person such as this

segment_text: is like holding on to a blazing fire,
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: or grabbing a deadly viper!
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: May you be well, please forgive me.”
title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

title: Subhā of Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

segment_text: In Pāṭaliputta, the cream of the world,
title: Isidāsī

title: Isidāsī

segment_text: both of them ladies of quality.
title: Isidāsī

title: Isidāsī

title: Isidāsī

segment_text: lovers of meditation and chanting,
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: learned, crushing corruptions.
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: They wandered for alms and had their meal.
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: When they had washed their bowls,
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: they sat happily in a private place
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: and started a conversation.
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: “You’re so lovely, Venerable Isidāsī,
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: your youth has not yet faded.
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: What problem did you see that made you
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: dedicate your life to renunciation?”
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: Being pressed like this in private,
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: Isidāsī, skilled in teaching Dhamma,
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: voiced the following words.
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: “Bodhī, hear how I went forth.
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: In the fine town of Ujjenī,
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: my father was a financier, a good and moral man.
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: I was his only daughter,
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: dear, beloved, and cherished.
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: Then some suitors came for me
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: from the top family of Sāketa.
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: They were sent by a financier abounding in wealth,
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: to whom my father then gave me as daughter-in-law.
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: Come morning and come night,
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: I bowed with my head to the feet
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: of my father and mother-in-law,
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: just as I had been told.
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: Whenever I saw my husband’s sisters,
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: his brothers, his servants,
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: or even he, my one and only,
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: I nervously gave them a seat.
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: Whatever they wanted—food and drink,
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: treats, or whatever was in the cupboard—
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: I brought out and offered to them,
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: ensuring each got what was fitting.
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: Having risen bright and early,
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: I approached the main house,
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: washed my hands and feet,
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: and went to my husband with joined palms.
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: Taking a comb, adornments,
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: eyeshadow, and a mirror,
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: I myself did the makeup for my husband,
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: as if I were his beautician.
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: I myself cooked the rice;
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: I myself washed the pots.
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: I looked after my husband
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: like a mother her only child.
title: Isidāsī

title: Isidāsī

segment_text: a loving, virtuous, and humble servant,
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: getting up early, and working tirelessly:
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: yet still my husband did me wrong.

title: Isidāsī

segment_text: ‘I’ll take my leave and go,
title: Isidāsī

title: Isidāsī

title: Isidāsī

segment_text: ‘Son, don’t speak like this!
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: Isidāsī is astute and competent,
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: she gets up early and works tirelessly,
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: son, why doesn’t she please you?’
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: ‘She hasn’t done anything to hurt me,
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: but I just can’t stand to live with her.
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: As far as I’m concerned, she’s just horrible.
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: I’ve had enough, I’ll take my leave and go.’
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: When they heard his words,
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: my father-in-law and mother-in-law asked me:
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: ‘What did you do wrong?
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: Tell us honestly, have no fear.’
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: ‘I’ve done nothing wrong,
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: I haven’t hurt him, or said anything bad.
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: What can I possibly do,
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: when my husband finds me so hateful?’
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: They led me back to my father’s home,
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: distraught, overcome with suffering, and said:
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: ‘By caring for our son,
title: Isidāsī

segment_text: we’ve lost her, so lovely and lucky!’

title: Isidāsī

segment_text: of a second wealthy family-man.

title: Isidāsī

segment_text: of that which the financier paid.

title: Isidāsī

title: Isidāsī

segment_text: a tamer of others and of himself:

title: Upon Awakening (1st)

segment_text: At one time, when he was first awakened, the Buddha was staying near Uruvelā at the root of the tree of awakening on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.
title: Upon Awakening (1st)

segment_text: There the Buddha sat cross-legged for seven days without moving, experiencing the bliss of freedom.
title: Upon Awakening (1st)

segment_text: When seven days had passed, the Buddha emerged from that state of immersion. In the first part of the night, he carefully applied the mind to dependent origination in forward order:
title: Upon Awakening (1st)

segment_text: “When this exists, that is; due to the arising of this, that arises. That is:
title: Upon Awakening (1st)

segment_text: Ignorance is a condition for choices.
title: Upon Awakening (1st)

segment_text: Choices are a condition for consciousness.
title: Upon Awakening (1st)

segment_text: Consciousness is a condition for name and form.
title: Upon Awakening (1st)

segment_text: Name and form are conditions for the six sense fields.
title: Upon Awakening (1st)

segment_text: The six sense fields are conditions for contact.
title: Upon Awakening (1st)

segment_text: Contact is a condition for feeling.
title: Upon Awakening (1st)

segment_text: Feeling is a condition for craving.
title: Upon Awakening (1st)

segment_text: Craving is a condition for grasping.
title: Upon Awakening (1st)

segment_text: Grasping is a condition for continued existence.
title: Upon Awakening (1st)

segment_text: Continued existence is a condition for rebirth.
title: Upon Awakening (1st)

segment_text: Rebirth is a condition for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be.
title: Upon Awakening (1st)

segment_text: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.”
title: Upon Awakening (1st)

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: Upon Awakening (1st)

segment_text: “When things become clear
title: Upon Awakening (1st)

title: Upon Awakening (1st)
