title: Upon Awakening (1st)

segment_text: since he understands each thing and its cause.”
title: Upon Awakening (1st)

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: Upon Awakening (2nd)

segment_text: At one time, when he was first awakened, the Buddha was staying near Uruvelā at the root of the tree of awakening on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.
title: Upon Awakening (2nd)

segment_text: There the Buddha sat cross-legged for seven days without moving, experiencing the bliss of freedom.
title: Upon Awakening (2nd)

segment_text: When seven days had passed, the Buddha emerged from that state of immersion. In the second part of the night, he carefully applied the mind to dependent origination in reverse order:
title: Upon Awakening (2nd)

segment_text: “When this doesn’t exist, that is not; due to the cessation of this, that ceases. That is:
title: Upon Awakening (2nd)

segment_text: When ignorance ceases, choices cease.
title: Upon Awakening (2nd)

segment_text: When choices cease, consciousness ceases.
title: Upon Awakening (2nd)

segment_text: When consciousness ceases, name and form cease.
title: Upon Awakening (2nd)

segment_text: When name and form cease, the six sense fields cease.
title: Upon Awakening (2nd)

segment_text: When the six sense fields cease, contact ceases.
title: Upon Awakening (2nd)

segment_text: When contact ceases, feeling ceases.
title: Upon Awakening (2nd)

segment_text: When feeling ceases, craving ceases.
title: Upon Awakening (2nd)

segment_text: When craving ceases, grasping ceases.
title: Upon Awakening (2nd)

segment_text: When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases.
title: Upon Awakening (2nd)

segment_text: When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases.
title: Upon Awakening (2nd)

segment_text: When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease.
title: Upon Awakening (2nd)

segment_text: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.”
title: Upon Awakening (2nd)

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: Upon Awakening (2nd)

segment_text: “When things become clear
title: Upon Awakening (2nd)

segment_text: to the keen, meditating brahmin,
title: Upon Awakening (2nd)

segment_text: his doubts are dispelled,
title: Upon Awakening (2nd)

segment_text: since he’s known the end of conditions.”
title: Upon Awakening (2nd)

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: Upon Awakening (3rd)

segment_text: At one time, when he was first awakened, the Buddha was staying near Uruvelā at the root of the tree of awakening on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.
title: Upon Awakening (3rd)

segment_text: There the Buddha sat cross-legged for seven days without moving, experiencing the bliss of freedom.
title: Upon Awakening (3rd)

segment_text: When seven days had passed, the Buddha emerged from that state of immersion. In the last part of the night, he carefully applied the mind to dependent origination in forward and reverse order:
title: Upon Awakening (3rd)

segment_text: “When this exists, that is; due to the arising of this, that arises.
title: Upon Awakening (3rd)

segment_text: When this doesn’t exist, that is not; due to the cessation of this, that ceases. That is:
title: Upon Awakening (3rd)

segment_text: Ignorance is a condition for choices.
title: Upon Awakening (3rd)

segment_text: Choices are a condition for consciousness.
title: Upon Awakening (3rd)

segment_text: Consciousness is a condition for name and form.
title: Upon Awakening (3rd)

segment_text: Name and form are conditions for the six sense fields.
title: Upon Awakening (3rd)

segment_text: The six sense fields are conditions for contact.
title: Upon Awakening (3rd)

segment_text: Contact is a condition for feeling.
title: Upon Awakening (3rd)

segment_text: Feeling is a condition for craving.
title: Upon Awakening (3rd)

segment_text: Craving is a condition for grasping.
title: Upon Awakening (3rd)

segment_text: Grasping is a condition for continued existence.
title: Upon Awakening (3rd)

segment_text: Continued existence is a condition for rebirth.
title: Upon Awakening (3rd)

segment_text: Rebirth is a condition for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be.
title: Upon Awakening (3rd)

segment_text: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.
title: Upon Awakening (3rd)

segment_text: When ignorance fades away and ceases with nothing left over, choices cease.
title: Upon Awakening (3rd)

segment_text: When choices cease, consciousness ceases.
title: Upon Awakening (3rd)

segment_text: When consciousness ceases, name and form cease.
title: Upon Awakening (3rd)

segment_text: When name and form cease, the six sense fields cease.
title: Upon Awakening (3rd)

segment_text: When the six sense fields cease, contact ceases.
title: Upon Awakening (3rd)

segment_text: When contact ceases, feeling ceases.
title: Upon Awakening (3rd)

segment_text: When feeling ceases, craving ceases.
title: Upon Awakening (3rd)

segment_text: When craving ceases, grasping ceases.
title: Upon Awakening (3rd)

segment_text: When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases.
title: Upon Awakening (3rd)

segment_text: When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases.
title: Upon Awakening (3rd)

segment_text: When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease.
title: Upon Awakening (3rd)

segment_text: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.”
title: Upon Awakening (3rd)

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: Upon Awakening (3rd)

segment_text: “When things become clear
title: Upon Awakening (3rd)

segment_text: to the keen, meditating brahmin,
title: Upon Awakening (3rd)

segment_text: he remains, scattering Māra’s army,
title: Upon Awakening (3rd)

segment_text: as the sun lights up the sky.”
title: Upon Awakening (3rd)

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: Whiny

segment_text: At one time, when he was first awakened, the Buddha was staying near Uruvelā at the goatherd’s banyan tree on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.
title: Whiny

segment_text: There the Buddha sat cross-legged for seven days without moving, experiencing the bliss of freedom.
title: Whiny

segment_text: When seven days had passed, the Buddha emerged from that state of immersion.
title: Whiny

segment_text: Then a certain brahmin of the whiny sort went up to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.
title: Whiny

segment_text: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he stood to one side, and said,
title: Whiny

segment_text: “Master Gotama, how do you define a brahmin? And what are the things that make one a brahmin?”
title: Whiny

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: Whiny

segment_text: “A brahmin who has banished bad qualities—
title: Whiny

segment_text: not whiny, not stained, but self-controlled,
title: Whiny

segment_text: a complete knowledge master <j>who has completed the spiritual journey—
title: Whiny

segment_text: may rightly proclaim the brahmin doctrine,
title: Whiny

segment_text: not proud of anything in the world.”
title: Whiny

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: The Brahmin

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: The Brahmin

segment_text: Now at that time a number of senior monks approached the Buddha—Venerables Sāriputta, Mahāmoggallāna, Mahākassapa, Mahākaccāna, Mahākoṭṭhita, Mahākappina, Mahācunda, Anuruddha, Revata, and Nanda.
title: The Brahmin

segment_text: The Buddha saw them coming off in the distance,
title: The Brahmin

segment_text: and addressed the mendicants:
title: The Brahmin

segment_text: “These, mendicants, are brahmins coming!
title: The Brahmin

segment_text: These are brahmins coming!”
title: The Brahmin

segment_text: When he said this, a certain mendicant of the brahmin caste asked the Buddha,
title: The Brahmin

segment_text: “Sir, how do you define a brahmin? And what are the things that make one a brahmin?”
title: The Brahmin

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: The Brahmin

segment_text: “Having banished bad qualities,
title: The Brahmin

segment_text: those who live always mindful,
title: The Brahmin

segment_text: with fetters ended, awakened,
title: The Brahmin

segment_text: they are the world’s true brahmins.”
title: The Brahmin

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Mahākassapa

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
title: With Mahākassapa

segment_text: Now at that time Venerable Mahākassapa was staying in the Pipphali cave, and he was sick, suffering, gravely ill.
title: With Mahākassapa

segment_text: Then after some time he recovered from that illness.
title: With Mahākassapa

segment_text: It occurred to him,
title: With Mahākassapa

segment_text: “Why not enter Rājagaha for almsfood?”
title: With Mahākassapa

segment_text: Now at that time five hundred deities were ready and eager for the chance to offer alms to Mahākassapa.
title: With Mahākassapa

segment_text: But Mahākasspa refused those deities. In the morning, he robed up, took his bowl and robe, and entered Rājagaha for alms.
title: With Mahākassapa

segment_text: He went to the streets of the poor, the destitute, and the weavers.
title: With Mahākassapa

segment_text: The Buddha saw him wandering for alms in the streets of the poor, the destitute, and the weavers.
title: With Mahākassapa

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: With Mahākassapa

segment_text: “The stranger, providing for no other,
title: With Mahākassapa

segment_text: tamed, grounded in the essence,
title: With Mahākassapa

segment_text: with defilements ended and flaws purged:
title: With Mahākassapa

segment_text: that’s who I call a brahmin.”
title: With Mahākassapa

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: At Ajakalāpaka

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying in Pāvā at the Ajakalāpaka Tree-shrine, the haunt of the native spirit Ajakalāpaka.
title: At Ajakalāpaka

segment_text: Now at that time the Buddha was meditating in the open during the dark of night, while a gentle rain drizzled down.
title: At Ajakalāpaka

segment_text: Then Ajakalāpaka, wanting to make the Buddha feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, approached him, and while not far away yelled three times, “Grr! Arrgh!” Then he added,
title: At Ajakalāpaka

segment_text: “Now that’s a goblin for you, ascetic!”
title: At Ajakalāpaka

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: At Ajakalāpaka

segment_text: “When a brahmin gets over
title: At Ajakalāpaka

segment_text: their own issues,
title: At Ajakalāpaka

segment_text: they transcend this goblin
title: At Ajakalāpaka

segment_text: and his grunts.”
title: At Ajakalāpaka

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Saṅgāmaji

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: With Saṅgāmaji

segment_text: Now at that time around Venerable Saṅgāmaji had arrived at Sāvatthī to see the Buddha.
title: With Saṅgāmaji

segment_text: His former wife heard
title: With Saṅgāmaji

segment_text: that he had arrived,
title: With Saṅgāmaji

segment_text: and went to the Jetavana, taking their boy.
title: With Saṅgāmaji

segment_text: Now at that time Venerable Saṅgāmaji was sitting at the root of a tree for the day’s meditation.
title: With Saṅgāmaji

segment_text: Then his former wife went up to him and said,
title: With Saṅgāmaji

segment_text: “I have a little child, ascetic, so please provide for me.”
title: With Saṅgāmaji

segment_text: When she said this, Saṅgāmaji kept silent.
title: With Saṅgāmaji

segment_text: For a second time she said,
title: With Saṅgāmaji

segment_text: “I have a little child, ascetic, so please provide for me.”
title: With Saṅgāmaji

segment_text: For a second time, Saṅgāmaji kept silent.
title: With Saṅgāmaji

segment_text: For a third time she said,
title: With Saṅgāmaji

segment_text: “I have a little child, ascetic, so please provide for me.”
title: With Saṅgāmaji

segment_text: For a third time, Saṅgāmaji kept silent.
title: With Saṅgāmaji

segment_text: Then she put down the boy in front of Saṅgāmaji, saying,
title: With Saṅgāmaji

segment_text: “This is your child, ascetic. Provide for him.”
title: With Saṅgāmaji

segment_text: But Saṅgāmaji neither looked at the boy nor spoke to him.
title: With Saṅgāmaji

segment_text: Then his former wife went a little distance away. Looking back, she saw Saṅgāmaji ignoring the boy, and thought,
title: With Saṅgāmaji

segment_text: “This ascetic doesn’t even want his child.”
title: With Saṅgāmaji

segment_text: She returned to pick up the boy, then left.
title: With Saṅgāmaji

segment_text: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, the Buddha saw how Saṅgāmaji’s former wife went back for the child.
title: With Saṅgāmaji

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: With Saṅgāmaji

segment_text: “When she came he was not glad,
title: With Saṅgāmaji

segment_text: when she left he did not grieve.
title: With Saṅgāmaji

segment_text: Victorious in battle, freed from chains,
title: With Saṅgāmaji

segment_text: that’s who I call a brahmin.”
title: With Saṅgāmaji

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: Dreadlocked Ascetics

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Gayā on Gayā Head.
title: Dreadlocked Ascetics

segment_text: Now at that time—during the cold spell when the snow falls in the dead of winter—many dreadlocked ascetics plunged in and out of the Gayā river. Plunging and showering, they served the sacred flame, thinking:
title: Dreadlocked Ascetics

segment_text: “Through this there is purity.”
title: Dreadlocked Ascetics

segment_text: The Buddha saw them plunging in and out.
title: Dreadlocked Ascetics

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: Dreadlocked Ascetics

segment_text: “Purity doesn’t come from water,
title: Dreadlocked Ascetics

segment_text: no matter how many people bathe there.
title: Dreadlocked Ascetics

segment_text: One who has truth and principle,
title: Dreadlocked Ascetics

segment_text: they are pure, they are brahmins.”
title: Dreadlocked Ascetics

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: Now at that time Bāhiya of the Bark Cloth was residing by Suppāraka on the ocean shore, where he was honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed. And he received robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: Then as he was in private retreat this thought came to his mind,
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: “I am one of those in the world who are perfected or on the path to perfection.”
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: Then a deity who was a former relative of Bāhiya, having compassion and wanting what’s best for him, approached him and said:
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: “Bāhiya, you’re not a perfected one, nor on the path to perfection.
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: You don’t have the practice by which you might become a perfected one or one on the path to perfection.”
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: “Then who exactly are those in the world who are perfected or on the path to perfection?”
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: “In the northern lands there is a city called Sāvatthī.
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: There that Blessed One is now staying, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: He is a perfected one and teaches the Dhamma for the sake of perfection.”
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: Impelled by that deity, Bāhiya left Suppāraka right away.
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: Sojourning no more than a single night in any place, he made his way to Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery in the Jeta Grove at Sāvatthī.
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: At that time several mendicants were walking mindfully in the open air.
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: Bāhiya approached them and said,
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: “Sirs, where is the Blessed One at present, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: For I want to see him.”
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: “He has entered an inhabited area for almsfood, Bāhiya.”
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: Then Bāhiya rushed out of the Jeta Grove and entered Sāvatthī, where he saw the Buddha walking for alms. He was impressive and inspiring, with peaceful faculties and mind, attained to the highest self-control and serenity, like an elephant with tamed, guarded, and controlled faculties.
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: Bāhiya went up to the Buddha, bowed down with his head at the Buddha’s feet, and said,
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: “Sir, let the Blessed One teach me the Dhamma! Let the Holy One teach me the Dhamma!
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: That would be for my lasting welfare and happiness.”
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: The Buddha said this:
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: “It’s not the time, Bāhiya, so long as I have entered an inhabited area for almsfood.”
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: For a second time, Bāhiya said,
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: “But you never know, sir, when life is at risk, either the Buddha’s or my own.
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: Let the Blessed One teach me the Dhamma! Let the Holy One teach me the Dhamma!
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: That would be for my lasting welfare and happiness.”
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: For a second time, the Buddha said,
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: “It’s not the time, Bāhiya, so long as I have entered an inhabited area for almsfood.”
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: For a third time, Bāhiya said,
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: “But you never know, sir, when life is at risk, either the Buddha’s or my own.
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: Let the Blessed One teach me the Dhamma! Let the Holy One teach me the Dhamma!
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: That would be for my lasting welfare and happiness.”
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: “In that case, Bāhiya, you should train like this:
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: ‘In the seen will be merely the seen; in the heard will be merely the heard; in the thought will be merely the thought; in the known will be merely the known.’
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: That’s how you should train.
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: When you have trained in this way,
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: you won’t be ‘by that’.
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: When you’re not ‘by that’,
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: you won’t be ‘in that’.
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: When you’re not ‘in that’,
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: you won’t be in this world or the world beyond or between the two.
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: Just this is the end of suffering.”
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: Then, due to this brief Dhamma teaching of the Buddha, Bāhiya’s mind was right away freed from defilements by not grasping.
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: And when the Buddha had given Bāhiya this brief advice he left.
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: But soon after the Buddha had left, a cow with a baby calf charged at Bāhiya and took his life.
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: Then the Buddha wandered for alms in Sāvatthī. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he departed the city together with several mendicants and saw that Bāhiya had passed away.
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: He said to the monks,
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: “Mendicants, pick up Bāhiya’s corpse. Having lifted it onto a cot and carried it, cremate it and build a monument.
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: Mendicants, one of your spiritual companions has passed away.”
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” replied those mendicants. They did as the Buddha asked, then returned to the Buddha
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: and said,
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: “Sir, Bāhiya’s corpse has been cremated and a monument built for him.
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: Where has he been reborn in his next life?”
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: “Mendicants, Bāhiya was astute. He practiced in line with the teachings, and did not trouble me about the teachings.
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: Bāhiya of the Bark Cloth has become fully extinguished.”
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: “Where water and earth,
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: fire and air find no footing:
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: there no star does shine,
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: nor does the sun shed its light;
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: there the moon glows not,
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: yet no darkness is found.
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: And when a sage, a brahmin, finds understanding
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: through their own sagacity,
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: then from forms and formless,
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: from pleasure and pain they are released.”
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: This too is a heartfelt saying that was spoken by the Blessed One: that is what I heard.
title: With Bāhiya

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Mucalinda

segment_text: At one time, when he was first awakened, the Buddha was staying near Uruvelā at the root of the Mucalinda tree on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.
title: With Mucalinda

segment_text: There the Buddha sat cross-legged for seven days without moving, experiencing the bliss of freedom.
title: With Mucalinda

segment_text: Just then a great storm blew up out of season, bringing seven days of rain, cold winds, and clouds.
title: With Mucalinda

segment_text: Mucalinda, the dragon king, came out from his abode, encircled the Buddha’s body with seven coils and spread his large hood over his head, thinking,
title: With Mucalinda

segment_text: “May the Buddha not be hot or cold, nor be bothered by flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, or reptiles.”
title: With Mucalinda

segment_text: When seven days had passed, the Buddha emerged from that state of immersion.
title: With Mucalinda

segment_text: When he knew the sky was clear, Mucalinda unwrapped his coils from the Buddha’s body. Hiding his own form, he manifested in the form of a brahmin youth. He stood in front of the Buddha, venerating him with joined palms.
title: With Mucalinda

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: With Mucalinda

segment_text: “Seclusion is happiness for the contented
title: With Mucalinda

segment_text: who see the teaching they have learned.
title: With Mucalinda

segment_text: Kindness for the world is happiness
title: With Mucalinda

segment_text: for one who’d not harm a living creature.
title: With Mucalinda

segment_text: Dispassion for the world is happiness
title: With Mucalinda

segment_text: for one who has gone beyond sensual pleasures.
title: With Mucalinda

segment_text: But dispelling the conceit ‘I am’
title: With Mucalinda

segment_text: is truly the ultimate happiness.”
title: With Mucalinda

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: Kings

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: Kings

segment_text: Now at that time, after the meal, on return from almsround, several mendicants sat together in the assembly hall and this discussion came up among them:
title: Kings

segment_text: “Which of these two kings has greater wealth, riches, treasury, dominion, vehicles, forces, might, and power: King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha or King Pasenadi of Kosala?”
title: Kings

segment_text: At that point the conversation among those mendicants was left unfinished.
title: Kings

segment_text: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat, went to the assembly hall, sat down on the seat spread out,
title: Kings

segment_text: and addressed the mendicants:
title: Kings

segment_text: “Mendicants, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was left unfinished?”
title: Kings

segment_text: So the mendicants told him what they had been talking about when the Buddha arrived. The Buddha said,
title: Kings

segment_text: “Mendicants, it is not appropriate for you gentlemen who have gone forth in faith from the lay life to homelessness to talk about such things.
title: Kings

segment_text: When you’re sitting together you should do one of two things:
title: Kings

segment_text: discuss the teachings or keep noble silence.”
title: Kings

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: Kings

segment_text: “Neither the pleasures of the senses,
title: Kings

segment_text: nor even divine happiness,
title: Kings

segment_text: is worth even a sixteenth part
title: Kings

segment_text: of the happiness of craving’s end.”
title: Kings

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: A Stick

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: A Stick

segment_text: Now at that time, between Sāvatthī and the Jeta Grove, several boys were hitting a snake with a stick.
title: A Stick

title: A Stick

segment_text: He saw the boys hitting the snake.
title: A Stick

title: A Stick

title: A Stick

segment_text: so if you harm them with a stick
title: A Stick

segment_text: in search of your own happiness,
title: A Stick

title: A Stick

title: Esteem

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: Esteem

segment_text: Now at that time the Buddha was honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed. And he received robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
title: Esteem

segment_text: And the mendicant Saṅgha was also honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed. And they received robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
title: Esteem

segment_text: But the wanderers who followed other religions were not honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed. And they didn’t receive robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
title: Esteem

segment_text: Then those wanderers who followed other religions, unable to bear the esteem of the mendicant Sangha, abused, attacked, harassed, and troubled the mendicants in the village and the wilderness.
title: Esteem

segment_text: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.
title: Esteem

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: Esteem

segment_text: “When struck by pleasure and pain <j>in the village or wilderness,
title: Esteem

segment_text: regard it not as self or other.
title: Esteem

segment_text: Contacts strike because of attachment;
title: Esteem

segment_text: how would contacts strike one free of attachment?”
title: Esteem

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: A Lay Follower

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: A Lay Follower

segment_text: Now at that time a certain lay follower from Icchānaṅgalaka arrived at Sāvatthī on some business.
title: A Lay Follower

segment_text: Having concluded his business in Sāvatthī he went to see the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side.
title: A Lay Follower

segment_text: The Buddha said this to him:
title: A Lay Follower

segment_text: “It’s been a long time, lay follower, since you took the opportunity to come here.”
title: A Lay Follower

segment_text: “For a long time I’ve wanted to come and see the Buddha, but I wasn’t able, being prevented by my many duties and responsibilities.”
title: A Lay Follower

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: A Lay Follower

segment_text: “One who has nothing is happy indeed,
title: A Lay Follower

segment_text: a learned person who has assessed the teaching.
title: A Lay Follower

segment_text: See how troubled are those with attachments,
title: A Lay Follower

segment_text: a person bound tight to people.”
title: A Lay Follower

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: The Pregnant Woman

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: The Pregnant Woman

segment_text: Now at that time a certain wanderer had a young brahmin wife who was pregnant and about to give birth.
title: The Pregnant Woman

segment_text: She said to him,
title: The Pregnant Woman

segment_text: “Go, brahmin, bring oil for my delivery.”
title: The Pregnant Woman

segment_text: The wanderer said,
title: The Pregnant Woman

segment_text: “But where, my dear, can I get oil?”
title: The Pregnant Woman

segment_text: For a second time, she said,
title: The Pregnant Woman

segment_text: “Go, brahmin, bring oil for my delivery.”
title: The Pregnant Woman

segment_text: For a second time, the wanderer said,
title: The Pregnant Woman

segment_text: “But where, my dear, can I get oil?”
title: The Pregnant Woman

segment_text: For a third time, she said,
title: The Pregnant Woman

segment_text: “Go, brahmin, bring oil for my delivery.”
title: The Pregnant Woman

segment_text: Now at that time ghee and oil were being given away to any ascetic or brahmin at the storehouse of King Pasenadi of Kosala. But it was only to drink there, not to take away.
title: The Pregnant Woman

segment_text: Knowing this, the wanderer thought,
title: The Pregnant Woman

segment_text: “Why don’t I go to the king’s storehouse, drink as much oil as I can, then come home and throw it up so it can be used for the delivery?”
title: The Pregnant Woman

segment_text: Then he did just that. But when he got home he was unable to either bring it up or pass it out.
title: The Pregnant Woman

segment_text: He rolled to and fro, suffering painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings.
title: The Pregnant Woman

segment_text: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
title: The Pregnant Woman

segment_text: He saw the wanderer in agony.
title: The Pregnant Woman

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: The Pregnant Woman

segment_text: “Oh! How happy are those with nothing!
title: The Pregnant Woman

segment_text: Hence knowledge masters are people with nothing.
title: The Pregnant Woman

segment_text: See how troubled are those with attachments,
title: The Pregnant Woman

segment_text: a person bound tight to people.”
title: The Pregnant Woman

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: An Only Son

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: An Only Son

segment_text: Now at that time a certain lay follower’s dear and beloved only child passed away.
title: An Only Son

segment_text: Then in the middle of the day several lay followers with wet clothes and hair went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to them:
title: An Only Son

segment_text: “Why, lay followers, have you come here in the middle of the day with wet clothes and hair?”
title: An Only Son

segment_text: The lay follower replied,
title: An Only Son

segment_text: “Sir, my dear and beloved only child has passed away.
title: An Only Son

segment_text: That’s why we came here in the middle of the day with wet clothes and hair.”
title: An Only Son

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: An Only Son

segment_text: “Hosts of gods and most human beings are bound
title: An Only Son

segment_text: to what seems dear and pleasant.
title: An Only Son

segment_text: Miserable and exhausted,
title: An Only Son

segment_text: they fall under the sway of the King of Death.
title: An Only Son

segment_text: The diligent, who day and night
title: An Only Son

segment_text: leave behind what seems pleasant,
title: An Only Son

segment_text: dig out the root of misery—
title: An Only Son

segment_text: Death’s bait so hard to escape.”
title: An Only Son

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kuṇḍiyā in the Kuṇḍadhāna Grove.
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: Now at that time Suppavāsā the Koliyan had been pregnant for seven years, and in difficult labor for seven days.
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: While suffering painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings, three thoughts helped her endure:
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: “Oh! The Blessed One is indeed a fully awakened Buddha, who teaches the Dhamma for giving up suffering such as this.
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: Oh! The Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples is indeed practicing well, who practice for giving up suffering such as this.
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: Oh! Extinguishment is so very blissful, where such suffering as this is not found.”
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: Then Suppavāsā addressed her husband,
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: “Please, master, go to the Buddha, and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Ask him if he is healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: And then say:
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: ‘Suppavāsā the Koliyan has been pregnant for seven years, and in difficult labor for seven days.
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: While suffering painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings, three thoughts help her endure:
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: “Oh! The Blessed One is indeed a fully awakened Buddha, who teaches the Dhamma for giving up suffering such as this.
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: Oh! The Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples is indeed practicing well, who practice for giving up suffering such as this.
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: Oh! Extinguishment is so very blissful, where such suffering as this is not found.”’”
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: “Excellent idea,” he replied. He went to the Buddha and told him of his wife’s struggles. The Buddha said:
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: “May Suppavāsā the Koliyan be happy and healthy! May she give birth to a healthy child!”
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: As soon as he spoke, Suppavāsā, happy and healthy, gave birth to a healthy child.
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: Saying “Yes, sir,” the Koliyan gentleman approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right. Then he returned to his own house.
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: He saw that his wife, happy and healthy, had given birth to a healthy child,
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: and thought,
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: “Oh, how incredible, how amazing! The Realized One has such psychic power and might! For as soon as he spoke, Suppavāsā, happy and healthy, gave birth to a healthy child.”
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: He became uplifted and overjoyed, full of rapture and happiness.
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: Then Suppavāsā addressed her husband,
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: “Please, master, go to the Buddha, and in my name bow with your head to his feet.
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: And then say,
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: ‘Suppavāsā the Koliyan, who was pregnant for seven years, and in difficult labor for seven days,
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: is now happy and healthy and has given birth to a healthy child.
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: She invites the mendicant Saṅgha headed by the Buddha to a meal for seven days.
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: Sir, might the Buddha please accept seven meals from Suppavāsā.’”
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: “Excellent idea,” he replied. He went to the Buddha, told him the good news, and conveyed his wife’s invitation.
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: Now at that time a certain lay follower had already invited the Sangha of monks headed by the Buddha for the meal on the following day.
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: That lay follower was Venerable Mahāmoggallāna’s supporter.
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: Then the Buddha addressed Venerable Mahāmoggallāna,
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: “Please, Moggallāna, go to the that lay follower and say to him,
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: ‘Suppavāsā the Koliyan, who was pregnant for seven years, and in difficult labor for seven days,
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: is now happy and healthy and has given birth to a healthy child.
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: She invites the mendicant Saṅgha headed by the Buddha to a meal for seven days.
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: Let Suppavāsā make seven meals, afterwards you can make yours.’
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: He is your supporter.”
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” replied Mahāmoggallāna. He went to that lay follower and conveyed the Buddha’s request.
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: “If, sir, Venerable Mahāmoggallāna can guarantee me three things—
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: wealth, life, and faith—
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: then let Suppavāsā make seven meals, afterwards I shall make mine.”
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: “I can guarantee you two things—
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: wealth and life.
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: But as for faith, you alone are the guarantor.”
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: “If, sir Venerable Mahāmoggallāna can guarantee me two things—
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: wealth and life—
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: then let Suppavāsā make seven meals, afterwards I shall make mine.”
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: Having persuaded that lay follower, Mahāmoggallāna went to the Buddha and said,
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: “I’ve persuaded the lay follower.
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: Let Suppavāsā make seven meals, afterwards he shall make his.”
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: For seven days Suppavāsā served and satisfied the Buddha with her own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: And she made her little boy bow to the Buddha and the mendicant Sangha.
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: Then Sāriputta said to the boy,
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: “I hope you’re keeping well, little boy; I hope you’re alright. I hope that you are not in pain.”
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: “How could I be keeping well? How could I be alright?
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: For seven years I lived in a pot of blood.”
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: Then Suppavāsā, thinking,
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: “My child is conversing with the General of the Dhamma!” was uplifted and overjoyed, full of rapture and happiness.
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: Knowing this, the Buddha said to her,
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: “Would you like to have another child like this?”
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: “Sir, I would like to have seven more children like this!”
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: “Pain in the guise of pleasure,
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: the disliked in the guise of the liked,
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: suffering in the guise of happiness,
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: overpower the negligent.”
title: Suppavāsā

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the Eastern Monastery, the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother.
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: Now at that time Visākhā was caught up in some business with King Pasenadi.
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: But the king’s settlement did not meet her expectations.
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: Then, in the middle of the day, she went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down.
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: The Buddha said to her:
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: “So, Visākhā, where are you coming from in the middle of the day?”
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: “Sir, I am caught up in some business with King Pasenadi.
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: But the king’s settlement did not meet my expectations.”
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: “All under another’s control is suffering,
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: all under one’s own authority is pleasing;
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: what’s shared is stressful for both parties,
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: for yokes are hard to escape.”
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Bhaddiya

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Anupiya in a mango grove.
title: With Bhaddiya

segment_text: Now at that time, Venerable Bhaddiya son of Kāḷīgodhā, even in the wilderness, at the foot of a tree, or in an empty dwelling, frequently expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: With Bhaddiya

segment_text: “Oh, what bliss! Oh, what bliss!”
title: With Bhaddiya

segment_text: Several mendicants heard him
title: With Bhaddiya

segment_text: and thought,
title: With Bhaddiya

segment_text: “Without a doubt, Venerable Bhaddiya leads the spiritual life dissatisfied.
title: With Bhaddiya

segment_text: It’s when recalling the pleasures of royalty he formerly enjoyed as a lay person that, even in the wilderness, at the foot of a tree, or in an empty dwelling, he frequently expresses this heartfelt sentiment:
title: With Bhaddiya

segment_text: ‘Oh, what bliss! Oh, what bliss!’”
title: With Bhaddiya

segment_text: Then those mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what was happening.
title: With Bhaddiya

segment_text: So the Buddha addressed a certain monk,
title: With Bhaddiya

segment_text: “Please, monk, in my name tell the mendicant Bhaddiya that
title: With Bhaddiya

segment_text: the teacher summons him.”
title: With Bhaddiya

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” that monk replied. He went to Bhaddiya and said to him,
title: With Bhaddiya

segment_text: “Reverend Bhaddiya, the teacher summons you.”
title: With Bhaddiya

segment_text: “Yes, reverend,” Bhaddiya replied. He went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:
title: With Bhaddiya

segment_text: “Is it really true, Bhaddiya, that even in the wilderness, at the foot of a tree, or in an empty dwelling, you frequently express this heartfelt sentiment:
title: With Bhaddiya

segment_text: ‘Oh, what bliss! Oh, what bliss!’?”
title: With Bhaddiya

segment_text: “Yes, sir.”
title: With Bhaddiya

segment_text: “But why do you say this?”
title: With Bhaddiya

segment_text: “Formerly, as a lay person ruling the land, my guard was well organized within and without the royal compound, within and without the city, and within and without the country.
title: With Bhaddiya

segment_text: But although I was guarded and defended in this way, I remained fearful, scared, suspicious, and nervous.
title: With Bhaddiya

segment_text: But these days, even when alone in the wilderness, at the foot of a tree, or in an empty dwelling, I’m not fearful, scared, suspicious, or nervous. I live relaxed, unruffled, surviving on charity, my heart free as a wild deer.
title: With Bhaddiya

segment_text: It is for this reason that, even in the wilderness, at the foot of a tree, or in an empty dwelling, I frequently expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: With Bhaddiya

segment_text: ‘Oh, what bliss! Oh, what bliss!’”
title: With Bhaddiya

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: With Bhaddiya

segment_text: “They who hide no anger within,
title: With Bhaddiya

segment_text: gone beyond any kind of existence;
title: With Bhaddiya

segment_text: happy, free from fear and sorrow—
title: With Bhaddiya

segment_text: even the gods can’t see them.”
title: With Bhaddiya

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: Born of the Fruits of deeds

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: Born of the Fruits of deeds

segment_text: Now, at that time a certain mendicant was sitting not far from the Buddha, cross-legged, with his body straight. As a result of past deeds, he suffered painful, sharp, severe, and acute feelings, which he endured unbothered, with mindfulness and awareness.
title: Born of the Fruits of deeds

segment_text: The Buddha saw him meditating and enduring that pain.
title: Born of the Fruits of deeds

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: Born of the Fruits of deeds

segment_text: “A mendicant who has left all deeds behind,
title: Born of the Fruits of deeds

segment_text: shaking off the dust of past deeds,
title: Born of the Fruits of deeds

segment_text: unselfish, steady, poised,
title: Born of the Fruits of deeds

segment_text: has no need to complain.”
title: Born of the Fruits of deeds

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Nanda

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: With Nanda

segment_text: Now at that time Venerable Nanda, the Buddha’s brother and maternal cousin, informed several mendicants:
title: With Nanda

segment_text: “I lead the spiritual life dissatisfied.
title: With Nanda

segment_text: I am unable to keep up the spiritual life. I shall resign the training and return to a lesser life.”
title: With Nanda

segment_text: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what was happening.
title: With Nanda

segment_text: So the Buddha addressed a certain monk,
title: With Nanda

segment_text: “Please, monk, in my name tell the mendicant Nanda that
title: With Nanda

segment_text: the teacher summons him.”
title: With Nanda

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” that monk replied. He went to Nanda and said to him,
title: With Nanda

segment_text: “Reverend Nanda, the teacher summons you.”
title: With Nanda

segment_text: “Yes, reverend,” Nanda replied. He went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:
title: With Nanda

segment_text: “Is it really true, Nanda, that you informed several mendicants that
title: With Nanda

segment_text: you are unable to keep up the spiritual life; that you shall resign the training and return to a lesser life?”
title: With Nanda

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” he replied.
title: With Nanda

segment_text: “But why are you so dissatisfied with the spiritual life?”
title: With Nanda

segment_text: “As I left my house, sir, the finest lady of the Sakyan land, her hair half-combed, glanced at me and said,
title: With Nanda

segment_text: ‘Hurry back, master.’
title: With Nanda

segment_text: Recalling that, I am dissatisfied and shall resign the training.”
title: With Nanda

segment_text: Then the Buddha took Nanda by the arm and, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, vanished from Jeta’s Grove and reappeared among the gods of the Thirty-Three.
title: With Nanda

segment_text: Now at that time five hundred dove-footed nymphs had come to attend to Sakka, the lord of gods.
title: With Nanda

segment_text: Then the Buddha said to Nanda,
title: With Nanda

segment_text: “Nanda, do you see these five hundred dove-footed nymphs?”
title: With Nanda

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” he replied.
title: With Nanda

segment_text: “What do you think, Nanda? Who is more attractive, good-looking, and lovely—the finest lady of the Sakyan land, or these five hundred dove-footed nymphs?”
title: With Nanda

segment_text: “Compared to these five hundred dove-footed nymphs, the finest lady of the Sakyan land is like a deformed monkey with its ears and nose cut off.
title: With Nanda

segment_text: She doesn’t count, there’s no comparison, she’s not worth a fraction.
title: With Nanda

segment_text: These five hundred dove-footed nymphs are far more attractive, good-looking, and lovely.”
title: With Nanda

segment_text: “Rejoice, Nanda, rejoice!
title: With Nanda

segment_text: I guarantee you five hundred dove-footed nymphs.”
title: With Nanda

segment_text: “If, sir, you guarantee me five hundred dove-footed nymphs, I shall happily lead the spiritual life under the Buddha.”
title: With Nanda

segment_text: Then the Buddha took Nanda by the arm and, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, vanished from the gods of the Thirty-Three and reappeared at Jeta’s Grove.
title: With Nanda

segment_text: The mendicants heard,
title: With Nanda

segment_text: “It seems Venerable Nanda—who is both the Buddha’s half-brother and maternal cousin—leads the spiritual life for the sake of nymphs.
title: With Nanda

segment_text: And it seems that the Buddha guaranteed him five hundred dove-footed nymphs.”
title: With Nanda

segment_text: Monks who were his friends accused him of being a hireling and a lackey,
title: With Nanda

segment_text: “It seems Nanda is a hireling, it seems he is a lackey: he leads the spiritual life for the sake of nymphs.
title: With Nanda

segment_text: And it seems that the Buddha guaranteed him five hundred dove-footed nymphs.”
title: With Nanda

segment_text: Then Nanda—embarrassed, ashamed, and disgusted at being called a hireling and a lackey—living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
title: With Nanda

segment_text: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is no return to any state of existence.”
title: With Nanda

segment_text: Venerable Nanda became one of the perfected.
title: With Nanda

segment_text: Then, late at night, a glorious deity, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him:
title: With Nanda

segment_text: “Sir, Venerable Nanda—who is both the Buddha’s half-brother and maternal cousin—has realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. He lives having realized it with his own insight due to the ending of defilements.”
title: With Nanda

segment_text: And the knowledge also came to the Buddha:
title: With Nanda

segment_text: “Nanda has realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. He lives having realized it with his own insight due to the ending of defilements.”
title: With Nanda

segment_text: Then, when the night had passed, Nanda went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
title: With Nanda

segment_text: “Sir, you guaranteed me five hundred dove-footed nymphs. I release you from that promise.”
title: With Nanda

segment_text: “Nanda, I comprehended your mind and knew that
title: With Nanda

segment_text: you had realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom.
title: With Nanda

segment_text: And deities also told me about this.
title: With Nanda

segment_text: As soon as your mind was freed from defilements by not grasping, I was released from that promise.”
title: With Nanda

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: With Nanda

segment_text: “The mendicant who has crossed over the bog,
title: With Nanda

segment_text: who has crushed the thorn of sensuality,
title: With Nanda

segment_text: who has reached the end of delusion,
title: With Nanda

segment_text: trembles not at pleasure and pain.”
title: With Nanda

segment_text: So I have heard.

title: With Pilindavaccha

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
title: With Pilindavaccha

title: With Pilindavaccha

title: With Pilindavaccha

segment_text: “Sir, Venerable Pilindavaccha addresses the mendicants as ‘lowlifes’.”
title: With Pilindavaccha

title: With Pilindavaccha

title: With Pilindavaccha

segment_text: the Teacher summons him.”
title: With Pilindavaccha

title: With Pilindavaccha

title: With Pilindavaccha

segment_text: “Yes, reverend,” Pilindavaccha replied. He went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:
title: With Pilindavaccha

segment_text: “Is it really true, Vaccha, that you addressed the mendicants as ‘lowlifes’?”
title: With Pilindavaccha

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” he replied.
title: With Pilindavaccha

segment_text: Then, having applied his mind to Pilindavaccha’s past lives, the Buddha said to the mendicants,
title: With Pilindavaccha

segment_text: “Mendicants, don’t complain about the mendicant Vaccha.
title: With Pilindavaccha

segment_text: He doesn’t addresses the mendicants as ‘lowlifes’ out of hate.
title: With Pilindavaccha

segment_text: For five hundred lives without interruption he was reborn in a brahmin family.
title: With Pilindavaccha

segment_text: For a long time, he has addressed people as ‘lowlife’.
title: With Pilindavaccha

segment_text: That’s why he addresses the mendicants as ‘lowlifes’.”
title: With Pilindavaccha

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: With Pilindavaccha

segment_text: “In whom dwells no deceit or conceit,
title: With Pilindavaccha

segment_text: rid of greed, unselfish, with no need for hope,
title: With Pilindavaccha

title: With Pilindavaccha

segment_text: they are a brahmin, an ascetic, a mendicant.”
title: With Pilindavaccha

title: Sakka’s Heartfelt Saying

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
title: Sakka’s Heartfelt Saying

segment_text: Now at that time Venerable Mahākassapa was staying in the Pipphali cave. Having entered a certain state of immersion, he sat cross-legged for seven days without moving.
title: Sakka’s Heartfelt Saying

segment_text: When seven days had passed, Mahākassapa emerged from that state of immersion.
title: Sakka’s Heartfelt Saying

segment_text: It occurred to him,
title: Sakka’s Heartfelt Saying

segment_text: “Why not enter Rājagaha for almsfood?”
title: Sakka’s Heartfelt Saying

segment_text: Now at that time five hundred deities were ready and eager for the chance to offer alms to Mahākassapa.
title: Sakka’s Heartfelt Saying

segment_text: But Mahākasspa refused those deities. In the morning, he robed up, took his bowl and robe, and entered Rājagaha for alms.
title: Sakka’s Heartfelt Saying

segment_text: Now at that time Sakka, lord of Gods, wished to give alms to Mahākassapa.
title: Sakka’s Heartfelt Saying

segment_text: Having manifested in the appearance of a weaver, he worked the loom while the demon maiden Sujā fed the shuttle.
title: Sakka’s Heartfelt Saying

segment_text: Then, as Mahākassapa wandered indiscriminately for almsfood in Rājagaha, he approached Sakka’s house.
title: Sakka’s Heartfelt Saying

segment_text: Seeing Mahākassapa coming off in the distance,
title: Sakka’s Heartfelt Saying

segment_text: Sakka came out of his house, greeted him, and took the bowl from his hand. He re-entered the house and filled the bowl with rice from the pot.
title: Sakka’s Heartfelt Saying

segment_text: That almsfood had many tasty soups and sauces.
title: Sakka’s Heartfelt Saying

segment_text: Then it occurred to Mahākassapa,
title: Sakka’s Heartfelt Saying

segment_text: “Now, what being is this who has such psychic power?”
title: Sakka’s Heartfelt Saying

segment_text: It occurred to him,
title: Sakka’s Heartfelt Saying

segment_text: “This is Sakka, lord of Gods.”
title: Sakka’s Heartfelt Saying

segment_text: Knowing this, he said to Sakka,
title: Sakka’s Heartfelt Saying

segment_text: “This is your doing, Kosiya;
title: Sakka’s Heartfelt Saying

segment_text: don’t do such a thing again.”
title: Sakka’s Heartfelt Saying

segment_text: “But Honorable Kassapa, we too need merit!
title: Sakka’s Heartfelt Saying

segment_text: We too ought make merit.”
title: Sakka’s Heartfelt Saying

segment_text: Then Sakka bowed and respectfully circled Mahākassapa, keeping him on his right. Then he rose into the air and, sitting cross-legged in the sky, expressed this heartfelt sentiment three times:
title: Sakka’s Heartfelt Saying

segment_text: “Oh the gift, the best gift is well established in Kassapa!
title: Sakka’s Heartfelt Saying

segment_text: Oh the gift, the best gift is well established in Kassapa!
title: Sakka’s Heartfelt Saying

segment_text: Oh the gift, the best gift is well established in Kassapa!”
title: Sakka’s Heartfelt Saying

segment_text: With clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, the Buddha heard Sakka express this heartfelt sentiment while sitting in the sky.
title: Sakka’s Heartfelt Saying

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: Sakka’s Heartfelt Saying

segment_text: “A mendicant who relies on alms,
title: Sakka’s Heartfelt Saying

segment_text: self-supported, providing for no other;
title: Sakka’s Heartfelt Saying

segment_text: the poised one is envied by even the gods,
title: Sakka’s Heartfelt Saying

segment_text: calm and ever mindful.”
title: Sakka’s Heartfelt Saying

title: One Who Eats Only Almsfood

title: One Who Eats Only Almsfood

segment_text: From time to time we too will get to see pleasing sights, hear pleasing sounds, smell pleasing smells, taste pleasing tastes, and encounter pleasing touches.
title: One Who Eats Only Almsfood

title: The World

segment_text: At one time, when he was first awakened, the Buddha was staying near Uruvelā at the root of the tree of awakening on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.
title: The World

segment_text: There the Buddha sat cross-legged for seven days without moving, experiencing the bliss of freedom.
title: The World

segment_text: When seven days had passed, the Buddha emerged from that state of immersion and surveyed the world with the eye of a Buddha.
title: The World

segment_text: He saw sentient beings tormented with many torments, and burning with many fevers
title: The World

segment_text: born of greed, hate, and delusion.
title: The World

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: The World

segment_text: “This world, born in torment,
title: The World

segment_text: overcome by contact, speaks of disease as the self.
title: The World

segment_text: For whatever it thinks it is,
title: The World

segment_text: it turns out to be something else.
title: The World

segment_text: The world is attached to continued existence, <j>overcome by continued existence,
title: The World

segment_text: taking pleasure only in continued existence, <j>yet it becomes something else.
title: The World

segment_text: What it enjoys, that is the fear;
title: The World

segment_text: what it fears, that is the suffering.
title: The World

segment_text: But this spiritual life is led
title: The World

segment_text: in order to give up continued existence.
title: The World

segment_text: Of the ascetics and brahmins who say that through continued existence one is freed from continued existence, none are themselves freed from continued existence, I say.
title: The World

segment_text: Of the ascetics and brahmins who say that through annihilation of existence one escapes from continued existence, none have themselves escaped from continued existence, I say.
title: The World

segment_text: For this suffering originates dependent on all attachment. With the ending of all grasping there is no origination of suffering.
title: The World

segment_text: Just look at this world!
title: The World

segment_text: Mired in all sorts of ignorance, beings in love with being are not released from continued existence.
title: The World

segment_text: Whatever states of continued existence there are—everywhere, all over—all are impermanent, suffering, and perishable.
title: The World

segment_text: One who sees truly like this,
title: The World

segment_text: with right wisdom,
title: The World

segment_text: gives up craving for continued existence,
title: The World

segment_text: while not looking forward to ending existence.
title: The World

segment_text: Extinguishment comes <j>from the ending of all cravings;
title: The World

segment_text: fading away and cessation with nothing left over.
title: The World

segment_text: There is no further existence
title: The World

segment_text: for that mendicant extinguished without grasping.
title: The World

segment_text: Victorious in battle, such a one has defeated Māra;
title: The World

segment_text: they’ve gone beyond all states of existence.”
title: The World

title: With Meghiya

title: With Meghiya

title: With Meghiya

title: With Meghiya

title: With Meghiya

title: With Meghiya

title: With Meghiya

title: With Meghiya

title: With Meghiya

title: With Meghiya

title: With Meghiya

title: With Meghiya
