segment_text: For a third time Meghiya said to the Buddha,
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: “Sir, the Buddha has nothing more to do, and nothing that needs improvement.
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: But I have.
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: If you allow me, I’ll go back to that mango grove to meditate.”
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: “Meghiya, since you speak of meditation, what can I say?
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: Please, Meghiya, go at your convenience.”
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: Then Meghiya got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right. Then he went to that mango grove, and, having plunged deep into it, sat at the root of a certain tree for the day’s meditation.
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: But while Meghiya was meditating in that mango grove he was beset mostly by three kinds of bad, unskillful thoughts, namely,
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: sensual, malicious, and cruel thoughts.
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: Then he thought,
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: “Oh, how incredible, how amazing!
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: I’ve gone forth from the lay life to homelessness out of faith,
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: but I’m still harassed by these three kinds of bad, unskillful thoughts:
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: sensual, malicious, and cruel thoughts.”
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Meghiya came out of retreat and went to the Buddha. He bowed, sat down to one side, and told the Buddha what had happened.
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: “Meghiya, when the heart’s release is not ripe, five things help it ripen.
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: What five?
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: Firstly, a mendicant has good friends, companions, and associates.
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: This is the first thing …
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and seeking alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: This is the second thing …
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant gets to take part in talk about self-effacement that helps open the heart and leads solely to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment when they want, without trouble or difficulty. That is, talk about fewness of wishes, contentment, seclusion, aloofness, arousing energy, ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom.’
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: This is the third thing …
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant lives with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They are strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: This is the fourth thing …
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: This is the fifth thing that, when the heart’s release is not ripe, helps it ripen.
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: These are the five things that, when the heart’s release is not ripe, help it ripen.
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: A mendicant with good friends, companions, and associates can expect to be ethical …
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: A mendicant with good friends, companions, and associates can expect to take part in talk about self-effacement that helps open the heart …
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: A mendicant with good friends, companions, and associates can expect to be energetic …
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: A mendicant with good friends, companions, and associates can expect to be wise …
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: But then, a mendicant grounded on these five things should develop four further things.
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: They should develop the perception of ugliness to give up greed, love to give up hate, mindfulness of breathing to cut off thinking, and perception of impermanence to uproot the conceit ‘I am’.
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: When you perceive impermanence, the perception of not-self becomes stabilized.
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: Perceiving not-self, you uproot the conceit ‘I am’ and attain extinguishment in this very life.”
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: “With thoughts whether low or fine,
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: excitement in the mind arises.
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: Not understanding these thoughts in the mind,
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: one with mind astray runs all over the place.
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: Having understood these thoughts in the mind,
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: an awakened one—keen, restrained, and mindful—
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: has given up them all;
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: excitement in the mind no longer arises.”
title: With Meghiya

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: Restless

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying in the sal forest of the Mallas at Upavattana near Kusinārā.
title: Restless

segment_text: Now at that time several mendicants were staying not far from the Buddha in a wilderness hut. They were restless, insolent, fickle, scurrilous, loose-tongued, unmindful, lacking situational awareness and immersion, with straying minds and undisciplined faculties.
title: Restless

segment_text: The Buddha saw those mendicants staying nearby.
title: Restless

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: Restless

segment_text: “Unguarded in body,
title: Restless

segment_text: ruined by wrong view,
title: Restless

segment_text: overcome with dullness and drowsiness,
title: Restless

segment_text: you fall under Māra’s sway.
title: Restless

segment_text: That’s why you should guard the mind,
title: Restless

segment_text: with right thoughts your pasture,
title: Restless

segment_text: and right view at the fore.
title: Restless

segment_text: Having understood rise and fall,
title: Restless

segment_text: a mendicant who has overcome <j>dullness and drowsiness
title: Restless

segment_text: would cast off all bad destinies.”
title: Restless

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: The Cowherd

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.
title: The Cowherd

segment_text: And then the Buddha left the road, went to the root of a certain tree, and sat down on the seat spread out.
title: The Cowherd

segment_text: Then a certain cowherd went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side.
title: The Cowherd

segment_text: The Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired him with a Dhamma talk.
title: The Cowherd

segment_text: Then the cowherd said to the Buddha,
title: The Cowherd

segment_text: “Sir, may the Buddha together with the mendicant Saṅgha please accept tomorrow’s meal from me.”
title: The Cowherd

segment_text: The Buddha consented with silence.
title: The Cowherd

segment_text: The cowherd got up from his seat, circumambulated the Buddha with his right side toward him, and left.
title: The Cowherd

segment_text: And when the night had passed the cowherd had plenty of thick milk-rice prepared in his own home, with fresh ghee. Then he had the Buddha informed of the time, saying,
title: The Cowherd

segment_text: “Sir, it’s time. The meal is ready.”
title: The Cowherd

segment_text: The Buddha robed up, took his bowl and robe and, together with the Sangha of monks, went to the house of that cowherd, where he sat down on the prepared seat in the dining hall.
title: The Cowherd

segment_text: Then the cowherd served and satisfied the mendicant Saṅgha headed by the Buddha with his own hands with a thick milk-rice and fresh ghee.
title: The Cowherd

segment_text: When the Buddha had eaten and washed his hand and bowl, the cowherd took a low seat and sat to one side.
title: The Cowherd

segment_text: The Buddha then instructed, inspired, and gladdened him with a teaching, after which he got up and left.
title: The Cowherd

segment_text: But soon after the Buddha had left, the cowherd was killed by a certain man in the gap between village borders.
title: The Cowherd

segment_text: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.
title: The Cowherd

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: The Cowherd

segment_text: “A wrongly directed mind
title: The Cowherd

segment_text: would do you more harm
title: The Cowherd

segment_text: than a hater to the hated,
title: The Cowherd

segment_text: or an enemy to their foe.”
title: The Cowherd

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: At that time Venerables Sāriputta and Moggallāna were staying near the pigeons’ alcove.
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: Now at that time Venerable Sāriputta was sitting outdoors in the moonlight, his head freshly shaven, having entered a certain state of immersion.
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: Now at that time two native spirits who were friends were on their way from the north to the south on some business.
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: They saw Sāriputta meditating there.
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: One of the spirits said to the other,
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: “I feel inspired, friend, to give this ascetic a blow on the head!”
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: The other spirit replied,
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: “Enough, friend, don’t hit the ascetic!
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: That is an eminent ascetic, powerful and mighty!”
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: For a second time the first spirit said to the other,
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: “I feel inspired, friend, to give this ascetic a blow on the head!”
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: For a second time, the other spirit replied,
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: “Enough, friend, don’t hit the ascetic!
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: That is an eminent ascetic, powerful and mighty!”
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: For a third time the first spirit said to the other,
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: “I feel inspired, friend, to give this ascetic a blow on the head!”
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: For a third time, the other spirit replied,
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: “Enough, friend, don’t hit the ascetic!
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: That is an eminent ascetic, powerful and mighty!”
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: Ignoring his friend, the first spirit struck Sāriputta.
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: The blow was so strong it would have felled a bull elephant seven or seven and a half cubits tall, or split apart a great mountain peak.
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: But then the spirit, crying out, “I burn, I burn!” fell into the Great Hell right there.
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, Venerable Moggallāna saw that spirit striking Venerable Sāriputta.
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: He approached him and said,
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: “I hope you’re keeping well, reverend; I hope you’re alright. I hope that you are not in pain.”
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: “I am alright, Reverend Moggallāna;
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: but my head does hurt a little.”
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: “It’s incredible, Reverend Sāriputta, it’s amazing!
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: How mighty and powerful is Venerable Sāriputta!
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: Just now, a native spirit struck you on the head.
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: The blow was so strong it would have felled a bull elephant seven or seven and a half cubits tall, or split apart a great mountain peak.
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: Yet you say, ‘I am alright, Reverend Moggallāna;
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: but my head does hurt a little.’”
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: “It’s incredible, Reverend Moggallāna, it’s amazing!
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: How mighty and powerful is Venerable Moggallāna, in that he can even see a native spirit!
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: Whereas I can’t even see a mud-goblin right now.”
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: With clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, the Buddha heard that discussion between those two spiritual giants.
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: “One whose mind is like a rock,
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: steady, never trembling,
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: free of desire for desirable things,
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: not getting annoyed when things are annoying:
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: from where will suffering strike one
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: whose mind is developed like this?”
title: The Spirit’s Blow

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: A Bull Elephant

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambi, in Ghosita’s Monastery.
title: A Bull Elephant

segment_text: Now at that time Buddha lived crowded by monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen; by rulers and their ministers, and monastics of other religions and their disciples.
title: A Bull Elephant

segment_text: Crowded, he lived in suffering and discomfort.
title: A Bull Elephant

segment_text: Then he thought,
title: A Bull Elephant

segment_text: “These days I live crowded by monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen; by rulers and their ministers, and monastics of other religions and their disciples.
title: A Bull Elephant

segment_text: Crowded, I live in suffering and discomfort.
title: A Bull Elephant

segment_text: Why don’t I live alone, withdrawn from the group?”
title: A Bull Elephant

segment_text: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Kosambī for alms.
title: A Bull Elephant

segment_text: After the meal, on his return from almsround, he set his lodgings in order himself. Taking his bowl and robe, without informing his attendants or taking leave of the mendicant Saṅgha, he set out to go wandering alone towards Pārileyya, with no companion.
title: A Bull Elephant

segment_text: When he eventually arrived,
title: A Bull Elephant

segment_text: he stayed in a protected forest grove, at the foot of a sacred sal tree.
title: A Bull Elephant

segment_text: A certain bull elephant was also living crowded by other males, females, younglings, and cubs. He ate the grass they’d trampled, and they ate the broken branches he dragged down. He drank muddy water, and after his bath the female elephants bumped into him.
title: A Bull Elephant

segment_text: Crowded, he lived in suffering and discomfort.
title: A Bull Elephant

segment_text: Then he thought,
title: A Bull Elephant

segment_text: “These days I live crowded by other males, females, younglings, and cubs. I eat the grass they’ve trampled, and they eat the broken branches I’ve dragged down. I drink muddy water, and after my bath the female elephants bump into me. Crowded, I live in suffering and discomfort.
title: A Bull Elephant

segment_text: Why don’t I live alone, withdrawn from the herd?”
title: A Bull Elephant

segment_text: So he left the herd and went to Pārileyya, where he approached the Buddha in the protected forest grove at the foot of a sacred sal tree.
title: A Bull Elephant

segment_text: There he attended on the Buddha, clearing the vegetation from the place where the Buddha stayed, and using his trunk to set out water for drinking and washing.
title: A Bull Elephant

segment_text: Then as the Buddha was in private retreat this thought came to his mind,
title: A Bull Elephant

segment_text: “Formerly I lived crowded by monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen; by rulers and their ministers, and monastics of other religions and their disciples. Crowded, I live in suffering and discomfort.
title: A Bull Elephant

segment_text: But now I live uncrowded by monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen; by rulers and their ministers, and monastics of other religions and their disciples. Being uncrowded, I live in happiness and comfort.”
title: A Bull Elephant

segment_text: And to the bull elephant also this thought came to mind,
title: A Bull Elephant

segment_text: “Formerly I lived crowded by other males, females, younglings, and cubs. I ate the grass they’d trampled, and they ate the broken branches I’d dragged down. I drank muddy water, and after my bath the female elephants bumped into me. Crowded, I lived in suffering and discomfort.
title: A Bull Elephant

segment_text: But now I live uncrowded by other males, females, younglings, and cubs. I eat untrampled grass, and other elephants don’t eat the broken branches I have dragged down. I don’t drink muddy water, and the female elephants don’t bump into me after my bath. Being uncrowded, I live in happiness and comfort.”
title: A Bull Elephant

segment_text: Then, understanding his own seclusion and knowing what that elephant was thinking, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: A Bull Elephant

segment_text: “The giant elephant,
title: A Bull Elephant

segment_text: with tusks like chariot-poles,
title: A Bull Elephant

segment_text: agrees heart to heart with the spiritual giant,
title: A Bull Elephant

segment_text: since each finds joy in the woods alone.”
title: A Bull Elephant

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: The Alms-gatherer

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: The Alms-gatherer

segment_text: Now at that time Venerable Bhāradvāja the Alms-gatherer was sitting not far from the Buddha, cross-legged, with his body straight. He was one who lived in the wilderness, ate only almsfood, wore rag robes, and owned just three robes. He was of few wishes, content, secluded, aloof, and energetic, an advocate of austerities, dedicated to the higher mind.
title: The Alms-gatherer

segment_text: The Buddha saw him meditating there.
title: The Alms-gatherer

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: The Alms-gatherer

segment_text: “Not speaking ill nor doing harm;
title: The Alms-gatherer

segment_text: restraint in the monastic code;
title: The Alms-gatherer

segment_text: moderation in eating;
title: The Alms-gatherer

segment_text: staying in remote lodgings;
title: The Alms-gatherer

segment_text: commitment to the higher mind—
title: The Alms-gatherer

segment_text: this is the instruction of the Buddhas.”
title: The Alms-gatherer

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Sāriputta

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: With Sāriputta

segment_text: Now at that time Venerable Sāriputta was sitting not far from the Buddha, cross-legged, with his body straight. He was of few wishes, content, secluded, aloof, energetic, dedicated to the higher mind.
title: With Sāriputta

segment_text: The Buddha saw him meditating there.
title: With Sāriputta

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: With Sāriputta

segment_text: “A sage of higher consciousness, diligent,
title: With Sāriputta

segment_text: training in the ways of sagacity:
title: With Sāriputta

segment_text: there are no sorrows for one thus poised,
title: With Sāriputta

segment_text: calm and ever mindful.”
title: With Sāriputta

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: Now at that time the Buddha was honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed. And he received robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: And the mendicant Saṅgha was also honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed. And they received robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: But the wanderers who followed other religions were not honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed. And they didn’t receive robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: Then those wanderers who followed other religions, unable to bear the esteem of the mendicant Sangha, approached the female wanderer Sundarī and said,
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: “Sister, are you able to do something for the welfare of your kin?”
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: “What can I do, venerables?
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: How can I help?
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: I’d even give my life for the welfare of my kin.”
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: “Well then, sister, frequently visit Jeta’s Grove.”
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: “Yes, venerables,” she replied, and did as they asked.
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: When those wanderers knew
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: that Sundarī had been clearly seen by many people frequently visiting Jeta’s Grove,
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: they killed her and dumped her in the ditch around Jeta’s Grove. Then they went to see King Pasenadi of Kosala and said to him,
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: “Great king, we cannot find the female wanderer Sundarī.”
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: “But where do you suspect she is?”
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: “At Jeta’s Grove, great king.”
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: “Well then, search Jeta’s Grove.”
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: So the wanderers searched Jeta’s Grove. They pulled her body up from the ditch where they had dumped it, and lifted it on a bier. Having entered Sāvatthī, they went from street to street and from square to square, complaining to people:
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: “See the deed of the Sakyan ascetics!
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: Shameless are these Sakyan ascetics, immoral and wicked. They are liars and fake celibates.
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: Sure, they claim to be of principled and moral conduct, to be celibate, truthful, ethical, and of good character.
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: But they have no asceticism, no spirituality.
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: Asceticism and spirituality are lost to them!
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: Where is their asceticism, where their spirituality?
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: They have abandoned asceticism and spirituality!
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: How on earth can a man, having done a man’s business, kill a woman!”
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: Then at that time when the people of Sāvatthī saw the mendicants they abused and insulted them with rude, harsh words:
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: “Shameless are these Sakyan ascetics, immoral, wicked, liars, and fake celibates.
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: Sure, they claim to be of principled and moral conduct, to be celibate, truthful, ethical, and of good character.
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: But they have no asceticism, no spirituality.
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: Asceticism and spirituality are lost to them!
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: Where is their asceticism, where their spirituality?
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: They have abandoned asceticism and spirituality!
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: How on earth can a man, having done a man’s business, kill a woman!”
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: Then several mendicants robed up in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: Then, after the meal, when they returned from almsround, they went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what was happening.
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: “That rumor, mendicants, won’t last long. It will only be seven days, then it will vanish.
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: So you may respond to those critics with this verse:
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: A liar goes to hell,
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: as does one who denies what they did.
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: Both are equal in the hereafter,
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: those men of base deeds.”
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: The mendicants memorized that verse in the Buddha’s presence, then used it to respond to those critics.
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: People thought,
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: “These Sakyan ascetics didn’t do it, it was not done by them, they swear it.”
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: That rumor didn’t last long. It was seven days, then it vanished.
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: “It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing!
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: How well said this was by the Buddha:
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: ‘That rumor, mendicants, won’t last long. It will only be seven days, then it will vanish.’
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: That rumor has vanished, sir.”
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: “People out of control stab with words,
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: like they stab a tusker in battle with darts.
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: When they hear a harsh word spoken,
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: a mendicant should endure with no anger in heart.”
title: With Sundarī

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Upasena

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
title: With Upasena

segment_text: Then as Venerable Upasena son of Vaṅgantā was in private retreat this thought came to his mind:
title: With Upasena

segment_text: “I’m so fortunate, so very fortunate!
title: With Upasena

segment_text: My Teacher is the Blessed One, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha.
title: With Upasena

segment_text: Well explained is the teaching and training in which I have gone forth from the lay life to homelessness.
title: With Upasena

segment_text: My spiritual companions are ethical and of good character.
title: With Upasena

segment_text: I have fulfilled the precepts.
title: With Upasena

segment_text: My mind is unified and serene.
title: With Upasena

segment_text: I am a perfected one who has ended the defilements.
title: With Upasena

segment_text: I am of great might and power.
title: With Upasena

segment_text: My life has been good, and my death will be good.”
title: With Upasena

segment_text: Then, knowing what that Venerable Upasena was thinking, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: With Upasena

segment_text: “One who has no guilt in life,
title: With Upasena

segment_text: nor grief at facing death:
title: With Upasena

segment_text: that wise one who has seen the truth,
title: With Upasena

segment_text: grieves not among the grieving.
title: With Upasena

segment_text: For the mendicant with peaceful mind,
title: With Upasena

segment_text: who has cut off craving for continued existence,
title: With Upasena

segment_text: Transmigration through births is finished,
title: With Upasena

segment_text: there are no future lives for them.”
title: With Upasena

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: The Peacefulness of Sāriputta

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: The Peacefulness of Sāriputta

segment_text: Now at that time Venerable Sāriputta was sitting not far from the Buddha, cross-legged, with his body straight, reviewing his own peacefulness.
title: The Peacefulness of Sāriputta

segment_text: The Buddha saw him meditating there.
title: The Peacefulness of Sāriputta

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: The Peacefulness of Sāriputta

segment_text: “With mind at peace, so full of peace,
title: The Peacefulness of Sāriputta

segment_text: for a mendicant who has cut the cord,
title: The Peacefulness of Sāriputta

segment_text: transmigration through births is finished:
title: The Peacefulness of Sāriputta

segment_text: they’re freed from Māra’s bonds.”
title: The Peacefulness of Sāriputta

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: Who Is More Dear?

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: Who Is More Dear?

segment_text: Now at that time King Pasenadi of Kosala was upstairs in the royal longhouse together with Queen Mallikā.
title: Who Is More Dear?

segment_text: Then King Pasenadi addressed Queen Mallikā,
title: Who Is More Dear?

segment_text: “Mallikā, is there anyone more dear to you than yourself?”
title: Who Is More Dear?

segment_text: “No, great king, there isn’t.
title: Who Is More Dear?

segment_text: But is there anyone more dear to you than yourself?”
title: Who Is More Dear?

segment_text: “For me also, Mallikā, there’s no-one.”
title: Who Is More Dear?

segment_text: Then King Pasenadi of Kosala came downstairs from the stilt longhouse, went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.
title: Who Is More Dear?

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: Who Is More Dear?

segment_text: “Having explored every quarter with the mind,
title: Who Is More Dear?

segment_text: Likewise for others, each holds themselves dear;
title: Who Is More Dear?

segment_text: so one who loves themselves would harm no other.”
title: Who Is More Dear?

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: Short-lived

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: Short-lived

segment_text: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Ānanda came out of retreat and went to the Buddha. He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:
title: Short-lived

segment_text: “It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing!
title: Short-lived

segment_text: How short-lived was the Blessed One’s mother! For seven days after the Blessed One was born, his mother passed away and was reborn in the host of Joyful Gods.”
title: Short-lived

segment_text: “That’s so true, Ānanda! For the mothers of beings intent of awakening are short-lived.
title: Short-lived

segment_text: Seven days after the beings intent on awakening are born, their mothers pass away and are reborn in the host of Joyful Gods.”
title: Short-lived

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: Short-lived

segment_text: “Whether born or to be born,
title: Short-lived

segment_text: all depart, leaving the body behind.
title: Short-lived

segment_text: The skillful, understanding that all is lost,
title: Short-lived

segment_text: would keenly practice the spiritual life.”
title: Short-lived

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: At that time in Rājagaha there was a leper called Suppabuddha.
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: He was poor, destitute, and pitiful.
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: Now, at that time the Buddha was teaching Dhamma, surrounded by a large assembly.
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: Suppabuddha saw the crowd seated off in the distance
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: and thought,
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: “Surely some fresh and cooked foods will be distributed there.
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: Why don’t I approach the crowd?
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: Hopefully I’ll get something to eat.”
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: So he approached the crowd
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: where he saw the Buddha teaching Dhamma, surrounded by a large assembly.
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: When he saw this he thought,
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: “There’s no food being distributed here.
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: The ascetic Gotama is teaching Dhamma in an assembly.
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: Why don’t I also listen to the teaching?”
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: Right there he sat down to one side, thinking,
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: “I also will listen to the teaching.”
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: Then the Buddha focused on comprehending the minds of everyone in the assembly, thinking,
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: “Who here is capable of understanding the teaching?”
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: He saw Suppabuddha sitting in the assembly,
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: and thought,
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: “He is capable of understanding the teaching.”
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: He gave a step by step talk especially for Suppabuddha
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: on giving, ethical conduct, and heaven. He explained the drawbacks of sensual pleasures, so sordid and corrupt, and the benefit of renunciation.
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: When the Buddha knew that Suppabuddha’s mind was ready, supple, without hindrances, elated, and confident, he revealed the teaching unique to the Buddhas:
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: Just as a clean cloth rid of stains would properly absorb dye,
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: in that very seat the stainless, immaculate vision of the Dhamma in Suppabuddha:
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: “Everything that has a beginning has an end.”
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: Then Suppabuddha saw, attained, understood, and fathomed the Dhamma. He went beyond doubt, got rid of indecision, and became self-assured and independent of others regarding the Teacher’s instructions. He rose from his seat and went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said:
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: “Excellent, sir! Excellent!
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, the Buddha has made the teaching clear in many ways.
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: After Suppabuddha had been educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired with a Dhamma talk by the Buddha, he got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha before leaving.
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: But soon after Suppabuddha had left, a cow with a baby calf charged at him and took his life.
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said,
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: “The leper called Suppabuddha, after being educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired with a Dhamma talk by the Buddha, has passed away.
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: Where has he been reborn in his next life?”
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: “Mendicants, Suppabuddha was astute. He practiced in line with the teachings, and did not trouble me about the teachings.
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: With the ending of three fetters, Suppabuddha is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening.”
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: When he said this, one of the mendicants said to the Buddha,
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why Suppabuddha became a leper,
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: poor, destitute, and pitiful?”
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: “Once upon a time, mendicants, Suppabuddha used to be a financier’s son right here in Rājagaha.
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: On his way to visit a park, he saw Tagarasikhī, an independent Buddha, entering the city for alms.
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: When he saw this he thought,
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: “Who is this leper wandering about with his leper’s robe?”
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: Before leaving, he spat on the ground and turned his left side to Tagarasikhī.
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: As a result of that deed he burned in hell for many years, for many hundreds, many thousands, many hundreds of thousands of years.
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: And as a residual result of that same deed, he became a leper right here in Rājagaha, poor, destitute and pitiful.
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: But owing to faith in the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One, he undertook ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom.
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: After undertaking these things, when his body broke up, after death, he was reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm, in the company of the gods of the Thirty-Three.
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: There he outshines the other gods in beauty and glory.”
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: “As a clear-eyed man would avoid rough paths,
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: so long as strength is found;
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: an astute person in the living world,
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: would shun bad deeds.”
title: With Suppabuddha the Leper

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: The Boys

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: The Boys

segment_text: Now at that time, between Sāvatthī and the Jeta Grove, several boys were tormenting some fish.
title: The Boys

segment_text: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
title: The Boys

segment_text: He saw the boys tormenting the fish.
title: The Boys

segment_text: He went to them and said,
title: The Boys

segment_text: “Boys, do you fear pain? Do you dislike pain?”
title: The Boys

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” they replied. “We dislike pain.”
title: The Boys

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: The Boys

segment_text: “If you fear pain,
title: The Boys

segment_text: if you dislike pain,
title: The Boys

segment_text: don’t do bad deeds
title: The Boys

segment_text: either openly or in secret.
title: The Boys

segment_text: If you should do a bad deed,
title: The Boys

segment_text: now or in the future,
title: The Boys

segment_text: you won’t be freed from suffering,
title: The Boys

segment_text: though you fly away and flee.”
title: The Boys

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the Eastern Monastery, the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: Now, at that time it was the sabbath, and the Buddha was sitting surrounded by the Saṅgha of monks.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: And then, as the night was getting late, in the first watch of the night, Venerable Ānanda got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha and said,
title: Sabbath

segment_text: “Sir, the night is getting late. It is the first watch of the night, and the Saṅgha of monks has been sitting long.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: Please, sir, may the Buddha recite the monastic code to the monks.”
title: Sabbath

segment_text: But when he said this, the Buddha kept silent.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: For a second time, as the night was getting late, in the middle watch of the night, Ānanda got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha and said,
title: Sabbath

segment_text: “Sir, the night is getting late. It is the first watch of the night, and the Saṅgha of monks has been sitting long.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: Please, sir, may the Buddha recite the monastic code to the monks.”
title: Sabbath

segment_text: But for a second time the Buddha kept silent.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: For a third time, as the night was getting late, in the last watch of the night, as dawn stirred, bringing joy to the night, Ānanda got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha and said,
title: Sabbath

segment_text: “Sir, the night is getting late. It is the last watch of the night and dawn stirs, bringing joy to the night.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: Please, sir, may the Buddha recite the monastic code to the monks.”
title: Sabbath

segment_text: “Ānanda, the assembly is not pure.”
title: Sabbath

segment_text: Then Venerable Mahāmoggallāna thought,
title: Sabbath

segment_text: “Who is the Buddha talking about?”
title: Sabbath

segment_text: Then he focused on comprehending the minds of everyone in the Saṅgha.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: He saw that unethical person, of bad qualities, filthy, with suspicious behavior, underhand, no true ascetic or spiritual practitioner—though claiming to be one—rotten inside, corrupt, and depraved, sitting in the middle of the Saṅgha.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: When he saw him he got up from his seat, went up to him and said,
title: Sabbath

segment_text: “Get up, reverend. The Buddha has seen you.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: You can’t live in communion with the monks.”
title: Sabbath

segment_text: But when he said this, that person kept silent.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: For a second time and a third time,
title: Sabbath

segment_text: he asked that monk to leave.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: But for a third time that person kept silent.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: Then Venerable Mahāmoggallāna took that person by the arm, ejected him out the gate, and bolted the door. Then he went up to the Buddha, and said to him,
title: Sabbath

segment_text: “I have ejected that person.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: The assembly is pure.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: Please, sir, may the Buddha recite the monastic code to the monks.”
title: Sabbath

segment_text: “It’s incredible, Moggallāna, it’s amazing,
title: Sabbath

segment_text: how that silly man waited to be taken by the arm!”
title: Sabbath

segment_text: Then the Buddha said to the monks,
title: Sabbath

segment_text: “From this day forth, monks, I will not perform the sabbath or recite the monastic code.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: Now you should perform the sabbath and recite the monastic code.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: It’s impossible, monks, it can’t happen that a Realized One could recite the monastic code in an impure assembly.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: Seeing these eight incredible and amazing things the demons love the ocean.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: What eight?
title: Sabbath

segment_text: The ocean gradually slants, slopes, and inclines, with no abrupt precipice.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: This is the first thing the demons love about the ocean.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: Furthermore, the ocean is consistent and doesn’t overflow its boundaries.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: This is the second thing the demons love about the ocean.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: Furthermore, the ocean doesn’t accommodate a carcass, but quickly carries it to the shore and strands it on the beach.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: This is the third thing the demons love about the ocean.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: Furthermore, when they reach the ocean, all the great rivers—that is, the Ganges, Yamunā, Aciravatī, Sarabhū, and Mahī—lose their names and clans and are simply considered ‘the ocean’.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: This is the fourth thing the demons love about the ocean.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: Furthermore, for all the world’s streams that reach it, and the rain that falls from the sky, the ocean never empties or fills up.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: This is the fifth thing the demons love about the ocean.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: Furthermore, the ocean has just one taste, the taste of salt.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: This is the sixth thing the demons love about the ocean.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: Furthermore, the ocean is full of many kinds of treasures, such as pearls, gems, beryl, conch, quartz, coral, silver, gold, rubies, and emeralds.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: This is the seventh thing the demons love about the ocean.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: Furthermore, many great beings live in the ocean, such as leviathans, leviathan-gulpers, leviathan-gulper-gulpers, demons, dragons, and centaurs. In the ocean there are life-forms a hundred leagues long, or even two hundred, three hundred, four hundred, or five hundred leagues long.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: This is the eighth thing the demons love about the ocean.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: Seeing these eight incredible and amazing things the demons love the ocean.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: In the same way, seeing eight incredible and amazing things, mendicants, the mendicants love this teaching and training.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: What eight?
title: Sabbath

segment_text: The ocean gradually slants, slopes, and inclines, with no abrupt precipice.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: In the same way in this teaching and training the penetration to enlightenment comes from gradual training, progress, and practice, not abruptly.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: This is the first thing the mendicants love about this teaching and training.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: The ocean is consistent and doesn’t overflow its boundaries.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: In the same way, when a training rule is laid down for my disciples they wouldn’t break it even for the sake of their own life.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: This is the second thing the mendicants love about this teaching and training.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: The ocean doesn’t accommodate a carcass, but quickly carries it to the shore and strands it on the beach.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: In the same way, the Saṅgha doesn’t accommodate a person who is unethical, of bad qualities, filthy, with suspicious behavior, underhand, no true ascetic or spiritual practitioner—though claiming to be one—rotten inside, corrupt, and depraved. But they quickly gather and expel them. Even if such a person is sitting in the middle of the Saṅgha, they’re far from the Saṅgha, and the Saṅgha is far from them.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: This is the third thing the mendicants love about this teaching and training.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: Furthermore, when they reach the ocean, all the great rivers—that is, the Ganges, Yamunā, Aciravatī, Sarabhū, and Mahī—lose their names and clans and are simply considered ‘the ocean’.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: In the same way, when they go forth from the lay life to homelessness, all four castes—aristocrats, brahmins, peasants, and menials—lose their former names and clans and are simply considered ‘Sakyan ascetics’.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: This is the fourth thing the mendicants love about this teaching and training.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: For all the world’s streams that reach it, and the rain that falls from the sky, the ocean never empties or fills up.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: In the same way, though several mendicants become fully extinguished in the element of extinguishment with nothing left over, the element of extinguishment never empties or fills up.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: This is the fifth thing the mendicants love about this teaching and training.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: The ocean has just one taste, the taste of salt.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: In the same way, this teaching and training has one taste, the taste of freedom.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: This is the sixth thing the mendicants love about this teaching and training.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: The ocean is full of many kinds of treasures, such as pearls, gems, beryl, conch, quartz, coral, silver, gold, rubies, and emeralds.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: In the same way, this teaching and training is full of many kinds of treasures, such as the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, the four right efforts, the four bases of psychic power, the five faculties, the five powers, the seven awakening factors, and the noble eightfold path.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: This is the seventh thing the mendicants love about this teaching and training.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: Many great beings live in the ocean, such as leviathans, leviathan-gulpers, leviathan-gulper-gulpers, demons, dragons, and centaurs. In the ocean there are life-forms a hundred leagues long, or even two hundred, three hundred, four hundred, or five hundred leagues long.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: In the same way, great beings live in this teaching and training, and these are those beings. The stream-enterer and the one practicing to realize the fruit of stream-entry. The once-returner and the one practicing to realize the fruit of once-return. The non-returner and the one practicing to realize the fruit of non-return. The perfected one, and the one practicing for perfection.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: This is the eighth thing the mendicants love about this teaching and training.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: Seeing these eight incredible and amazing things, the mendicants love this teaching and training.”
title: Sabbath

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: Sabbath

segment_text: “The rain saturates things that are covered up;
title: Sabbath

segment_text: it doesn’t saturate things that are open.
title: Sabbath

segment_text: Therefore you should open up a covered thing,
title: Sabbath

segment_text: so the rain will not saturate it.”
title: Sabbath

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: Now at that time Venerable Mahākaccāna was staying in the land of the Avantis near Kuraraghara on Steep Mountain.
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: And the layman Soṇa of the Sharp Ears was Mahākaccāna’s attendant.
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: Then as Soṇa was in private retreat this thought came to his mind,
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: “As I understand Venerable Mahākaccāna’s teachings, it’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from lay life to homelessness?”
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: Then Soṇa went up to Mahākaccāna, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what he was thinking. Then he said,
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: “May Venerable Mahākaccāna please give me the going forth!”
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: When this was said, Mahākaccāna said to him,
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: “It’s hard to lead the spiritual life as long as you live, eating in one part of the day and sleeping alone.
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: Come now, Soṇa, while remaining a layperson just as you are, devote yourself to the instructions of the Buddhas, leading the spiritual life at suitable times, eating in one part of the day and sleeping alone.”
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: Then Soṇa’s aspiration to go forth died down.
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: For a second time, while in private retreat the thought came to Soṇa that he should go forth, but the outcome was the same.
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: For a third time, as Soṇa was in private retreat this thought came to his mind,
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: “As I understand Venerable Mahākaccāna’s teachings, it’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from lay life to homelessness?”
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: For a third time, Soṇa went up to Mahākaccāna, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what he was thinking. Then he said,
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: “May Venerable Mahākaccāna please give me the going forth!”
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: Then Mahākaccāna gave Soṇa the going forth.
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: Now at that time the southern region, including Avanti, was short of monks.
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: It took three years and much struggle and difficulty before Venerable Mahākaccāyana was able to assemble from here and there a Sangha consisting of ten monks and give Venerable Soṇa the full ordination.
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: Then as Venerable Soṇa was in private retreat this thought came to his mind,
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: “I have not personally seen the Buddha. I have only heard reports that
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: that Blessed One is like this or like that.
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: If my mentor allows, I should go to see that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.”
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: Then in the late afternoon, Soṇa came out of retreat, went up to Mahākaccāna, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what he was thinking. Then Mahākaccāna said,
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: “Good, good, Soṇa!
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: Go to see the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: You will see that Blessed One who is impressive and inspiring, with peaceful faculties and mind, attained to the highest self-control and serenity, like an elephant with tamed, guarded, and controlled faculties.
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: On seeing him, in my name bow with your head to his feet. Ask him if he is healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably, saying,
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: ‘Sir, my mentor Venerable Mahākaccāna bows with his head to your feet. He asks if you are healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.’”
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: Saying, “Yes, sir,” Soṇa welcomed and agreed with Mahākaccāna’s words. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled Mahākaccāna, keeping him on his right. Then he set his lodgings in order and, taking his bowl and robe, set out for Sāvatthī.
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: Eventually he came to Sāvatthī and Jeta’s Grove. He went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side.
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: Soṇa said to the Buddha,
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: “Sir, my mentor Venerable Mahākaccāna bows with his head to your feet. He asks if you are healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.”
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: “I hope you’re keeping well, mendicant; I hope you’re all right. And I hope you have arrived from your journey unwearied, having had no trouble getting almsfood.”
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: “I’m keeping well, sir; I’m all right. And I have arrived from my journey unwearied, having had no trouble getting almsfood.”
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: Then the Buddha said to Venerable Ānanda,
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: “Prepare lodgings for this visiting mendicant.”
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: Then Venerable Ānanda thought,
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: “When the Buddha orders me
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: to prepare lodgings for a specific mendicant, he wishes to stay in the same dwelling with that mendicant. The Buddha wishes to stay together with Venerable Soṇa.”
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: He prepared lodgings for Soṇa in the same dwelling where the Buddha was staying.
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: The Buddha spent much of the night sitting meditation in the open. Then he got up from his seat, washed his feet and entered the dwelling.
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: Venerable Soṇa did the same.
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: Then the Buddha rose at the crack of dawn and addressed Soṇa,
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: “Speak some Dhamma, mendicant, as you feel inspired.”
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” replied Soṇa. He intoned all sixteen discourses in the Chapter of the Eights.
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: When Soṇa finished his intoning, the Buddha applauded, saying,
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: “Good, good, mendicant! You have learned the sixteen discourses of the Chapter of the Eights well, you have applied the mind and remembered it well. You are a good speaker, with a polished, clear, and articulate voice that expresses the meaning.
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: How many rains have you been ordained, mendicant?”
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: “I have one rains, Blessed One.”
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: “But why did it take you so long to make it?”
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: “Sir, I have long seen the drawbacks of sensual pleasures,
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: yet living in a house is cramped, with many duties and much to do.”
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: “Seeing the danger of the world,
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: I understood the reality without attachments.
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: The Noble One does not delight in evil,
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: the Pure One does not delight in evil.”
title: With Soṇa

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Revata the Doubter

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: With Revata the Doubter

segment_text: Now at that time Venerable Revata the Doubter was sitting not far from the Buddha, cross-legged, with his body straight, reviewing his own purification through overcoming doubt.
title: With Revata the Doubter

segment_text: The Buddha saw him meditating there.
title: With Revata the Doubter

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: With Revata the Doubter

segment_text: “Any doubts about this world or the world beyond,
title: With Revata the Doubter

segment_text: about one’s own experiences or those of another:
title: With Revata the Doubter

segment_text: those who meditate give them all up,
title: With Revata the Doubter

segment_text: keenly practicing the spiritual life.”
title: With Revata the Doubter

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: Schism in the Saṅgha

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
title: Schism in the Saṅgha

segment_text: Now at that time Venerable Ānanda robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Rājagaha for alms.
title: Schism in the Saṅgha

segment_text: Devadatta saw him wandering for alms,
title: Schism in the Saṅgha

segment_text: so he went up to him and said,
title: Schism in the Saṅgha

segment_text: “From this day forth, Reverend Ānanda, I shall perform the sabbath and legal proceedings of the Saṅgha apart from the Buddha and the Saṅgha of mendicants.”
title: Schism in the Saṅgha

segment_text: Then Ānanda wandered for alms in Rājagaha. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side,
title: Schism in the Saṅgha

segment_text: and told him what had just happened, adding:
title: Schism in the Saṅgha

segment_text: “Today, sir, Devadatta will split the Saṅgha. He will perform the sabbath and legal proceedings of the Saṅgha.”
title: Schism in the Saṅgha

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: Schism in the Saṅgha

segment_text: “It’s easy for the good to do good,
title: Schism in the Saṅgha

segment_text: and hard for the good to do bad.
title: Schism in the Saṅgha

segment_text: It’s easy for the bad to do bad,
title: Schism in the Saṅgha

segment_text: but for the noble ones, bad is hard to do.”
title: Schism in the Saṅgha

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: Teasing

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.
title: Teasing

segment_text: Now at that time several students were passing by not far from the Buddha in a teasing manner.
title: Teasing

segment_text: The Buddha saw them.
title: Teasing

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: Teasing

segment_text: “Dolts pretending to be astute,
title: Teasing

segment_text: they talk, their words right out of bounds.
title: Teasing

segment_text: They blab at will, their mouths agape,
title: Teasing

segment_text: and no-one knows what leads them on.”
title: Teasing

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Cūḷapanthaka

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: With Cūḷapanthaka

segment_text: Now at that time Venerable Cūḷapanthaka was sitting not far from the Buddha, cross-legged, his body set straight, and mindfulness established in front of him.
title: With Cūḷapanthaka

segment_text: The Buddha saw him meditating there.
title: With Cūḷapanthaka

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: With Cūḷapanthaka

segment_text: “Steady in body, steady in mind,
title: With Cūḷapanthaka

segment_text: standing, sitting or lying down:
title: With Cūḷapanthaka

segment_text: a mendicant focusing on this mindfulness
title: With Cūḷapanthaka

segment_text: gains an ever higher distinction.
title: With Cūḷapanthaka

segment_text: And when they have done so,
title: With Cūḷapanthaka

segment_text: they vanish from the King of Death.”
title: With Cūḷapanthaka

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: Surrendering the Life Force

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
title: Surrendering the Life Force

segment_text: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Vesālī for alms.
title: Surrendering the Life Force

segment_text: Then, after the meal, on his return from almsround, he addressed Venerable Ānanda:
title: Surrendering the Life Force

segment_text: “Ānanda, get your sitting cloth.
title: Surrendering the Life Force

segment_text: Let’s go to the Cāpāla shrine for the day’s meditation.”
title: Surrendering the Life Force

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” replied Ānanda. Taking his sitting cloth he followed behind the Buddha.
title: Surrendering the Life Force

segment_text: Then the Buddha went up to the Cāpāla shrine, where he sat on the seat spread out.
title: Surrendering the Life Force

segment_text: When he was seated he said to Venerable Ānanda:
title: Surrendering the Life Force

segment_text: “Ānanda, Vesālī is lovely. And the Udena, Gotamaka, Seven Maidens, Many Sons, Sārandada, and Cāpāla Tree-shrines are all lovely.
title: Surrendering the Life Force

segment_text: Whoever has developed and cultivated the four bases of psychic power—made them a vehicle and a basis, kept them up, consolidated them, and properly implemented them—may, if they wish, live for the proper lifespan or what’s left of it.
title: Surrendering the Life Force

segment_text: The Realized One has developed and cultivated the four bases of psychic power, made them a vehicle and a basis, kept them up, consolidated them, and properly implemented them. If he wished, the Realized One could live for the proper lifespan or what’s left of it.”
title: Surrendering the Life Force

segment_text: But Ānanda didn’t get it, even though the Buddha dropped such an obvious hint, such a clear sign.
title: Surrendering the Life Force

segment_text: He didn’t beg the Buddha,
title: Surrendering the Life Force

segment_text: “Sir, may the Blessed One please remain for the eon! May the Holy One please remain for the eon! That would be for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of compassion for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.” For his mind was as if possessed by Māra.
title: Surrendering the Life Force

title: Surrendering the Life Force

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” replied Ānanda. He rose from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before sitting at the root of a tree close by.
title: Surrendering the Life Force

segment_text: And then, not long after Ānanda had left, Māra the Wicked went up to the Buddha, stood to one side, and said to him:
title: Surrendering the Life Force

segment_text: “May the Blessed One now become fully extinguished! May the Holy One now become fully extinguished! Now is the time for the Buddha to become fully extinguished.
title: Surrendering the Life Force

segment_text: Sir, you once made this statement:
title: Surrendering the Life Force

segment_text: ‘Wicked One, I shall not become fully extinguished until I have monk disciples who are competent, educated, assured, learned, have memorized the teachings, and practice in line with the teachings. Not until they practice properly, living in line with the teaching. Not until they’ve learned their own tradition, and explain, teach, assert, establish, disclose, analyze, and make it clear. Not until they can legitimately and completely refute the doctrines of others that come up, and teach with a demonstrable basis.’
title: Surrendering the Life Force

segment_text: Today you do have such monk disciples.
title: Surrendering the Life Force

segment_text: May the Blessed One now become fully extinguished! May the Holy One now become fully extinguished! Now is the time for the Buddha to become fully extinguished.

title: Surrendering the Life Force

title: Surrendering the Life Force

segment_text: “Comparing the incomparable <j>with the creation of prolonged life,

title: Surrendering the Life Force

title: Surrendering the Life Force

segment_text: he shattered self-creation like a suit of armor.”
title: Surrendering the Life Force
