title: Seven Matted-Hair Ascetics

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the Eastern Monastery, the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother.
title: Seven Matted-Hair Ascetics

segment_text: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and sat outside the gate.
title: Seven Matted-Hair Ascetics

segment_text: Then King Pasenadi of Kosala went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side.
title: Seven Matted-Hair Ascetics

segment_text: Now at that time seven matted-hair ascetics, seven Jain ascetics, seven naked ascetics, seven one-cloth ascetics, and seven wanderers passed by not far from the Buddha. Their armpits and bodies were hairy, and their nails were long; and they carried their stuff with shoulder-poles.
title: Seven Matted-Hair Ascetics

segment_text: King Pasenadi saw them passing by.
title: Seven Matted-Hair Ascetics

segment_text: He got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, knelt with his right knee on the ground, raised his joined palms toward those various ascetics, and pronounced his name three times:
title: Seven Matted-Hair Ascetics

segment_text: “Sirs, I am Pasenadi, king of Kosala!
title: Seven Matted-Hair Ascetics

segment_text: I am Pasenadi, king of Kosala!
title: Seven Matted-Hair Ascetics

segment_text: I am Pasenadi, king of Kosala!”
title: Seven Matted-Hair Ascetics

segment_text: Then, soon after those ascetics had left, King Pasenadi went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
title: Seven Matted-Hair Ascetics

segment_text: “Sir, are they among those in the world who are perfected ones or who are on the path to perfection?”
title: Seven Matted-Hair Ascetics

segment_text: “Great king, as a layman enjoying sensual pleasures, living at home with your children, using sandalwood imported from Kāsi, wearing garlands, perfumes, and makeup, and accepting gold and money, it’s hard for you to know who is perfected or on the path to perfection.
title: Seven Matted-Hair Ascetics

segment_text: You can get to know a person’s ethics by living with them. But only after a long time, not casually; only when attentive, not when inattentive; and only by the wise, not the witless.
title: Seven Matted-Hair Ascetics

segment_text: You can get to know a person’s purity by dealing with them. …
title: Seven Matted-Hair Ascetics

segment_text: You can get to know a person’s resilience in times of trouble. …
title: Seven Matted-Hair Ascetics

segment_text: You can get to know a person’s wisdom by discussion. But only after a long time, not casually; only when attentive, not when inattentive; and only by the wise, not the witless.”
title: Seven Matted-Hair Ascetics

segment_text: “It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing,
title: Seven Matted-Hair Ascetics

segment_text: how well said this was by the Buddha. …
title: Seven Matted-Hair Ascetics

segment_text: Sir, these are my spies, my undercover agents returning after spying on the country.
title: Seven Matted-Hair Ascetics

segment_text: First they go undercover, then I have them report to me.
title: Seven Matted-Hair Ascetics

segment_text: And now—when they have washed off the dust and dirt, and are nicely bathed and anointed, with hair and beard dressed, and dressed in white—they will amuse themselves, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation.”
title: Seven Matted-Hair Ascetics

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: Seven Matted-Hair Ascetics

segment_text: “Don’t strive in every situation,
title: Seven Matted-Hair Ascetics

segment_text: don’t become another’s man.
title: Seven Matted-Hair Ascetics

segment_text: Don’t live depending on another,
title: Seven Matted-Hair Ascetics

segment_text: and don’t use the teaching to make money.”
title: Seven Matted-Hair Ascetics

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: The Buddha’s Reviewing

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: The Buddha’s Reviewing

segment_text: Now at that time the Buddha was sitting reviewing his own giving up of many bad, unskillful qualities, and the many skillful qualities he had fully developed.
title: The Buddha’s Reviewing

segment_text: Then, knowing the many bad, unskillful qualities that he had given up and the many skillful qualities he had fully developed, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: The Buddha’s Reviewing

segment_text: “What was before then was not;
title: The Buddha’s Reviewing

segment_text: what before was not then was.
title: The Buddha’s Reviewing

segment_text: It never was, nor will it be,
title: The Buddha’s Reviewing

segment_text: nor is it found today.”
title: The Buddha’s Reviewing

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: Now at that time several ascetics, brahmins, and wanderers who followed various other religions were residing in Sāvatthī, holding different views and opinions, relying on different views.
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: There were some ascetics and brahmins who had this doctrine and view:
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: “The cosmos is eternal. This is the only truth, other ideas are silly.”
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: Others held views such as the following, each regarding their own view as true and others as silly.
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: “The cosmos is not eternal.”
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: “The world is finite.”
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: “The world is infinite.”
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: “The soul and the body are the same thing.”
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: “The soul and the body are different things.”
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: “A Realized One still exists after death.”
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: “A Realized One no longer exists after death.”
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: “A Realized One both still exists and no longer exists after death.”
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: “A Realized One neither still exists nor no longer exists after death.”
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: They were arguing, quarreling, and disputing, continually wounding each other with barbed words:
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: “Such is Truth, such is not Truth!
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: Such is not Truth, such is Truth!”
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: Then several mendicants robed up in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: Then, after the meal, when they returned from almsround, they went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what was happening. The Buddha said:
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: “The wanderers of other religions are blind and sightless.
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: They don't understand what is beneficial or what is not beneficial, nor what is the truth and what is not the truth.
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: That’s why they are arguing, quarreling, and disputing, continually wounding each other with barbed words.
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: Once upon a time, mendicants, right here in Sāvatthī there was a certain king.
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: Then the king addressed a man,
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: ‘Please, mister, gather all those blind from birth throughout Sāvatthī and bring them together in one place.’
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: ‘Yes, Your Majesty,’ that man replied. He did as the king asked, then said to him,
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: ‘Your Majesty, the blind people throughout Sāvatthī have been gathered.’
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: ‘Well then, my man, show them an elephant.’
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: ‘Yes, Your Majesty,’ that man replied. He did as the king asked.
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: To some of the blind people he showed the elephant’s head, saying,
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: ‘Here is the elephant.’
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: To some of them he showed the elephant’s ear, saying,
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: ‘Here is the elephant.’
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: To some of them he showed the elephant’s tusk, saying,
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: ‘Here is the elephant.’
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: To some of them he showed the elephant’s trunk, saying,
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: ‘Here is the elephant.’
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: To some of them he showed the elephant’s flank, saying,
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: ‘Here is the elephant.’
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: To some of them he showed the elephant’s leg, saying,
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: ‘Here is the elephant.’
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: To some of them he showed the elephant’s thigh, saying,
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: ‘Here is the elephant.’
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: To some of them he showed the elephant’s tail, saying,
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: ‘Here is the elephant.’
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: To some of them he showed the tip of the elephant’s tail, saying,
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: ‘Here is the elephant.’
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: Then he approached the king and said,
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: ‘Your Majesty, the blind people have been shown the elephant.
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: Please go at your convenience.’
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: Then the king went up to the blind people and said,
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: ‘Have you seen the elephant?’
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: ‘Yes, Your Majesty, we have been shown the elephant.’
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: ‘Then tell us, what kind of thing is an elephant?’
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: The blind people who had been shown the elephant’s head said,
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: ‘Your Majesty, an elephant is like a pot.’
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: Those who had been shown the ear said,
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: ‘An elephant is like a winnowing fan.’
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: Those who had been shown the tusk said,
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: ‘An elephant is like a ploughshare.’
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: Those who had been shown the trunk said,
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: ‘An elephant is like a plough-pole.’
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: Those who had been shown the flank said,
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: ‘An elephant is like a storehouse.’
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: Those who had been shown the leg said,
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: ‘An elephant is like a pillar.’
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: Those who had been shown the thigh said,
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: ‘An elephant is like a mortar.’
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: Those who had been shown the tail said,
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: ‘An elephant is like a pestle.’
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: Those who had been shown the tip of the tail said,
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: ‘An elephant is like a broom.’
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: Saying, ‘Such is an elephant, not such!
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: Such is not an elephant, such is!’ they punched each other with their fists.
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: At that, the king was pleased.
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: In the same way, mendicants, the wanderers of other religions are blind and sightless.
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: They don't understand what is beneficial or what is not beneficial, nor what is the truth and what is not the truth.
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: That’s why they are arguing, quarreling, and disputing, continually wounding each other with barbed words.
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: ‘Such is Truth, such is not!
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: Such is not Truth, such is!’”
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: “Some ascetics and brahmins, it seems,
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: cling to these things.
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: Arguing, they quarrel,
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: the folk who see just one part.”
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (1st)

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (2nd)

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (2nd)

segment_text: Now at that time several ascetics, brahmins, and wanderers who followed various other religions were residing in Sāvatthī, holding different views and opinions, relying on different views.
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (2nd)

segment_text: There were some ascetics and brahmins who had this doctrine and view:
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (2nd)

segment_text: “The self and the cosmos are eternal. This is the only truth, other ideas are silly.”
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (2nd)

segment_text: Others held views such as the following, each regarding their own view as true and others as silly.
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (2nd)

segment_text: “The self and the cosmos are not eternal.”
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (2nd)

segment_text: “The self and the cosmos are both eternal and not eternal.”
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (2nd)

segment_text: “The self and the cosmos are neither eternal nor not eternal.”
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (2nd)

segment_text: “The self and the cosmos are made by oneself.”
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (2nd)

segment_text: “The self and the cosmos are made by another.”
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (2nd)

segment_text: “The self and the cosmos are made by both oneself and another.”
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (2nd)

segment_text: “The self and the cosmos have arisen by chance, not made by oneself or another.”
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (2nd)

segment_text: “Pleasure and pain are eternal, and the self and the cosmos.”
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (2nd)

segment_text: “Pleasure and pain are not eternal, and the self and the cosmos.”
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (2nd)

segment_text: “Pleasure and pain are both eternal and not eternal, and the self and the cosmos.”
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (2nd)

segment_text: “Pleasure and pain are neither eternal nor not eternal, and the self and the cosmos.”
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (2nd)

segment_text: “Pleasure and pain are made by oneself, and the self and the cosmos.”
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (2nd)

segment_text: “Pleasure and pain are made by another, and the self and the cosmos.”
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (2nd)

segment_text: “Pleasure and pain are made by both oneself and another, and the self and the cosmos.”
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (2nd)

segment_text: “Pleasure and pain have arisen by chance, not made by oneself or another, and the self and the cosmos.”
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (2nd)

segment_text: They were arguing, quarreling, and disputing, continually wounding each other with barbed words:
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (2nd)

segment_text: “Such is Truth, such is not Truth!
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (2nd)

segment_text: Such is not Truth, such is Truth!”
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (2nd)

segment_text: Then several mendicants robed up in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (2nd)

segment_text: Then, after the meal, when they returned from almsround, they went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what was happening.
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (2nd)

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (2nd)

segment_text: “Some ascetics and brahmins, it seems,
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (2nd)

segment_text: cling to these things.
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (2nd)

segment_text: They flounder in mid-stream,
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (2nd)

segment_text: without reaching a firm footing.”
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (2nd)

segment_text: So I have heard.

title: Followers of Various Other Religions (3rd)

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (3rd)

segment_text: “Folk are fixated on the I-maker,
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (3rd)

segment_text: which is tied up with the other-maker.
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (3rd)

segment_text: There are some who do not realize this,
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (3rd)

segment_text: they do not see the dart.
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (3rd)

segment_text: But when they see this dart,
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (3rd)

segment_text: they do not think, ‘I make it’,
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (3rd)

segment_text: nor ‘another makes it’.
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (3rd)

segment_text: These folk are caught up in conceit,
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (3rd)

segment_text: tied by conceit, shackled by conceit.
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (3rd)

segment_text: Vehemently defending their views,
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (3rd)

segment_text: they don’t escape transmigration.”
title: Followers of Various Other Religions (3rd)

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Subhūti

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: With Subhūti

segment_text: Now at that time Venerable Subhūti was sitting not far from the Buddha, cross-legged, with his body straight, having attained the immersion free of placing the mind.
title: With Subhūti

segment_text: The Buddha saw him meditating there.
title: With Subhūti

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: With Subhūti

segment_text: “In whom mental vibrations are cleared away,
title: With Subhūti

segment_text: internally clipped off entirely,
title: With Subhūti

segment_text: perceiving the formless, beyond attachments,
title: With Subhūti

segment_text: having overcome the four yokes, <j>they are not born again.”
title: With Subhūti

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: The Courtesan

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
title: The Courtesan

segment_text: Now at that time two gangs were both hopelessly in love with a certain courtesan.
title: The Courtesan

segment_text: Quarreling, arguing, and disputing, they attacked each other with fists, stones, rods, and swords,
title: The Courtesan

segment_text: resulting in death and deadly pain.
title: The Courtesan

segment_text: Then several mendicants robed up in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, entered Rājagaha for alms.
title: The Courtesan

segment_text: Then, after the meal, when they returned from almsround, they went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what was happening.
title: The Courtesan

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: The Courtesan

segment_text: “What has been attained and what is to be attained are both strewn over with dust for that one training while still sick.
title: The Courtesan

segment_text: Those for whom the training is the essence, or precepts and observances, celibacy, and service as the essence: this is one extreme.
title: The Courtesan

segment_text: Those who say,
title: The Courtesan

segment_text: ‘There’s nothing wrong with sensual pleasures’: this is the second extreme.
title: The Courtesan

segment_text: Thus these two extremes swell the charnel grounds, while the charnel grounds swell wrong view.
title: The Courtesan

segment_text: Not realizing these two extremes, some get stuck and some overreach.
title: The Courtesan

segment_text: Those who realize these things, who were not found there, who did not conceive by that, there is no cycle of rebirths to be found.”
title: The Courtesan

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: Hastening By

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: Hastening By

segment_text: Now at that time the Buddha was meditating in the open during the dark of night, while oil lamps were burning.
title: Hastening By

segment_text: And many moths were falling down and crashing down into the lamps, coming to grief and ruin.
title: Hastening By

segment_text: The Buddha saw the moths coming to grief.
title: Hastening By

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: Hastening By

segment_text: “Hastening by, they miss the essence,
title: Hastening By

segment_text: sprouting ever more new bonds.
title: Hastening By

segment_text: Like moths falling in the flame,
title: Hastening By

segment_text: some have become fixed in what is seen or heard.”
title: Hastening By

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: Arising

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: Arising

segment_text: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:
title: Arising

segment_text: “Sir, so long as the Realized Ones, the perfected ones, the fully awakened Buddhas do not arise in the world, the wanderers of other religions are honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed. And they receive robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
title: Arising

segment_text: But when the Realized Ones do arise in the world, the wanderers of other religions are no longer honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed. And they do not receive robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
title: Arising

segment_text: Now only the Buddha is honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed. And he receives robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.”
title: Arising

segment_text: “That’s so true, Ānanda. So long as the Realized Ones do not arise in the world, the wanderers of other religions are honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed. And they receive robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
title: Arising

segment_text: But when the Realized Ones do arise in the world, the wanderers of other religions are no longer honored in this way.
title: Arising

segment_text: Now only the Realized One is honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed. And he receives robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick. And so does the mendicant Saṅgha.”
title: Arising

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: Arising

segment_text: “The glow-worm shines so long
title: Arising

segment_text: as the beacon of the sun does not rise.
title: Arising

segment_text: But when the sun has come up,
title: Arising

segment_text: that light is erased and shines no more.
title: Arising

segment_text: So too the reasoners shine bright
title: Arising

segment_text: so long as the Buddhas don’t arise in the world.
title: Arising

segment_text: The reasoners are not purified, nor are their disciples.
title: Arising

segment_text: Having bad views, they are not freed from suffering.”
title: Arising

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: Bhaddiya the Dwarf (1st)

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: Bhaddiya the Dwarf (1st)

segment_text: Now at that time Venerable Sāriputta was educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring Venerable Bhaddiya the Dwarf in many ways with a Dhamma talk.
title: Bhaddiya the Dwarf (1st)

segment_text: Then after being taught like this Bhaddiya’s mind was freed from defilements by not grasping.
title: Bhaddiya the Dwarf (1st)

segment_text: The Buddha saw what had happened.
title: Bhaddiya the Dwarf (1st)

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: Bhaddiya the Dwarf (1st)

segment_text: “Above, below, everywhere free,
title: Bhaddiya the Dwarf (1st)

segment_text: not contemplating ‘I am this’.
title: Bhaddiya the Dwarf (1st)

segment_text: Freed like this, he has crossed the flood
title: Bhaddiya the Dwarf (1st)

segment_text: not crossed before, so as to not be reborn.”
title: Bhaddiya the Dwarf (1st)

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: Bhaddiya the Dwarf (2nd)

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: Bhaddiya the Dwarf (2nd)

segment_text: Now at that time Venerable Sāriputta was educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring Venerable Bhaddiya the Dwarf in even more ways with a Dhamma talk, thinking that he was still a trainee.
title: Bhaddiya the Dwarf (2nd)

segment_text: The Buddha saw what was happening.
title: Bhaddiya the Dwarf (2nd)

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: Bhaddiya the Dwarf (2nd)

segment_text: “They’ve cut the cycle, gone to the wishless;
title: Bhaddiya the Dwarf (2nd)

segment_text: the streams are dried, they flow no more.
title: Bhaddiya the Dwarf (2nd)

segment_text: Cut, the cycle no longer turns.
title: Bhaddiya the Dwarf (2nd)

segment_text: Just this is the end of suffering.”
title: Bhaddiya the Dwarf (2nd)

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: Clinging (1st)

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: Clinging (1st)

segment_text: Now at that time most of the people in Sāvatthī overly clung to sensual pleasures. Lustful, greedy, tied, infatuated, they lived completely addicted to sensual pleasures.
title: Clinging (1st)

segment_text: Then several mendicants robed up in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
title: Clinging (1st)

segment_text: Then, after the meal, when they returned from almsround, they went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what was happening.
title: Clinging (1st)

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: Clinging (1st)

segment_text: “Clinging to sensual pleasures, <j>to the chains of the senses,
title: Clinging (1st)

segment_text: blind to the faults of the fetters,
title: Clinging (1st)

segment_text: clinging to the chain of the fetters,
title: Clinging (1st)

segment_text: there’s no way they can cross the flood so vast.”
title: Clinging (1st)

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: Clinging (2nd)

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: Clinging (2nd)

segment_text: Now at that time most of the people in Sāvatthī clung to sensual pleasures. Lustful, greedy, tied, infatuated, attached, and blinded, they lived completely addicted to sensual pleasures.
title: Clinging (2nd)

segment_text: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
title: Clinging (2nd)

segment_text: He saw how attached the people were.
title: Clinging (2nd)

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: Clinging (2nd)

segment_text: “Blinded by sensual pleasures, wrapped in a net,
title: Clinging (2nd)

segment_text: they are smothered over by craving;
title: Clinging (2nd)

segment_text: bound by the kinsman of the negligent,
title: Clinging (2nd)

segment_text: like a fish caught in a funnel-net trap.
title: Clinging (2nd)

segment_text: They chase old age and death,
title: Clinging (2nd)

segment_text: like a suckling calf its mother.”
title: Clinging (2nd)

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: Another Discourse with Bhaddiya the Dwarf

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: Another Discourse with Bhaddiya the Dwarf

segment_text: Then Venerable Bhaddiya the Dwarf, closely following several mendicants, approached the Buddha.
title: Another Discourse with Bhaddiya the Dwarf

segment_text: The Buddha saw Venerable Bhaddiya coming off in the distance—ugly, unsightly, deformed, and despised by most of the mendicants.
title: Another Discourse with Bhaddiya the Dwarf

segment_text: The Buddha addressed the mendicants:
title: Another Discourse with Bhaddiya the Dwarf

segment_text: “Mendicants, do you see this monk coming—ugly, unsightly, deformed, and despised by most of the mendicants?”
title: Another Discourse with Bhaddiya the Dwarf

segment_text: “Yes, sir.”
title: Another Discourse with Bhaddiya the Dwarf

segment_text: “That mendicant is very mighty and powerful. It’s not easy to find an attainment that he has not already attained.
title: Another Discourse with Bhaddiya the Dwarf

segment_text: And he has realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lives having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.”
title: Another Discourse with Bhaddiya the Dwarf

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: Another Discourse with Bhaddiya the Dwarf

segment_text: “With flawless wheel and white canopy,
title: Another Discourse with Bhaddiya the Dwarf

segment_text: the one-spoke chariot rolls on.
title: Another Discourse with Bhaddiya the Dwarf

segment_text: See it come, untroubled,
title: Another Discourse with Bhaddiya the Dwarf

segment_text: with stream cut, unbound.”
title: Another Discourse with Bhaddiya the Dwarf

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: The Ending of Craving

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: The Ending of Craving

segment_text: Now at that time Venerable Koṇḍañña Who Understood was sitting not far from the Buddha, cross-legged, with his body straight, reviewing the freedom through the ending of craving.
title: The Ending of Craving

segment_text: The Buddha saw him meditating there.
title: The Ending of Craving

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: The Ending of Craving

segment_text: “There is no root or ground or leaves for them,
title: The Ending of Craving

segment_text: so where would creepers sprout from?
title: The Ending of Craving

segment_text: That wise one is released from bonds:
title: The Ending of Craving

segment_text: who is worthy to criticize them?
title: The Ending of Craving

segment_text: Even the gods praise them,
title: The Ending of Craving

segment_text: and by Brahmā, too, they’re praised.”
title: The Ending of Craving

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: The Ending of Proliferation

title: About Extinguishment (1st)

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: About Extinguishment (1st)

segment_text: Now at that time the Buddha was educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants with a Dhamma talk about extinguishment.
title: About Extinguishment (1st)

segment_text: And those mendicants were paying attention, applying the mind, concentrating wholeheartedly, and actively listening.
title: About Extinguishment (1st)

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: About Extinguishment (1st)

segment_text: “There is, mendicants, that dimension where there is no earth, no water, no fire, no wind; no dimension of infinite space, no dimension of infinite consciousness, no dimension of nothingness, no dimension of neither perception nor non-perception; no this world, no other world, no moon or sun.
title: About Extinguishment (1st)

segment_text: There, mendicants, I say there is no coming or going or remaining or passing away or reappearing.
title: About Extinguishment (1st)

segment_text: It is not established, does not proceed, and has no support.
title: About Extinguishment (1st)

segment_text: Just this is the end of suffering.”
title: About Extinguishment (1st)

segment_text: So I have heard.

title: About Extinguishment (3rd)

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: About Extinguishment (3rd)

segment_text: Now at that time the Buddha was educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants with a Dhamma talk about extinguishment.
title: About Extinguishment (3rd)

segment_text: And those mendicants were paying attention, applying the mind, concentrating wholeheartedly, and actively listening.
title: About Extinguishment (3rd)

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: About Extinguishment (3rd)

segment_text: “There is, mendicants, an unborn, unproduced, unmade, and unconditioned.
title: About Extinguishment (3rd)

segment_text: If there were no unborn, unproduced, unmade, and unconditioned, then you would find no escape here from the born, produced, made, and conditioned.

title: About Extinguishment (4th)

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: About Extinguishment (4th)

segment_text: Now at that time the Buddha was educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants with a Dhamma talk about extinguishment.
title: About Extinguishment (4th)

segment_text: And those mendicants were paying attention, applying the mind, concentrating wholeheartedly, and actively listening.
title: About Extinguishment (4th)

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: About Extinguishment (4th)

segment_text: “For the dependent there is agitation. For the independent there’s no agitation.
title: About Extinguishment (4th)

segment_text: When there’s no agitation there is tranquility.
title: About Extinguishment (4th)

segment_text: When there is tranquility there’s no inclination.
title: About Extinguishment (4th)

segment_text: When there’s no inclination, there’s no coming and going.
title: About Extinguishment (4th)

segment_text: When there’s no coming and going, there’s no passing away and reappearing.
title: About Extinguishment (4th)

segment_text: When there’s no passing away and reappearing there’s no this world or world beyond or between the two.
title: About Extinguishment (4th)

segment_text: Just this is the end of suffering.”
title: About Extinguishment (4th)

title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Magadhans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants when he arrived at the village of Pāṭali.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: The lay followers of Pāṭali Village heard that he had arrived.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: So they went to see him, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: “Sir, please consent to come to our guest house.”
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: The Buddha consented with silence.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, the lay followers of Pāṭali Village got up from their seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right. Then they went to the guest house, where they spread carpets all over, prepared seats, set up a water jar, and placed a lamp. Then they went back to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and told him of their preparations, saying:
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: “Please, sir, come at your convenience.”
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: In the morning, the Buddha robed up and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the guest house together with the Saṅgha of mendicants. Having washed his feet he entered the guest house and sat against the central column facing east.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: The Saṅgha of mendicants also washed their feet, entered the guest house, and sat against the west wall facing east, with the Buddha right in front of them.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: The lay followers of Pāṭali Village also washed their feet, entered the guest house, and sat against the east wall facing west, with the Buddha right in front of them.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: Then the Buddha addressed them:
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: “Householders, there are these five drawbacks for an unethical person because of their failure in ethics.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: What five?
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: Firstly, an unethical person loses substantial wealth on account of negligence.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: This is the first drawback.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: Furthermore, an unethical person gets a bad reputation.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: This is the second drawback.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: Furthermore, an unethical person enters any kind of assembly timid and embarrassed, whether it’s an assembly of aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or ascetics.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: This is the third drawback.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: Furthermore, an unethical person feels lost when they die.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: This is the fourth drawback.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: Furthermore, an unethical person, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: This is the fifth drawback.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: These are the five drawbacks for an unethical person because of their failure in ethics.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: There are these five benefits for an ethical person because of their accomplishment in ethics.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: What five?
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: Firstly, an ethical person gains substantial wealth on account of diligence.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: This is the first benefit.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: Furthermore, an ethical person gets a good reputation.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: This is the second benefit.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: Furthermore, an ethical person enters any kind of assembly bold and self-assured, whether it’s an assembly of aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or ascetics.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: This is the third benefit.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: Furthermore, an ethical person dies not feeling lost.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: This is the fourth benefit.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: Furthermore, when an ethical person’s body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: This is the fifth benefit.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: These are the five benefits for an ethical person because of their accomplishment in ethics.”
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: The Buddha spent much of the night educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the lay followers of Pāṭali Village with a Dhamma talk. Then he dismissed them,
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: “The night is getting late, householders. Please go at your convenience.”
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: And then the lay followers of Pāṭali Village approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. They got up from their seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right, before leaving.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: Soon after they left the Buddha entered a private cubicle.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: Now at that time the Magadhan ministers Sunidha and Vassakāra were building a citadel at Pāṭali Village to keep the Vajjis out.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: At that time thousands of deities were taking possession of building sites in Pāṭali Village.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: Illustrious rulers or royal ministers inclined to build houses at sites possessed by illustrious deities.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: Middling rulers or royal ministers inclined to build houses at sites possessed by middling deities.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: Lesser rulers or royal ministers inclined to build houses at sites possessed by lesser deities.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, the Buddha saw those deities taking possession of building sites in Pāṭali Village,
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: and the people building houses in accord with the station of the deities.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: The Buddha rose at the crack of dawn and addressed Ānanda,
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: “Ānanda, who is building a citadel at Pāṭali Village?”
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: “Sir, the Magadhan ministers Sunidha and Vassakāra are building a citadel to keep the Vajjis out.”
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: “It’s as if they were building the citadel in consultation with the gods of the Thirty-Three.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I saw those deities taking possession of building sites.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: Illustrious rulers or royal ministers inclined to build houses at sites possessed by illustrious deities.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: Middling rulers or royal ministers inclined to build houses at sites possessed by middling deities.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: Lesser rulers or royal ministers inclined to build houses at sites possessed by lesser deities.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: As far as the civilized region extends, as far as the trading zone extends, this will be the chief city: the Pāṭaliputta trade center.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: But Pāṭaliputta will face three threats:
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: from fire, flood, and dissension.”
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: Then the Magadhan ministers Sunidha and Vassakāra approached the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they stood to one side and said,
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: “Would Master Gotama together with the mendicant Saṅgha please accept today’s meal from me?”
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, they went to their own guest house, where they had delicious fresh and cooked foods prepared. Then they had the Buddha informed of the time, saying,
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: “It’s time, Master Gotama, the meal is ready.”
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to their guest house together with the mendicant Saṅgha, where he sat on the seat spread out.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: Then Sunidha and Vassakāra served and satisfied the mendicant Saṅgha headed by the Buddha with their own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: When the Buddha had eaten and washed his hand and bowl, Sunidha and Vassakāra took a low seat and sat to one side.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: The Buddha expressed his appreciation with these verses:
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: “In the place he makes his dwelling,
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: having fed the astute
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: and the virtuous here,
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: the restrained spiritual practitioners,
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: he should dedicate an offering
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: to the deities there.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: Venerated, they venerate him;
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: honored, they honor him.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: After that they have compassion for him,
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: like a mother for the child at her breast.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: A man beloved of the deities
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: always sees nice things.”
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: When the Buddha had expressed his appreciation to Sunidha and Vassakāra with these verses, he got up from his seat and left.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: Sunidha and Vassakāra followed behind the Buddha, thinking,
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: “The gate through which the ascetic Gotama departs today shall be named the Gotama Gate.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: The ford at which he crosses the Ganges River shall be named the Gotama Ford.”
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: Then the gate through which the Buddha departed was named the Gotama Gate.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: Then the Buddha came to the Ganges River.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: Now at that time the Ganges was full to the brim so a crow could drink from it.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: Wanting to cross from the near to the far shore, some people were seeking a boat, some a dinghy, while some were tying up a raft.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: But, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, the Buddha, together with the mendicant Saṅgha, vanished from the near shore and landed on the far shore.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: He saw all those people wanting to cross over.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: “Those who cross a deluge or stream
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: have built a bridge and left the marshes behind.
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: While some people are still tying a raft,
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: intelligent people have crossed over.”
title: The Layfolk of Pāṭali Village

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: A Fork in the Road

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was traveling along a road in the Kosalan lands with Venerable Nāgasamāla as his second monk.
title: A Fork in the Road

segment_text: Nāgasamāla saw a fork in the road
title: A Fork in the Road

segment_text: and said to the Buddha,
title: A Fork in the Road

segment_text: “Sir, this is the road,
title: A Fork in the Road

segment_text: let us go this way.”
title: A Fork in the Road

segment_text: But when he said this the Buddha responded,
title: A Fork in the Road

segment_text: “Nāgasamāla, this is the road,
title: A Fork in the Road

segment_text: let us go this way.”
title: A Fork in the Road

segment_text: For a second time,
title: A Fork in the Road

segment_text: and a  third time Nāgasamāla said to the Buddha,
title: A Fork in the Road

segment_text: “Sir, this is the road,
title: A Fork in the Road

segment_text: let us go this way.”
title: A Fork in the Road

segment_text: And for a third time the Buddha responded,
title: A Fork in the Road

segment_text: “Nāgasamāla, this is the road,
title: A Fork in the Road

segment_text: let us go this way.”
title: A Fork in the Road

segment_text: Then Nāgasamāla put the Buddha’s bowl and robes down on the ground right there and left, saying,
title: A Fork in the Road

segment_text: “Sir, here are your bowl and robes.”
title: A Fork in the Road

segment_text: Then as Nāgasamāla was going down that road, he was set upon by bandits who struck him with fists and feet, broke his bowl, and tore up his outer robe.
title: A Fork in the Road

segment_text: Then Nāgasamāla—with his bowl broken and his outer robe torn—went to the Buddha and told him what had happened.
title: A Fork in the Road

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: A Fork in the Road

segment_text: “Walking together, dwelling as one,
title: A Fork in the Road

segment_text: the knowledge master mixes with foolish folk.
title: A Fork in the Road

segment_text: Knowing this, they give up wickedness,
title: A Fork in the Road

segment_text: like a milk-drinking heron the water.”
title: A Fork in the Road

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the Eastern Monastery, the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother.
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: Now at that time the dear and beloved granddaughter of Visākhā Migāra’s Mother had just passed away.
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: Then, in the middle of the day, Visākhā with wet clothes and hair went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down.
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: The Buddha said to her,
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: “So, Visākhā, where are you coming from in the middle of the day with wet clothes and hair?”
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: “Sir, my beloved granddaughter has just passed away.
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: That’s why I came here in the middle of the day with wet clothes and hair.”
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: “Visākhā, would you like as many children and grandchildren as there are people in the whole of Sāvatthī?”
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: “I would, sir.”
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: “But Visākhā, how many people pass away each day in Sāvatthī?”
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: “Every day, sir, there are ten people passing away in Sāvatthī.
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: Or else there are nine,
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: eight,
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: seven,
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: six,
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: five,
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: four,
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: three,
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: two,
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: or at least one person who passes away every day in Sāvatthī.
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: Sāvatthī is never without someone passing away.”
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: “What do you think, Visākhā? Would there ever be a time when your clothes and hair were not wet?”
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: “No, sir.
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: Enough, sir, with so many children and grandchildren.”
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: “Those who have a hundred loved ones, Visākhā, have a hundred sufferings.
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: Those who have ninety loved ones,
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: or eighty,
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: seventy,
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: sixty,
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: fifty,
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: forty,
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: thirty,
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: twenty,
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: ten,
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: nine,
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: eight,
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: seven,
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: six,
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: five,
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: four,
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: three,
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: two,
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: or one loved one have one suffering.
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: Those who have no loved ones have no suffering. They are free of sorrow, stains, and anguish I say.”
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: “All the sorrows and lamentations
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: and the countless forms of suffering in the world
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: occur because of those that we love;
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: without loved ones they do not occur.
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: That’s why those who have no loved ones <j>at all in the world
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: are happy and free of grief.
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: So aspiring to the sorrowless and stainless,
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: have no loved ones in the world at all.”
title: With Visākhā

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Dabba (1st)

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
title: With Dabba (1st)

segment_text: Then Venerable Dabba the Mallian went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:
title: With Dabba (1st)

segment_text: “Holy One, it is the time for my full extinguishment.”
title: With Dabba (1st)

segment_text: “Please, Dabba, do as you see fit.”
title: With Dabba (1st)

segment_text: Then Dabba rose from his seat, bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right. Then he rose into the air and, sitting cross-legged in the sky, entered and withdrew from the fire element before becoming fully extinguished.
title: With Dabba (1st)

segment_text: Then when he became fully extinguished while sitting in the sky, his body burning and combusting left neither ashes nor soot to be found.
title: With Dabba (1st)

segment_text: It’s like when ghee or oil blaze and burn, and neither ashes nor soot are found.
title: With Dabba (1st)

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: With Dabba (1st)

segment_text: “The body is broken up, perception has ceased,
title: With Dabba (1st)

segment_text: all feelings have become cool;
title: With Dabba (1st)

segment_text: choices are stilled,
title: With Dabba (1st)

segment_text: and consciousness come to an end.”
title: With Dabba (1st)

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: Dabba (2nd)

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: Dabba (2nd)

segment_text: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
title: Dabba (2nd)

segment_text: “Mendicants!”
title: Dabba (2nd)

segment_text: “Venerable sir,” they replied.
title: Dabba (2nd)

segment_text: The Buddha said this:
title: Dabba (2nd)

segment_text: “Mendicants, when Dabba the Mallian rose into the air and, sitting cross-legged in the sky, entered and withdrew from the fire element before becoming fully extinguished, his body burning and combusting left neither ashes nor soot to be found.
title: Dabba (2nd)

segment_text: It’s like when ghee or oil blaze and burn, and neither ashes nor soot are found.
title: Dabba (2nd)

segment_text: In the same way, when Dabba the Mallian rose into the air and, sitting cross-legged in the sky, entered and withdrew from the fire element before becoming fully extinguished, his body burning and combusting left neither ashes nor soot to be found.”
title: Dabba (2nd)

segment_text: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
title: Dabba (2nd)

segment_text: “When an iron bar is struck
title: Dabba (2nd)

segment_text: by heat and flame
title: Dabba (2nd)

segment_text: the heat gradually dissipates,
title: Dabba (2nd)

segment_text: and where it has gone no-one knows.
title: Dabba (2nd)

segment_text: In the same way for the rightly released,
title: Dabba (2nd)

segment_text: who have crossed the flood of sensual bonds,
title: Dabba (2nd)

segment_text: and attained unshakable happiness,
title: Dabba (2nd)

segment_text: where they have gone cannot be found.”
title: Dabba (2nd)

segment_text: The Heartfelt Sayings are finished.
title: Dabba (2nd)
